PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Disarmament
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Nuclear Disarmament
To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth: That your petitioners are concerned about foreign owned military bases on Australian territory and the entry into Australian waters and territory of foreign warships and aircraft carrying nuclear weaponry. And that the Australian Government should take an active and constructive role in the promotion of a nuclear-free world. Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should:
1. Promote the expression of Australian sovereignty by legislating to bring foreign military bases on Australian territory under the control of the Australian Government.

2. Make it compulsory that the disclosure of weaponry carried by foreign warships and aircraft be given in confidence to the Australian Government prior to a request for entry. And that foreign warships and aircraft that carry nuclear weaponry be banned from Australian waters and territory.
3. Legislate for the cessation of all uranium mining in Australia and its subsequent export.

4. Urge the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to pose to the Governments of the United States and the Soviet Union that both countries agree to immediately halt the testing, production and further deployment of all nuclear weapons, missiles and delivery systems in a way that can be checked and verified by both sides.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
We have become the innocent victims of your Government's Medicare scheme.
We are forced to pay 1 per cent of our wages only to receive less per capita benefits than the people of other states.

Without canvassing the rights or wrongs of the dispute between the Federal Government and the State of Queensland the fact is that because of it over one million Queenslanders, who contribute to health funds, are being blatantly discriminated against compared with people in the rest of Australia.
Because of the dispute over the introduction of Medicare, Queensland public hospital bed charges are $120 per day compared with $80.00 per day in the other states. This is grossly unfair.
As it was the Federal Government which decided to introduce Medicare, we believe it is their responsibility to take action allowing health funds' rates in Queensland to be kept at reasonable levels.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should use its influence with Government so as to avoid the discrimination (of $ 40 per day) against insured Queenslanders
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Export of Kangaroo Products
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth their desire to stop the commercial exploitation of the kangaroo.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House re-apply the ban on the export of kangaroo products.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend the Acts Interpretation Act 1901.
Bill presented by Senator Gareth Evans, and read a first time.
Standing Orders suspended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to facilitate the giving of effect to the intentions of the Parliament when Acts of the Parliament fall to be interpreted. The Bill makes a number of amendments to the existing Acts Interpretation Act 1901 for this purpose. Eighteen new provisions are proposed to be inserted in the Act, in some cases in substitution for existing provisions. Some of the amendments are of a technical nature and are explained in the explanatory memorandum that has been circulated. I deal with the more important provisions in this second reading speech.
Use of Extrinsic Material in the Interpretation of an Act

First and foremost I refer to the proposed new section 15AB, which provides that, if any material not forming part of the Act is capable of assisting in the ascertainment of the meaning of a provision of the Act, consideration may be given to that material. The important point to note is that the word used is ' may', not 'shall'. That is to say, reference to such materials is not to be compulsory but is to be left to the discretion and the judgment of the courts. The provision also states that, in the contemplation of the Parliament, such material would be used for one of two purposes:

(a) to confirm that the meaning of the provision is the ordinary meaning conveyed by the text of the provision taking into account its context in the Act and the purpose or object underlying the Act; or
(b) to determine the meaning of the provision when either the provision is ambiguous or obscure, or the ordinary meaning is manifestly absurd or is unreasonable.

The provision therefore does not contemplate that extrinsic material would be used to overturn the ordinary meaning of a provision, arrived at by taking into account the purpose or object underlying the Act, unless there is an ambiguity or obscurity or something that is manifestly absurd or unreasonable. On the other hand, the provision does make it clear that extrinsic materials can be looked at to confirm the ordinary meaning of an Act. The fact is that judges do this already, and have been doing so for some time.

The provision goes on in sub-section (2) to specify, in a non-exhaustive way, the main categories of extrinsic materials that can assist in the interpretation of Acts. As well as such obvious matters as headings and marginal notes to provisions, and end notes in the text of the Act as printed by the Government Printer, the following categories are covered:
any relevant reports laid before or made to Parliament before the time when the provision was enacted;
any treaty or other international agreement that is referred to in the Act;
the explanatory memorandum relating to the Bill circulated to members of parliament before the time when the provision was enacted;
the second reading speech of the Minister;
any document that is expressly declared by the Act in question to be a relevant document for the purposes of section 15AB;
finally, any relevant material in the Journals or Votes and Proceedings or in Hansard.
Attention is also drawn to sub-section (3), which conveys the clear wish and intention of Parliament that in applying section 15AB regard shall be had to:
the desirability of persons being able to rely on the ordinary meaning conveyed by the text of the provision, taking into account the purpose or object underlying the Act; and
the need to avoid prolonging legal or other proceedings without compensating advantages.

In my ministerial statement tabled in the Senate on 30 November 1983 I said that the reaching of a satisfactory outcome in relation to the use of extrinsic materials would depend on the good sense of both judges and parliament combining to produce a situation in which the range of materials, and the way in which they are used, are reasonably defined and confined. Section 15AB meets these requirements. It does so in a way that respects the independence of the judiciary. Judges are neither required to nor prohibited from looking at any materials. On the other hand, the Parliament in section 15AB would be giving a clear lead as to the way in which extrinsic materials can best be used, without imposing undue burdens on the users of legislation or on the legal system generally. The provision is in accord with the deliberations of the top level Symposium on Statutory Interpretation-convened by Senator Durack last year-the proceedings of which were tabled at the time of my ministerial statement of 30 November 1983. The Symposium supported the proposition that Parliament should give a lead, as it had already successfully done in section 15AA of the Acts Interpretation Act, by recognising that judges have, or should have, a discretion to refer to extrinsic materials where to do so can assist in the interpretation of Acts.

There is a clear link between the proposed new section 15AB and section 15AA, which was inserted in the Acts Interpetation Act in 1981 on the initiative-which I commend-of the then Attorney-General, Senator Durack. We strongly supported that provision when in Opposition. It requires the purpose or object underlying an Act to be taken into account when interpreting its provisions. As Attorney- General I successfully moved the adoption of a similar provision for inclusion in the Companies and Securities (Interpretation and Miscellaneous Provisions) Act passed in 1983. I am pleased to say that the provision so inserted has already had a significant beneficial effect. In a decision handed down on 28 February 1984-just a few days ago-Mr Justice Hampel of the Victorian Supreme Court expressly relied on that provision in deciding that a share offer should have been made by way of a prospectus. As one commentator observed, use of this approach will lead to less legalistic or literal interpretations of the national code of companies and securities legislation, as was the original intention.

A provision identical with section 15AA was included in the Interpretation of Legislation Bill recently introduced into the Victorian Parliament. That Bill also contains a provision dealing with the use of extrinsic materials. That provision is less elaborate than our proposed section 15AB, but the two provisions are basically consistent one with the other, partly as a result of consultation at officer and ministerial levels. Perhaps in time there will be greater commonality between the laws of the Commonwealth and the laws of various States in this area. However, I am sure honourable senators will agree that it is appropriate for the Commonwealth to take the lead in this area, as indeed it did with section 15AA.
Reference to Gender in Acts

The existing Acts Interpretation Act provides in section 23, and has so provided since 1901, that words importing the masculine gender shall include the female, unless the contrary intention appears. I propose by this Bill that this sexist way of dealing with matters of gender should be altered so that the provision simply provides that, unless the contrary intention appears, words importing a gender include the other gender.
Modern Methods of Recording Information

Section 25 of the existing Act needs to be rewritten to define documents and writing so as to include modern modes of storing and reproducing words, figures, symbols, et cetera. Also, a provision needs to be inserted to provide for the production of records kept in a computer or in similar facilities, where an Act requires a person to produce the information in question. This is dealt with in the proposed new section 25A.
Statement of Reasons

A new standard provision needs to be inserted stating that where an Act requires the giving of written reasons for a decision, the instrument giving the reasons shall also set out the findings on material questions of fact and refer to the evidence or other material on which those findings are based. The form of this provision is derived from section 28 of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975 and from section 13 of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977.
Attaining a Particular Age

There is a little known legal rule of medieval origin-no doubt of appeal to the Opposition-that a person attains a particular age at the first moment of the day immediately before the anniversary of his birth. Thus a person becomes, say, sixty not on the first instant of the sixtieth anniversary of his day of birth but on the first instant of the day immediately before that birthday. I refer anyone interested in this esoterica to the judgment of Sir Owen Dixon in Prowse v. McIntyre (1961) 111 CLR 264. References to age in Commonwealth legislation clearly need to be brought into line with the common understanding that a person attains a particular age on the first moment of the actual anniversary of his or her birth. This is proposed to be brought about by the new section 25E to be inserted by the Bill. It is proposed that this particular provision will apply on and after 1 January 1985. A provision along these lines has already been included in the Superannuation Act 1976.
Alterations in Penalties

I propose the insertion of a new section 45A (1) providing that, where an Act increases a penalty for an offence, the penalty is to apply only to offences committed after the commencement of the provision of the Act increasing the penalty. I also propose a new section 45A (2) providing that, where an Act reduces the penalty, the penalty as reduced extends to offences committed before the commencement of the provision reducing the penalty-but not so as to affect any penalty imposed before that commencement. Both the above provisions are in accordance with the requirements of Article 15 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.
Other Amendments

I have already referred honourable senators to the explanatory memorandum in relation to the other amendments. They are all of a technical nature. The only comment I would make is that they deal with deficiencies that have come to light over the years and are long overdue for attention. The Bill has no financial implications. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Collard) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend the Judiciary Act 1903.
Bill presented by Senator Gareth Evans, and read a first time.
Standing Orders suspended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Judiciary Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1984 serves two purposes. In the first place, it aims to relieve the High Court of Australia of some of its existing workload by removing provisions for appeal as of right to the High Court and by empowering the Court to remit certain matters now within its exclusive jurisdiction to the Federal Court of Australia or to State or Territory courts. Secondly, the Bill provides for the establishment of the Australian Government Solicitor in place of the present office of Crown Solicitor.
Measures to Relieve the Workload of the High Court

The justices of the High Court have expressed concern about the effect of the increasing workload of the High Court on its capacity to function effectively as a final appellate court in Australia and as the interpreter of the Constitution. This Bill deals with two of the matters that have given rise to that concern. One is that, where a case involves subject matter to the value of $20,000 or more, there is a right of appeal from the Full Court of a State Supreme Court or the Federal Court to the High Court, irrespective of the merits or general legal significance of the points in issue. The amount of $20,000 was fixed in 1976 and changing money values have had the result that many more cases fall within the provisions of appeal as of right.

In the second place, there are certain matters within the exclusive jurisdiction of the High Court which may, on occasion, involve a lengthy trial of the issues of fact involved. It is not appropriate that the time of the High Court should be taken up with the trial of issues of fact which could be more conveniently disposed of by another court. The appellate jurisdiction of the High Court derives from section 73 of the Constitution. Section 73 provides for appeals to the High Court from State Supreme Courts, or State courts exercising Federal jurisdiction and Federal Courts. The Parliament may prescribe exceptions to that appellate jurisdiction and regulate its exercise.

I have already indicated that an appeal lies as of right from a State Full Court or from the Full Court of the Federal Court to the High Court where the appeal involves subject matter of the value of $20,000 or more regardless of the merits of the matter. The case involving constitutional issues may also be taken on appeal as of right from a State Full Court to the High Court whether or not the constitutional point is of real substance.

It is generally acknowledged that a financial test is not really an appropriate test for determining whether there should be an appeal as of right. The value of the subject matter of an action is no necessary indication of the intrinsic importance of the action. My officers have had discussions with representatives of the Law Council of Australia on the matter, and I have also discussed the matter with those representatives. They have not been able to suggest a more satisfactory test to isolate those cases in respect of which there might be an appeal as of right to the High Court. Consequently, the Government has agreed to accept the proposition put by the justices of the High Court that all appeals to the High Court from the Federal Court and from State and Territory courts should be by special leave only. I have had some discussions with the Chief Justice on measures which might be taken by the Court itself to meet some of the criticisms which the legal profession has made of the existing procedures for seeking special leave to appeal, and those discussions are continuing. I am hoping that, in particular, arrangements will soon be able to be made for regular sittings of the Court in Sydney and Melbourne to hear applications for special leave.

The present exclusive jurisdiction of the High Court is defined by section 38 of the Judiciary Act. The matter specified in that section covers matters arising directly out of any treaty and suits by the Commonwealth and the States. Except to the extent to which jurisdiction is already conferred on the Federal Court of Australia, the High Court also has exclusive jurisdiction in matters in which a writ of mandamus or prohibition is sought against an officer of the Commonwealth or a Federal Court. The Bill would amend section 44 of the Judiciary Act. This section already provides for the High Court to remit to a Federal Court or to a State or Territory court matters commenced in the High Court in which that other court has concurrent jurisdiction. Clause 5 of the Bill will empower the High Court similarly to remit matters arising directly out of any treaty or suits between the States or suits between the Commonwealth and States. The High Court will be empowered to remit the whole of the matter or it may remit part of the matter as, for example, the hearing of evidence to establish findings of fact. The proceedings in the court to which the matter is remitted will be subject to any directions of the High Court, so that the High Court will retain control over the progress of the matter.
The Australian Government Solicitor

An important function of the Attorney-General's Department is the provision of the services of a solicitor to the Commonwealth, to Ministers, departments and, as required, to Commonwealth instrumentalities and other persons. The Secretary, as permanent head of the Department, is ultimately responsible under the Public Service Act for the proper carrying out of this function, as for all other functions of the Department. However, the greater part of the work of the solicitor for the Commonwealth performed by the Department, particularly the conduct of litigation, is carried out in the States and Territories. The supervision of this work must be done on the spot in each State and Territory. An administrative structure is required to ensure that this work is properly integrated with the other legal work of the Department and that there is effective accountability, both under the Public Service Act and to the courts, of those who perform these solicitor functions.

During 1983 a comprehensive review of the structure and organisation of the Attorney-General's Department was undertaken at my direction. The review had as its objective improving the Department's efficiency, effectiveness and responsiveness to the Government, the Attorney-General and clients. The committee which conducted the review recommended the change in the 'solicitor' functions of the Department embodied in this Bill. Clause 6 of the Bill provides , in place of the personal office of the Crown Solicitor, for the establishment of a statutory corporate entity, to be known as the Australian Government Solicitor. The Australian Government Solicitor will perform the function of solicitor for the Commonwealth, Ministers, Commonwealth authorities and certain other bodies and persons.

The Australian Government Solicitor will be, in effect, the 'firm-name' under which the legal services functions of the Attorney-General's Department which would ordinarily be performed by a solicitor for his client will be carried out. The Australian Government Solicitor will not be a separate authority constituted by a person or body of persons, nor will it have its own staff. The Secretary to the Department and certain legally qualified senior officers of the Department authorised by the Secretary for that purpose will be empowered to act in the name of the Australian Government Solicitor. Thus, the members of the 'firm' will be, in effect, the Secretary and the authorised officers and they will have the ordinary responsibility of a solicitor to the courts in respect of acts done in the name of the Australian Government Solicitor. This will ensure judicial control over those responsible for handling matters before the courts. Officers authorised to act in the name of the Australian Government Solicitor will be responsible for their actions in the conduct of their activities to the Secretary to the Department, and through the Secretary, to the Attorney-General. In addition, the authorised officers will be subject to the direction of the Secretary and, where so directed, the responsibility to the courts for acts performed in accordance with those directions will rest with the Secretary.

The Australian Government Solicitor will be empowered to act on behalf of those entities, persons and bodies on behalf of which the Crown Solicitor is presently empowered to act by virtue of section 55E of the Judiciary Act. For the purposes of acting as solicitor for these persons and entities the Australian Government Solicitor is entitled under the Bill to the same rights and privileges of a solicitor in each of the States and Territories. These entitlements which are the same as those currently bestowed on the office of Crown Solicitor will enable the Australian Government Solicitor to carry out the function of solicitor in the various States and Territories. In addition, for the purposes of acting in the name of the Australian Government Solicitor, the Secretary or an authorised person will be entitled to do all things necessary and convenient to carry out the function and will be entitled to all the rights and privileges of a solicitor in each State or Territory whether or not he is entitled to practise as a solicitor in any State or Territory. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Collard) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: FEDERAL COURT OF AUSTRALIA AMENDMENT BILL 1984

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend the Federal Court of Australia Act 1976.
Bill presented by Senator Gareth Evans, and read a first time.
Standing Orders suspended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill complements the changes proposed in the Judiciary Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1984 which removes existing provisions for appeals as of right to the High Court from State Supreme Courts. The effect is to remove the right of appeal from the Full Court of the Federal Court to the High Court where the appeal involves subject matter of the value of $20,000 or more. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Collard) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I make this statement on behalf of Senator Ryan. This is the eleventh annual report of the Education Research and Development Committee. It is unique because it is the last report on the activities of the Education Research and Development Committee. Some members may need to be reminded that the Education Research and Development Committee was abolished in June 1981 on the recommendations of the Review of Commonwealth Functions, better known as the razor gang. Established in 1970, the ERDC played a vital role in educational research until its recent demise. It is generally acknowledged in the wider education community that the ERDC was active and imaginative in the pursuit of its goals.

SPEECH.PARA: This Report demonstrates that the razor gang and indeed the previous Government had little understanding of the organisation and process of education when it suggested that ERDC was concerned with research on matters which were the responsibility of the States. I would challenge, for instance, that Dr Warren Lett's Survey and Report on the Needs and Priorities for Research on Arts Education in Australia-page 34-the report by Connell, Ashenden, Kessler and Dowsett, entitled 'making the Difference-Schools, Families and Social Division'- page 13-and Professor Colin Power's paper 'Factors Influencing Retentivity within High School'-page 40-are concerned with matters that are the sole responsibility of the States.

My colleague, the Hon. Senator Barry Jones-Senator! We have promoted Mr Jones- in his Science and Technology Statement for 1982-83 highlighted the dismal state of affairs for educational research in Australia. His report to Parliament clearly showed that between 1980-81 and 1982-83 total Commonwealth expenditure on research and development overall increased by 32 per cent whereas research and development expenditure on education declined by 25 per cent.

This Government came into office with the clear announcement that education reform was central to its general program. Within this context we did not envisage that educational research was an optional extra which can be turned off to save a few pennies. Educational research is essential in order to improve the general quality of Australian education, and to provide strategies and policies to deal with current and future problems.

This Government has made a commitment in the Prices and Incomes Statement of Accord that it sees as a matter of priority 'raising Australia's educational research effort' from the depths where the previous Government has placed it, and we are looking at ways in which the Government can most effectively revive this important area of education.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

I will speak briefly because of the pressures on our program today. I hope that a member of another place takes appropriate umbrage at having been described in this statement as a member of this chamber, although we of course think it is a promotion for him.

TALK.START.PARA: —He might get ambitions.

—He might get ambitions, as others seem to have done in the past. Acknowledging that the person referred to is probably Barry Jones, the Minister for Science and Technology, this statement, which has been countersigned at the bottom 'approved' with initials which look as though they are probably the initials of the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs ( Senator Ryan), clearly has not involved close reading or any kind of proof reading. The point I make about this statement is that it completely misses the opportunities and responsibilities of the present Government. It is all very well to criticise a decision by a previous Government with which it does not agree, but it was within the capacity of the present Government, in the year in which it has held office, to have provided the money and to have taken the administrative decisions to restore the Education Research and Development Committee. It is quite apparent that this statement is hypocritical, because it is quite apparent that this Government, now having held office for a year, has brought down a Budget and educational guidelines, and has done nothing to restore the ERDC to existence and has done nothing to cut short the process by which the ERDC was winding up its activities as set out in the statement.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government had an opportunity to redress the situation which it claims to deplore so much. It will not wash in the Senate to say what a terrible thing it is, having wound down the ERDC. That may be a very defensible statement. Senator Macklin has made that point on many occasions. But I put to all honourable senators that if it was a bad thing and if the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs wants to say so, she must explain to the educational establishment and to those who care about the ERDC why she and her Government have not taken the opportunity, during their first year of office, to set right a situation which they find to be so deplorable.

Unless and until the Government is willing to restore the ERDC, it has no legitimacy in coming here and saying what a terrible thing it was to abolish it. It may well have been an error on the part of the previous Government, but it was a matter on which it was proper and open to the present Government, if it cared, to have reversed the decision and to have corrected it. It has not done so. It has not matched this rhetoric with any kind of action. When that is realised by education research workers, this Government will have to answer for its failure to act. The fact that it has offered us these words this morning will in no way mollify people who wanted something more than these words from the Government for which they voted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The last report of the Education Research and Development Committee is in many ways a report which brings to mind, certainly in its appendices, the type of activities in which the Committee has been engaged over the years since its foundation. From the beginning of the report one gets some idea of what the report is talking about when it refers to the fact that we are withdrawing financial support for the research grant program, the cessation of the research training fellowship program and the dissemination program.

SPEECH.PARA: The statement of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) on behalf of the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan), refers to something about which the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones) has often talked-the funding for research in Australia, research not only in education but in every area. We know that private industry, for example, in Australia has been remiss by comparison with private industry in other countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development in that a very small percentage of the budgets of the larger companies goes towards providing adequate funds for research. As a country, we have tended to live on the research done in other areas. In education this has proved a dismal failure, and there are very good reasons for that. By and large each country has developed, historically and socially, an education system suited to itself, and much of the research which is done in other countries on education matters is not easily transferred, and certainly not easily applied, in countries which have different educational institutions and different social structures.

I remind the Senate of some of the research programs which were undertaken by funding of this Committee. From those, one can see fairly clearly that we are not talking about something which the previous Government said was a matter for State governments. I think it is useful to indicate the programs of national importance that the Committee was attempting to fund. One such program dealt with cognitive abilities of moderately and severely mentally retarded individuals. That program, as one sees when one reads an abstract of the work that was done, which is well known in the education community, was not bounded by lines on the map. It concerned a group of people within the Australian community who had similar problems. It is not bounded by the different types of educational programs that the States mount. It is a national issue and ought to be addressed at the national level.

A piece of research which was undertaken in my own State into the effects of class size on pupils was of world class. Attempts have been made for 20 to 25 years to establish the relationships between class size and educational outcomes . This piece of work was one of the two-the other was undertaken in the United States of America-pathfinders in this area conclusively to come up with what is necessary for the types of things which every teacher knows but which have never up to this stage been able to be linked in any effective way. Another such program was for the teaching of basic reading skills and a mastery of learning procedures. Another dealt with language and numeracy demands on work for school leavers. If that is not a national issue, I do not know what is. Other programs dealt with semantics for early deaf communication, reading disabilities, the education of severely and profoundly hearing impaired children, young hyperactive children, specific learning disorders in migrant children, transition from school to work and nutrition and physical education. So the list goes on. They are very important matters that need funds over and above those which are available at the State level. The previous Government made a decision which had no educational backing whatsoever, a decision which has been defended in this place by Senator Peter Baume, the previous Minister for Education, and which effectively pulled the guts out of the educational research in our universities and colleges of advanced education. Eventually that has been turned round to the type of statement put down by Senator Ryan today.

I agree with the sentiments expressed by Senator Baume, although I find it very difficult to understand why he is expressing them now. I would have much preferred him to express them on the many occasions when I asked questions about this issue when he was Minister for Education. The last two paragraphs of Senator Ryan's statement leave one in wonderment. The criticisms of the razor gang's decision in the first paragraphs are good ones, but one has to ask: What is the follow-up from this Government? I condemned the previous Government's action, which action was supported in this place by such people as Senator Baume and Senator Teague, but we now find that Senator Ryan is not willing to undertake the necessary restoration in that area or to indicate from which alternative institutions those funds will be available.

It is not necessary to re-establish that Committee to be able to provide those funds. However, I believe that on any objective and dispassionate reading of this report, particularly of the appendices, one would be hard pressed to think of a better way of dispersing scarce funds for maximum returns. It is not just a matter of someone coming up with an idea, applying to this Committee and having the idea accepted because some money happens to be around. The Committee, over the years it worked, came up with some very rigid and very useful guidelines for education funding. The Committee was the only body which was able to oversee the direction of research in this area in Australia. Indeed, it had many cases before it of admirable research programs that it refused to fund. The reason it refused to fund them is, precisely, that they were being conducted elsewhere or it did not seem to the Committee that the argument put had sufficient contact with ongoing research or the ability to effect practice.

All those types of things that people outside the research area feel fairly strongly about were taken into consideration by this Committee. If one were to speak to anyone in the education community one would find that the Committee was held in the highest regard. Yet in a report that had no educational backing, a report that went from a group of people whom I believe had no understanding as to what they were doing, the previous Government cut the ground from under a very admirable way of organising scarce resources to maximum effect. I must admit I am at a loss to think of a better way of doing this. Yet the current Government has not indicated in this statement how it intends to follow through those things that it was criticising and still is criticising in the first two paragraphs of this statement. For that reason this is an extraordinary statement . Why bother bringing it in, why bother putting these types of propositions, unless we know where we are going now? We have a new government, a government that has made claims to the electorate. Yet in this report we find absolutely nothing of what this Government intends to do. Surely any government, in tabling a statement on a report, should be prepared not only to criticise actions of previous governments but also to put down the positive programs that it intends to implement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: -I support the views that have been expressed by Senator Peter Baume and Senator Macklin. It seems extraordinary that we should have such a statement approved by the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) and brought into this Senate, yet the Minister is not present to answer the questions that have been validly raised by both Senator Baume and Senator Macklin today. In what direction is the funding to go in order to adopt some of the very important educational research activities that were undertaken under the auspices of the Education Research and Development Committee? That is the question that should have been addressed in this tabling statement. It is not addressed in this tabling statement. There will not be a response from the Minister because she is not in the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: Admittedly, Ministers and members of parliament have legitimate activities associated with their ministerial or parliamentary responsibilities, or their responsibilities to their constituents which take them out of the chamber from time to time, but why bring in this statement at this time? Why bring it in today when the Minister is not in the chamber to answer the very valid questions that have been raised? I contrast Senator Ryan's absence on this occasion with her statement on 19 December last year. Honourable senators will recall that 16 December was the last sitting day of this parliament last year. There was a good deal of debate then on the Sex Discrimination Bill. I did not have any breakfast or dinner on that day because I was in the chamber for the whole of the day until about 4.45 p.m. when the last vote was taken.

On that day the Minister issued a Press statement to the effect that I did not even come into the chamber for the vote on the Bill. That was taken up by the Press-for example, by Australian. The Press reporters were all at a booze up given by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), so they were not present in the Press Gallery. They took the Press statement issued by Senator Ryan. I moved 21 amendments on that particular day, as everybody will recall. Of course, the newspaper simply took Senator Ryan's less than honest statement that my contribution to the debate was that I did not come into the chamber for the vote on the Bill. In fact, I participated in 38 of the 39 votes on that particular Bill and did not participate on the last vote for a very good reason which was clearly stated at the time.

We do not have any statement now as to why Senator Ryan is not here to defend this statement, why she is not here to answer the very important questions that arise out of this statement. I therefore seek leave to continue my remarks later because I hope that at a particular stage that would enable this matter to go back on to the Notice Paper to enable the Minister, when she is available, to respond to the matters that have been raised in this debate.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I apologise to Senator Harradine for the absence of the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) who is obviously not here for a good reason because of ministerial duties. Senator Harradine has done what is done with all these statements-he has sought leave to continue his remarks later and, therefore, adjourned the motion that the Senate take note of the paper. The matter will go on to the Notice Paper and will be answered. I do not accept that the criticism of Senator Ryan is fair. Senator Ryan is assiduous in her attendance in this chamber. She is back here now and I am glad she is. I merely point out that Senator Harradine chose not to come here at all on Monday because there was a holiday down in Tasmania. He was down there having a good time. I think Senator Ryan's reasons for being absent are pretty good.
—Labor had a holiday.
—Yes, Senator Harradine was having a holiday. We were all here working and he took a holiday.

SPEECH.PARA: Debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-On the front page of the Canberra Times today an article by Paul Malone, the political correspondent of that newspaper, under the heading: 'Opposition senators abstain on tapes', very much misrepresents my position in connection with the production to the Parliament of the so-called Age tapes which relate to corruption in New South Wales and to the difficulties or problems raised in connection with a certain judge. I will quote the first paragraph which, as I say, totally misrepresents my position under that headline . It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Cracks have appeared in the Opposition's strategy on the Age tapes with the revelation that two government senators--
I am sure he means two Opposition senators-
failed to vote with their colleagues on the motion to table the tapes.

That implies that in some way or other I was not supportive of my Opposition colleagues in the motion which we put before the Senate. I am sure the Senate will know that I totally supported that motion, spoke in favour of it and voted in favour of it. To suggest that I was not supportive of the Opposition's strategy in regard to the Age tapes totally misrepresents my position and I think, frankly, is libellous. Actually, if one reads further on in the article one will see that Mr Malone does tend to put my position by saying that I said that the Australian Democrats had combined with the Government to amend the Opposition's motion and to 'gut it'. I said that I was not prepared to vote with Labor and therefore had walked out. That again misrepresents my position slightly. It is not that I am not prepared to vote with Labor on any matter- which the article implies-but that I was not prepared to vote with Labor on this particular matter which had then become a charade. In my view, the Liberal- National Party Opposition should have walked out of this chamber on that occasion and observed the Australian Labor Party voting against the Democrats. In my view, that should have been our proper position. We did not have an opportunity to discuss that matter, so I took that course myself. Clearly, I have been misrepresented in this article by the suggestion in the headline and the first paragraph that I was not supportive of my colleagues in this matter. It also misrepresents me in the suggestion that I will never vote with the Labor Party in any matter in this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also claim to have been misrepresented and seek leave to make a personal explanation.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I, too, object to the leading paragraph of the article in the Canberra Times to which Senator Lewis referred. I assure the Senate that, like Senator Lewis, I do not want to appear to be causing a split, or any other inference that one would like to make, with regard to Opposition strategy.
—What about the photograph?

—I was not responsible for the photograph. I thought it was a good photograph, actually. The attitude I took was exactly the same as that taken by Senator Lewis. I did not want to vote with the Australian Labor Party on the matter. I believe that the Australian Democrats' amendment would have advanced the cause somewhat, and I did not wish to vote with the Labor Party on that matter. On a radio program last night I made it quite clear that if the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) claims that the judge in question did not do anything illegal, the Attorney-General and the Government have a responsibility to come clean and present the Senate with the evidence. As far as I am concerned, I believe that the Opposition is behaving quite responsibly in trying to get the facts placed before the Senate. Perhaps the best way to do that would be to establish a select committee so that these things can be elucidated.

—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I certainly understand Senator Jessop speaking on this matter, but I think he is now starting to stray into more general issues. He is saying that he was misrepresented by the newspaper-I think everyone accepts that-and he is now pointing out the defects in Liberal Party strategy.
—The Senate granted Senator Jessop leave to make a personal explanation. He can make that statement in the way he wishes.

—Mr Deputy President, I rise on the point of order. I think it may be true that Senator Jessop has now started to debate the precise strategy we will advance this afternoon, and I welcome his support for it. I suggest that he is within bounds in trying to make clear his own position, when it has been put in a very prominent way by a newspaper. I think he ought to be permitted to complete his personal explanation.
—I have ruled that Senator Jessop is entitled to make his statement in the way he wishes.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. My main concern in this whole exercise-this is why I made the statement, quite truthfully, that I did not think there was any harm in the Democrats' motion-is the question of privilege. The best way to deal with the question of protecting people who may be named in some way or other in unauthenticated tapes would be to establish a select committee, where adequate protection could be afforded them.

Sex Discrimination Bill 1983.

Debate resumed from 7 March, on motion by Senator Chaney:

That the Senate censures the Attorney-General for his handling of the Age tapes , and in particular his persistent refusal to provide information to the Parliament in order that it might properly perform its role in matters relating to the Judiciary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We were debating yesterday afternoon for almost four hours a censure motion moved by the Opposition on the Attorney-General. I note that eight more senators wish to speak on this matter. If that situation remains, it is quite clear that we will continue debate today. Because we cannot leave a censure motion hanging over a government or a Minister in this way, we may well have to continue the debate in the time set aside for General Business. The motion was moved without enthusiasm and it received very little enthusiastic support on the other side of this chamber until, of course, the entry of Senator Sir John Carrick into the debate. I said a few words about that last night. During the speech of Senator Sir John Carrick in particular, and to a lesser extent the speech of Senator Peter Baume, we were treated to a display of personal abuse of the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans), of innuendo, vituperation, and almost every other tactic that could be used in these procedures. Senator Sir John Carrick was ably assisted along the way by various interjections from Senator Archer, some of which I am glad will appear in Hansard to demonstrate the standards we have had.

SPEECH.PARA: We are dealing with a motion of censure against the Attorney-General which came about because of the existence of some tapes and some alleged transcripts of tapes which no one questions were illegally obtained; which no one questions involved a gross invasion of privacy; which are of uncertain authenticity; which have been examined not only by members of the Government but also by members of the Opposition, practically every newspaper in this country, numerous members of the general public, and heaven knows who else. The tapes and transcripts have been examined, particularly as they pertain to the judge in the case, by Mr Temby, a prominent legal practitioner and recognised as such by the whole of the legal profession in Australia, though not recognised as such of course by Senator Sir John Carrick. However, that does not cut much ice with us. The circumstances also have been looked at by the Solicitor-General.

Now, after seven days of almost continuous debate in this place and question times during which questions were repeatedly asked of the Attorney-General, with the Opposition indulging in a fishing expedition employing all sorts of innuendo , a Minister in the Queensland Government and a backbencher in that Government, in a deplorable incident the other night, have exposed the names of the people on the tapes. As justification of this we have the Opposition demanding that the Attorney-General produce all this unauthenticated, dubious and doubtful material so that we as a Senate can all sit around, look at it and come to some collective decision. Apparently the Attorney-General is condemned for not supplying this information. The best justification I heard yesterday for the production of the information was that given by Senator Chaney who said that we had to supply it now because these charming characters in the Queensland Government had named names.

We believe that this censure motion is a nonsense motion. We believe the tactics of some members of the Opposition in debating this motion were deplorable. The behaviour of Senator Sir John Carrick, knight of the realm, ex- secretary of the Liberal Party of New South Wales, was deplorable. We believe that the behaviour of Mr Jennings and Mr Lane, Mr Hodgman last night in the other place, and Senator Sir John Carrick and Senator Archer, for good measure, yesterday afternoon has been squalid.

This question has to be asked: Where are we going in this country? Where are we going when this chamber can spend so much time debating tapes which quite clearly, if they are authentic, were obtained illegally, were distributed widely throughout this country illegally, and were the subject of innuendo and scurrilous articles in some parts of the Press? They were not even re-produced accurately in the Age. Are we going to spend hours in this place, week after week, every time someone produces tapes of telephone conversations? What will it be next? Will we have tapes of bar room conversations, tapes of conversations illegally obtained in all sorts of circumstances and then selectively produced to condemn any individual, not only in the High Court but any individual in this chamber or the other place? Are we going to allow debate of the type that occurred here yesterday when Senator Sir John Carrick stood up and indirectly smeared Mr Temby, directly smeared the judge and very directly smeared the Attorney-General? He then sat with a pained expression on his face when he got a bit of his own back. He will get a bit of his own back if he keeps up that sort of behaviour in this place. This chamber will become a farce. This Parliament will become a farce. The rights of privacy and the rights of natural justice in this country will not be protected if we behave in this way.

The Attorney-General has had a difficult job balancing his responsibility for the administration of justice-balancing his responsibility to see that justice is done collectively against his responsibility to see that justice is done to individuals. He has had a difficult job to do but he has done it well and honourably. At all times he has tried to retain a sense of decency in this place , which other honourable senators have not necessarily done.

TALK.START.PARA: —It depends on your standards.

—If my standards were as low as Senator Walters's I would be down in the gutter with her. That is all I have to say. The Attorney-General deserves praise, not censure. It is about time we stopped this debate. If we are going to debate this matter for another four hours we will have wasted another day in this place when there are far more important things to do. The motion deserves to be defeated and I am pleased to say that it will be defeated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Senate that we are debating this motion moved by Senator Chaney:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate censures the Attorney-General for his handling of the Age tapes , and in particular his persistent refusal to provide information to the Parliament in order that it might properly perform its role in matters relating to the Judiciary.

This is a serious motion, as the Government has acknowledged, and it calls for further dispassionate debate. We are not on air today and I do not expect my speech to have any influence on the New South Wales election or any other election but I hope it will have some influence here. I believe that there are matters that need reiteration.

I believe that the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) deserves censure for the way in which he has handled this matter generally. I think the Attorney- General has taken a very arrogant attitude towards the development of the argument about the tapes. I think it was last Wednesday week that I read into the record some statements on the duty of the Attorney-General. It is not his duty to be a partisan in debate. The Attorney-General has a role which is very separate from that of other Ministers. I regret that this Attorney-General has shown himself to be extremely partisan, to be extremely concerned for his own situation and ready to abuse other members of Parliament rather than to take a reasonable attitude and to answer questions.

I will briefly state what I think are the major criticisms of the Attorney- General made in this debate and others which justify the motion of censure. Even though the motion may not be carried because the Australian Democrats have indicated they will not vote for it, nonetheless I think it is necessary that we should place these things on record. Since the Age exercised what it believed was its public duty-I believe it was its duty-disclosed the tapes and these serious allegations and called for Parliament and other bodies to investigate, the Attorney-General has acted in a considerable hurry. He tried to pre-empt the Parliament by getting opinions and advice and suggesting a limitation upon the Parliament's power. It is very significant that in the statement which he made last Tuesday week he said:

One might hope that that is where the matter will be allowed to rest-in the interests not only of the judge concerned, who has already had to endure a disgraceful campaign of gossip and innuendo, but also of the whole institution of the judiciary.

I think the Attorney-General hoped and had expectations that by obtaining opinions from the Solicitor-General and Mr Temby and putting his own view we would agree that no further investigation should be made, particularly in the area which is the concern of this Parliament-that is serious allegations against a member of the judiciary. I think the Attorney-General hurried to obtain that advice in order to by-pass this Parliament and to stop it from proceeding to consider the matter. The matter has not been allowed to rest and the Attorney- General must be very aware of that now.

The Attorney-General accepted the advice as to what 'proved misbehaviour' was which came hurriedly from Mr Temby-advice of a very limited nature. He accepted also the unfortunate advice that he should see the judge in question and ask him certain questions about the matter. As we know, he has reported selectively back to Parliament in regard to those matters. As I have said before and I do not propose to go into the argument, it was a grave mistake for the Attorney-General to do that himself rather than get it done by someone of eminent status outside the political area. As I said, it is unfortunate that he got Mr Temby to investigate and give his opinion in the first place. I believe Mr Temby is a man of considerable ability and one would hope that he will make a very good director-general of prosecutions--

TALK.START.PARA: —However.

—I do not say 'however'; I say the Attorney-General has done Mr Temby an injustice by setting him-a man who has got, reasonably enough, a political background within the Labor Party-this job. It should have been done by someone of no political background.
—But you appointed Costigan to the painters and dockers.

—We appointed Mr Costigan to do a job and he has done it in a very fine way. I am saying that in a matter which is so highly political-and obvious so-it would have been wise for the Attorney-General to have appointed someone outside the political area to advise him. I think he did an injustice to Mr Temby in doing that. The Attorney-General also got the advice of the Solicitor-General, and I will have more to say about that in a moment. I attacked that advice at length in the Senate last Monday. I think the Attorney- General has been unwise to accept the definitions of misbehaviour and the other advice in that opinion. I also believe that since that time the Attorney-General has shown in this Parliament a lack of initiative, an inability to try to advance the resolution of these matters in a way in which Parliament could ably handle them. He has answered questions at various stages. This week we had Senator Durack and other members of the Opposition attempting to have the tabling of a sanitised version-without names-of the material.
—So it becomes a public document.

—No, not so that there would be names and descriptions of people but so that members of this Parliament could see what was raised in those tapes and statements. I have not heard any tapes or seen any transcripts. I have read what has been put in the newspapers. I think it is important for us to consider these matters in due course. Of course, the Government then performed a very clever sleight of hand. The Democrats had moved an amendment about which they were misled and which would have guaranteed that the documents to be tabled had been accepted as authenticated and were genuine. We may never have seen any documents tabled by the Government and this would have considerably delayed the settlement and finalisation of this whole matter.
—You much prefer phoney ones; they are easier to work with, aren't they?
—No.
—It suits your style of operation on that side.

—It does not suit my style of operation. What the Government did was a trick. By supporting the Democrats' amendment the Government turned the Opposition's amendment into a nonsense. The Government then crossed the floor, cleverly, to vote against the amendment when it had become ineffective. I will give the Government a B grade pass for clever tactics but that does not help this Parliament in the resolution of this matter. It is important to decide today the question of whether a committee should be appointed. That is a question which we sorely need to deal with here so that the other matter is dealt with outside the range of public debate. A committee of the Parliament could consider these matters and hear from those persons who may be involved in the tapes.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to what I think are four propositions that have arisen in this debate so far as the rights and duties of the Parliament are concerned. I do not intend to repeat the arguments which I raised in detail in my speech in this Parliament on Monday and which I stand by. Several of the arguments, which the Opposition has raised, have been conceded by the Attorney-General. He endeavours to say that he has not changed his ground but, of course, he has. The first is the proposition that these matters, arising under section 72 of the Constitution, are not justiciable, that they would not be dealt with by a court, in particular the High Court of Australia. There is an exception, which both the Attorney- General and I maintain, that is, that if the Parliament proceeded where there was no semblance of misbehaviour but where there was merely a political exercise or prejudice and there was no evidence of misbehaviour, the Court may well intervene. However, it is clear-the Attorney-General now accepts the proposition -that otherwise the Court will not intervene. The interesting point is that, in the statement which the Attorney-General made on Tuesday week to this Parliament and, in particular, in the detailed opinion which the Solicitor-General gave him and which accompanied it, there is no reference to the question of justiciability. There is no argument whatsoever about it and no acceptance there of the proposition that this is a matter for the Parliament, not one for the courts to intervene. However, it has now been accepted and we must be thankful for that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Without a charge?
—Without a charge, of course. Parliament is not a court. Parliament does not deal with these as if it were a criminal trial.
—You want it to be, though, don't you? You want to play lawyers in this situation.
—No, I do not want to play lawyers. I retired from that after 25 years.
—Where is the misbehaviour?
—Order!
—I am not going to bother to deal with such childish interjections; I will proceed with my argument.

—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. There has been a continuous stream of interjections, including from the front bench. There have been requests by the Chair during this debate that honourable senators be heard in reasonable silence. I ask you to request that Senator Missen be given an opportunity to make his speech in silence.
—Order! There is no point of order. All interjections are unparliamentary. Senator Missen, I suggest you address your remarks through the Chair.

—I will certainly do that, Mr Acting Deputy President. I was saying that, so far as justiciability is concerned, one need only read the Convention debates-both Senator Durack and I put them into the record on Monday- to see that when section 72 of the Constitution was formed these matters were very much in the minds of the founding fathers who created the Constitution. They made it very clear that they expected Parliament to be the premier body to determine these matters. They regarded as ludicrous the idea that courts-for example, the High Court-might be forced to sit in judgment in appeal on something affecting perhaps a member of its own Bench. Obviously this was not the intention when the Constitution was drawn up. That is accepted now. It is not a judicial procedure by Parliament; it is a matter about which Parliament certainly must be fair and ought to exercise all the elements of natural justice , allowing people to be heard and represented. It is not a matter in which the courts are intervening, nor is it a matter about which evidence which may be necessary to prove a charge or conviction in a court is all that can be considered.

SPEECH.PARA: The Parliament can consider what it believes is reliable information in determining this matter. That is the first proposition where, now that the Attorney-General has retreated, it has been accepted as being one of Parliament' s objectives. It is solely Parliament's duty to consider these complaints. I think this point has now been conceded. It must be proved to the satisfaction of Parliament. The word 'proved' is in the Constitution because the founding fathers wanted to make very clear that Parliament had the sole right to do that. That point has now been acceded to by the Attorney-General.

Honourable senators should remember that when he put down the opinion by Dr Gavan Griffith on Tuesday week there was a very different situation as to whether Parliament should make up its own mind, create its own procedures and decide whether, in its view, there was some proved misbehaviour. Paragraph 21 of Dr Gavan Griffith's opinion states:
It follows that the terms of section 72 dictate meaning for ''proved misbehaviour''.
Dictate to whom?

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is the misbehaviour?
—I will come to that. Dr Gavan Griffith goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Inasmuch as Parliament considers the matter, the question is whether there is proved offence against the general law ''of such a nature as to warrant the conclusion that the incumbent is unfit to exercise the office''.

That is taken from an opinion of Mr Garfield Barwick, as he then was, long before he was a member of this Parliament or even a judge. It is one which I believe is not backed up by any other evidence. Dr Griffith goes on to say:

Parliament is not at large to define proved misbehaviour by reference to its own standards or views of suitability for office or moral or social character or conduct. The Parliamentary enquiry is whether commission of an offence of the requisite quality and seriousness is proved. Parliament would act beyond power if it sought to apply wider definition or criteria for misbehaviour than the recognized meaning of misbehaviour not pertaining to office.

That is his interpretation of 'misbehaviour'. That is what he regarded as having to be proved. He also referred to the Parliament acting beyond its power. I presume he means some court would intervene. When the Attorney-General relied upon that opinion he was relying upon one that told Parliament what it could not do. That is advice which the Attorney-General has now abandoned.

I turn to the third proposition in this matter, that is, the two grounds of ' proved misbehaviour' which the Attorney-General tells us are the only grounds the Parliament can look at. One pertains to some action by a judge in his judicial office which is so offensive that he ought to be removed. The second is what has been said by Dr Gavan Griffith and repeated and accepted by the Attorney-General. I note that it was accepted yesterday by the Prime Minister ( Mr Hawke), despite the fact that I think we have refuted it already in this Parliament. It is 'the commission of an offence against the general law of such a quality as to indicate that the incumbent is unfit to exercise his office'. I am not at all sure what is meant by 'an offence against the general law'. I know the common law and I know the statute law, but 'the general law' is such a vague idea. Presumably it does not include taxation law, for example. If a judge were seen to be acting in a very fraudulent way in regard to the taxation law, setting a standard which made other citizens despise him, I think that would be a matter which ought to be considered. So even if one were to take the two criteria of Mr Temby and Dr Griffith, the second proposition is too vague. I do not know what it means. Of course, the answer is that no such definition is exclusive. We showed this the other day. The words used by the authorities relied on by the Attorney-General and the Solicitor-General talk about the definition of misbehaviour being inclusive of these things. By a slide and by a very poor argument they have then assumed its exclusiveness, that is, that there are no other grounds for proven misbehaviour.

Of course, we know that many things which could be done by a judge would not break the general law, yet may be far worse in terms of behaviour than a criminal breach. For example, a judge could be found guilty of drunk driving or some offence of that sort. That is a criminal offence. Yet it would be much worse if, in fact, a judge were found to be conniving with corrupt elements in our community, or if he were found, for example, to be engaging in politics to the denigration of other people's characters. People who expected from him much higher standards-and I notice that it is accepted generally that a judge's standards should be higher than average-would find that to be a worse offence, although it is not a criminal offence. That is the problem, of course, for the Attorney-General. He has got Mr Temby and the Solicitor-General to say that the behaviour must be criminal behaviour. Yet the behaviour of a judge may be much worse than that where a crime is committed. The definition which Parliament has of misbehaviour must be wide enough to cover all those incidents.

However, in the opinion before us here, Mr Temby talks not about just the general law. His view is that the offence must be an 'infamous offence'. He resurrects the very old view of what are called 'infamous offences', which include treason and, I think, misprision and all kinds of offences, some of which are no longer relevant. So there is an alternative. Even according to the Attorney-General's advice, the offence can be an infamous offence or an offence against the general law. Senator Durack, I and others have maintained that the definition of misbehaviour cannot be defined and that Parliament is the body to determine it in particular circumstances. The important thing is that once one concedes, as does the Attorney-General, that Parliament must make these decisions and that this matter should not be dealt with by courts, what is the value of the Government trying to put Parliament in a straightjacket? It acknowledges that Parliament should not be overriden but it suggests that, in effect, this is what Parliament ought to do.

The last of the four propositions is that Parliament should not insist on the documents being produced, should not insist on taking this matter further and should not insist on asking the Attorney-General more questions. That is a matter about which the Attorney-General and his adviser can advise the Parliament and make suggestions, but it cannot demand.

Parliament, of course, must go ahead to deal with this matter through a committee inquiry quietly examining the allegations which were seriously made and questions such as the reliability of the record, whether the tapes have been tampered with and whether they are illegally obtained. The latter seems to be generally accepted--

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you an expert on that, that you can make a decision?

—No. Senator Gietzelt does not understand. It is so long since he has been active on Senate committees that he apparently does not realise that committees of the Parliament can and must call in experts. They must listen to the material which the joint investigating bodies-the police and others-have found regarding the allegations. I trust they would have to bring in the judge if necessary and question him as to the conversations--
—Would you like every one of your conversations taped?

—I have a very strong opinion against the taping of conversations and so forth. But I am not as concerned with what people say during their conversations as with what they do. I do not presume anything, either in regard to this judge or in regard to other people on the tapes. One has to be satisfied in regard to what they do, that is, whether they are directing or requesting people to do things which are abominable and vicious. One has to be satisfied as to their actions and not just as to their conversations.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not disagree with the Attorney-General, with Senator Chipp and others who have pointed out the dangers inherent in the taping of these conversations and the necessity for us to be satisfied that they took place and that they are really more than just windy conversation or even lies or puffery on a conversational level. They have to be shown to be more than that. That has not been shown. I have not formed any fixed judgment whatsoever in regard to these parties.

There are two or three other matters. We have heard extraordinary speeches by Senator Button and Senator Grimes. It is quite evident that neither really defends the Attorney-General or his actions. The honourable senators went on to the attack about other people and the misuse of tapes--

TALK.START.PARA: —Misuse of parliamentary privilege, too.

—And misuse of parliamentary privilege. I am very concerned about the misuse of parliamentary privilege. I say quite definitely that I do not take much notice of anything that is said by that couple of renegade Liberals in Queensland. I am pleased to say that I voted for the expulsion of one of them from the Liberal Party in Victoria, after he had denigrated his parliamentary leader over a long period. I am proud of the fact that I voted for his expulsion . He moved elsewhere. I do not take notice of what happens in other parliaments on this subject or think that it is something that this Parliament should take much notice of. This Parliament has the responsibility to deal with the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Button's speech yesterday was extraordinary. I think we could call it a Rip Van Winkle speech. Obviously, he has been asleep for the whole of the last fortnight. He said that nobody in Opposition had challenged the opinions in question during the debate.

Incredibly, Senator Button was not with us last Monday-although I thought he was-if he does not know that these opinions were challenged. Unfortunately, we have a fairly servile media in this country which is interested in what the Attorney-General says but is not interested in reading what we have said. Now that the copies of Hansard are here, the media representatives can read what we said regarding the unsoundness of the opinions on which the Attorney has based his views. To say, as Senator Button said, that these opinions have not been challenged is, of course, incredible. It reminds me of a meeting in 1975 of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs which was having a tremendous argument over the matter of national compensation. A row was going on in the Committee meeting between the Chairman, former Senator Everett and former Liberal Senator Reggie Wright, who were not exactly bosom pals. Senator Chaney will no doubt remember this incident. After we had tried to settle something finally the Chairman said: 'We could solve this thing if only Senator Button were here'. Pointing across the room, I said: 'He is here. There he is in the ringed-back chair. He has fallen asleep and missed the whole of this row.' He was there. Obviously he has been sleeping through the whole of this debate in this chamber over the last fortnight.

Senator Button said that the Opposition has made nothing of the inconsistency in its questioning. I beg to differ entirely with that. He said that the Senate must be judicial in what it does. I have refuted that. It is not so. He finished up by asking: 'Where is this Parliament going?'. That is a good question, because I think we have to determine in a practical sense where it is going. We have to determine whether this series of allegations, which may or may not be faulty and which may or may not be reliable--

TALK.START.PARA: —But don't you agree, Senator, that the Justice's reputation has been torn to shreds as a result of this?

—I agree that a justice's reputation has been gravely damaged. I think that it is the duty of this Parliament to investigate this matter now in a dispassionate way, preferably by a committee where the same flourishes and the same desire to impress the public outside does not exist. It is important, and not only in the interests of that judge's reputation, that this matter be carefully examined. It has to be done. We cannot leave the matter where it stands now. It is not good enough for Senator Evans to say: 'I want to let it rest'. The matter cannot rest. In fact, it is our duty under the Constitution to investigate these matters. We must do so. I hope that Senator Durack's initiative, which requires some change in the wording--
—About censuring the Attorney-General?
—I do not expect that to be carried.
—But that is the motion you are speaking to.

—I know that I am speaking to that motion, but I am being realistic about it. I am saying that I hope the subsequent proposal will be adopted. If it is, we can get this criticism of judicial behaviour into a framework and a forum where these Houses of Parliament can be advised by a committee after careful investigation of the matter. We have to do that now because the situation has been reached where not only is the judge's reputation being damaged but also the reputation of the judiciary throughout Australia is being somewhat affected. There are articles in the newspapers which recognise the concern. We must recognise the facts. We must recognise the great dangers in the invasions of privacy that occurred in the taping.
—You used to be a champion against bringing material forward that could damage people's privacy.
—I continue to be so. I have not changed my views in any respect.
—Would you wait for the material to be authenticated?

—No, because the damage is done long before that time. It is not good enough for us to wait. We must have, as quickly as possible, what evidence there is as to its authentic nature. We may need to ask the people in question, because they are the ones who can say: 'No, that is not an accurate statement. I did not say that and, if I did, I did not mean it to be taken seriously'.
—You have decided it is prima facie evidence?

—I am not deciding anything is prima facie evidence. I have no personal animus against the judge who I believe is criticised or against the other persons on the tapes, most of whom I probably do not know. I claim to have no personal bias or animosity in this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I am concerned that Parliament does it right. For example, having read recently how the other House of Parliament in 1920 dealt with the expulsion of a Mr Mahon because he had made what was considered to be--

TALK.START.PARA: —That was before tapes were ever thought of.

—It does not matter. He made over a weekend a public speech which was regarded as seditious, pro-Irish and anti-British Empire. He was expelled by the other House of Parliament. The way in which that was done was one of the disgraceful performances of this Parliament. Likewise, the way in which the Parliament performed its duties in the Browne and Fitzpatrick case, in which the other House of Parliament again exercised its privileges in 1965, I think, was a disgrace. It had these powers then but it used them very badly and did not deal with justice with people outside its ranks.

SPEECH.PARA: This present matter has had a bad start but we have to finish it by trying to see that it is properly done, without the sensationalism which has accompanied it and which is influenced, to some extent, by an imminent State election, although I think that election will probably be very little affected by things said and done in this Parliament.
