It is this Parliament's honour and integrity which are at stake at this time. We cannot avoid going into this matter properly by committee. Although this motion concerns the Attorney-General's actions-I regret that his actions have heightened and failed to solve the matter. Therefore, this is a relevant question. The important discussion is: Where do we go to from here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is considering a motion of censure against the Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans, for his handling of what is called the Age tapes affair and his refusal to provide appropriate information to this Parliament. The first line of defence the Attorney-General has put up is the illegality of the taping. There is no reasonable doubt that these tapes were illegally made, but the attitude of the Government and of Government Ministers seems to be fairly flexible. Some time ago the present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) used a tape which was illegally obtained. On the Mike Willesee show he was asked about his attitude to his use of this illegal tape. This was his answer:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . not only do I not regard it as any significant invasion of privacy that I should be concerned about, but I believe it's a duty of anyone who's got information which will disclose the nature of these people and what they will do to decent Australians, then they should be revealed for the sort of people they are and the perfidious and hypocritical actions that they undertake.
That was the remark of the present Prime Minister when he was using, for his own purposes, an illegally obtained tape.

It is important to understand that the fact that this information is obtained illegally-there is no reasonable doubt about that-does not prevent us taking appropriate action, although of course we have to be satisfied before we take action that the material is authentic and relevant. The Attorney-General has made a great deal about the invasion of privacy involved, and certainly that is very serious, but of course the invasion of privacy is exactly the same whether the tapes were obtained legally or illegally. The invasion of Mr Combe's privacy , although his tapes were obtained legally, was just as much an invasion of privacy as this is. The problem I find with the Attorney-General's attitude is that he is putting up smokescreens to prevent his doing what I think he knows he should be doing.

Worse still-I think he was well described as an Inspector Clousseau in his behaviour and success-he seems to be most concerned, because it is a simply proved offence, one would have thought, to get the people who made the tapes. One wants to think about the circumstances in which these police, and I am sure they were police, made these tapes. They were confronted with a situation in New South Wales where some level of corruption has been endemic for years. It has become much worse under the Wran Government. They were confronted, when trying to investigate serious crime, with a network that covered police, politics, the criminals and elements of the judiciary. In order to try to find out what was blocking proper law enforcement in New South Wales they illegally taped things. Their methods were wrong; their motives, I think, were admirable. The danger is that Senator Evans's Inspector Clousseau-type activities will get the honest cops in New South Wales thrown out and leave the people they were trying to expose still in positions of power and influence. He has to start considering what will be the consequences of his actions. Like nearly all the things he does , they will have quite counter-productive effects.

I now turn to the responsibility of Parliament in this matter. Section 72 of the Constitution makes it quite clear that this Parliament is responsible for removing judges who have shown themselves to be inappropriate to hold that position. We have to define misbehaviour. It is not for the Solicitor-General or for some Director of Public Prosecutions. We have to make up our minds what is misbehaviour. Consider what might happen if there were before this chamber a motion to remove a judge for misbehaviour. We would have to decide whether we accepted that his behaviour constituted misbehaviour. It is our responsibility. Of course, being a responsible body, I hope that we would listen to people, including the Solicitor-General and others. Knowing lawyers, we would have very diverse arguments to listen to, but we ultimately hold the responsibility. We in this Parliament must decide whether a particular type of behaviour constitutes misbehaviour. No one else can do it. They can advise us, but our responsibility remains.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not from first principles.

—Of course, from first principles. It is our responsibility. We can take such advice as we wish, but we must have responsibility. There is another point in the Constitution I should refer to-the reference to 'proved misbehaviour'. That does not mean, as some honourable senators appear to think, that there has to be some sort of conviction in a court of law before the Parliament can act. The 'proved' undoubtedly refers to this Parliament having to accept, to decide, that the offence which it is complaining about is proven. We have to be the deciding body. We can take what advice we like, but ultimately the responsibility is ours and we cannot get away from it.

SPEECH.PARA: The question of the justiciability of these decisions is pretty clear. There is no way in which our decision that the offence was proved is justiciable. I can conceive of circumstances in which the Parliament might act completely irrationally so that the decision that behaviour constituted misbehaviour within the meaning of section 72 of the Constitution might be reviewed by the High Court. The question of proof is not justiciable. The definition of misbehaviour which Parliament accepted might be challenged. In the first instance, after taking proper advice, it is the responsiblity of this Parliament, not the Executive, not the judiciary, to decide what constitutes misbehaviour. If we are to make such a decision, we must have the information on which that decision can be made. The Government is trying to push us into a catch-22 situation in which the Attorney-General says: 'Yes, it is your responsibility, but no, I will not give the information on which you can exercise that responsibility'. That is a position which we cannot accept.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two bob each way.

—No, I am having it all on the one horse. We must make the decisions. We are the responsible body. We must decide whether the material is genuine or authentic. We should not delegate that decision to the Executive. We shall not make it by ourselves; we shall get advice-which is what the Attorney- General will be doing-which will allow us to decide whether the material is genuine or authentic. It is our responsibility. That was the weakness of, and why I voted against, the amendment moved by the Australian Democrats on the question of producing these tapes and transcripts in this chamber. They had left the decision as to whether the tapes and transcripts are genuine or authentic to the Executive. That is quite wrong. It is not the Executive's responsibility; it is the Parliament's responsibility, and we cannot yield it to anyone else.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Gareth Evans has referred the material to the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking. He did not check it for authenticity first. He gave the material to the Commission. That Commission will no doubt decide whether the material is genuine or authentic. Senator Gareth Evans gave it the whole lot. Why does he treat a royal commission in that way, and Parliament, which has quite different but clear and separate responsibilities, in a different way? He should give the relevant material that he gave to the Royal Commission to that Commission and he should give Parliament the relevant material that concerns us. He should not filter it first. We agree that it is to be published-I shall come to that shortly-and that it has to be sanitised, to use the expression which is in current use, to remove persons' names. But nevertheless, ultimately the responsibility is ours, and we must have the material on which we have to exercise that responsibility.

I accept the difficulty involved in tabling this material even when it is sanitised by removing the names and distinguishing characteristics of individuals. They will be identified. But on balance, I thought that it was proper to table the material, because most of it had already been published in a newspaper. We have the situation that the material was in the hands of the Government, having been given to it by the newspaper, but was not being given to the Parliament. I accept this difficulty, but the Attorney-General has not said: 'There is a difficulty, but I shall endeavour to overcome it'. He has never, for instance, said: 'I cannot give it to the Parliament to be tabled publicly, yet of course I will give it to a select committee'. If he says that a select committee is not appropriate, I draw his attention to the fact that he has proposed the setting up of a select committee of Parliament to monitor security matters and to have access to information far more sensitive and far more damaging to individuals than is this information. Yet he has made no such proposal in this case. All that we have been met with is a blank and sometimes childish refusal to provide any information of any relevance to the Parliament. We have gone on, day after day, probing so that we can perform our proper role, the role assigned to us by the Constitution and the role for which we are elected. All that we are met with is indifference, sneers or frivolous answers from the Attorney-General. That is just not good enough.

I must mention one further matter about the judiciary. Until this case is resolved there will be a permanent stain on the judiciary. All of them are under this slur. Until the one judge is identified, all are under suspicion. I believe that it would have been decent and proper for the judge concerned, when this matter first arose, to come forward and say: 'I am the judge concerned. Of course, I do not like the invasion of privacy; I think that it was outrageous. But I am innocent of any wrong doing'. He should identify himself. There is a very good precedent for this. When, in England, a similar slur was cast on the members of the Conservative front bench, Winston Churchill junior, one of the Conservative front bench, came forward and said: 'To avoid my colleagues being unjustly reflected upon by this sort of misinformation, I announce that I am the Conservative front bencher concerned'. I think that the judge should have done the same because until he is publicly identified this slur will be hanging over the whole Federal judiciary, to the great damage of our judicial system.

Finally, I return to the Attorney-General himself. It is very sad that he has shown himself-although in many ways he was quite successful as shadow Attorney- General-to be quite unable to cope with the job itself. He seems quite unable to combine the job of being a party Minister in a party government with the job of being the first law officer of the Commonwealth and the legal adviser to this Parliament. He also does not seem able to distance himself from his former contacts, some of whom, in current circumstances, are inappropriate. He reminds me very much of a footballer bounding forward and shooting at goal with both feet-but, of course, being an Inspector Clousseau type, missing all the time and probably falling over. Nevertheless, he is bounding forward and shooting wildly at goal, then suddenly he stops, blows the whistle, becomes the referee, and says that the opposition is offside. He cannot combine these two functions in the way in which he is trying to do. He has neither the style nor the temperament for it.

The Attorney-General has lost the confidence of the Opposition in his ability and impartiality as Attorney-General. From this debate it also appears that he has lost the confidence of the Government. Neither the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) nor the Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Grimes) bothered to defend him. They spent all their time attacking the Opposition. This is a problem for this Parliament. It is most important that this Parliament should have an Attorney-General in whom it has confidence and whom it can trust.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you say that the Leader of the Government in the Senate and his Deputy did not support him?
—Do you suggest that you have an open mind on this?

—I have a very open mind about it. I repeat, for Senator Robertson 's benefit, that in their debating speeches neither the Leader of the Government in the Senate nor the Deputy Leader of the Government spent much time defending the Attorney-General. They spent most of their time attacking the Opposition. We have an Attorney-General who, by his actions and by his childish behaviour, has lost the confidence of this chamber and this Parliament. He should be censured.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to defend the Attorney- General, Senator Gareth Evans, against this censure motion moved by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Chaney). I state from the outset that I shall be defending the Attorney-General's handling of this matter in a very personal sense. From the very first moment that the Age tapes surfaced the Attorney-General immediately referred the material for investigation. He referred them to Mr Temby, QC, an eminent lawyer and one whose integrity, I should have thought, would not have been in question. The Attorney-General referred the material to the Solicitor-General, Dr Griffith, one of the senior law officers of the nation and, again, a person whose integrity is not and should not be in question. Their opinions showed conclusively, without any doubt , that the judge in question was not guilty of misbehaviour.

SPEECH.PARA: The Attorney-General, as he has already stated in the Senate, conducted an interview with the judge himself. Again, after the interview, after reading the transcripts, after hearing the tapes, after looking at the opinions of Mr Temby and of the Solicitor-General, he came to the conclusion that the judge was not guilty of misbehaviour. That he should be satisfied with those opinions of independent men of integrity should come as no surprise to any of us. That the Opposition should not be satisfied with those opinions should, equally, be no surprise to any of us because this matter should be seen and known to be a purely political exercise, one to even old scores in a vain attempt to make new impressions-but a vain attempt it will remain.

The amazing scenes in this Parliament over the last few days, in the New South Wales Parliament a few days earlier and in the Queensland Parliament can only serve to bring down the public esteem of our institutions. I do not wish to comment too much on the performance of Mr Jennings in the Queensland Parliament except to say that it was Barry Simon, Andrew Peacock's henchman and hired help, who successfully had him booted out of the Victorian Liberal Party, and that Andrew Peacock should seek to rely on him and hide behind his skirts is pathetic . But it is indicative of the Opposition's campaign of recent weeks. As to the fact that I should call this a political exercise, some would say that it is because I have a bias in this matter. But I would like to quote from this morning's Sydney Daily Telegraph. The editorial on page 10 states:
Only a fool would believe that the drama being enacted in both Houses of Parliament over the past few days was not a jostle for political advantage.
The Liberals must think the electorate naive enough to forget the early concern of the Opposition Leader, Mr Peacock, 'to observe the civil liberties of those named in the transcripts'.
It is amazing how that concern evaporated with the announcement of a State election in New South Wales.

That, of course, is what all this tawdry operation has been about. That Senator Gareth Evans, who has acted so honourably, so promptly, so fairly and so properly in this matter, should have a censure motion put forward in an attempt to besmirch his name is again indicative of how low the Opposition will stoop. That all this could be based on tapes and transcripts-purported transcripts of conversations not backed up by tapes and, what is more, thrown over a journalist 's back fence-shows just how far the Opposition is willing to go. Ms Mary Gaudron, the Solicitor-General in New South Wales, one of the first persons of repute in our community to have the opportunity to investigate this material, when looking at how authentic these tapes might be, said:
In some conversations there are changes in speech patterns and/or speed which are to the untrained ear suggestive of 'editing.'

The question then becomes: Should the Attorney-General be a party to this political exercise? Should he denigrate this House and the Parliament as a whole by playing the Opposition's game? I am told that 11 conversations are recorded on these tapes. Some 3,000 conversations, taken over six months, are summarised or in some cases purported to be recorded faithfully in transcripts. How could any person named on those transcripts, whether he allegedly took part in a conversation or was merely referred to in one, ever defend his name once that material was made public? Those people would remain forever damned, forever blackened, with no opportunity for defence. Those transcripts can never be properly verified or authenticated. There have already been expert opinions on them. No doubt when the Australian Federal Police has finished its investigations into them even more expert opinions will be available. But, regardless of how many expert opinions we get, how do we verify transcripts that will never be backed up by tapes? There have been doubts as to where this material originated. It was said that it came from the Crime Intelligence Unit in the New South Wales Police-something upon which the Premier of New South Wales, Mr Neville Wran, has already cast serious doubt.

We must get back to the original question about which Senator Gareth Evans has been very concerned since this matter began. Senator Gareth Evans has a long record in the fight for civil liberties in this country. What civil liberties would exist for the people referred to on those tapes and transcripts if the demands of the Opposition were met by the Government? Which civil liberties would be allowed for those who are referred to but who are not involved directly in the alleged conversations? It should be noted at this stage that Ms Mary Gaudron has had much to say on this point as well. In her original report she said:
The remaining six bundles of documents are not matched with corresponding tapes . There is thus no measure by which their accuracy or authenticity can be assessed.

In view of the fact there just is not any way in which we can authenticate the material, how can the Parliament subject itself to being the arbiter of the future reputation of those people when it knows that there is a doubt about the material from the beginning that it can never erase? Let us look at the Attorney -General's responsibilities against the background of the points I have already made. The motion seems largely to have been forgotten in debate by those Opposition speakers who have spoken. I note that no member of the National Party has so far spoken. Perhaps members of that Party are sufficiently embarrassed by Mr Jennings's performance to wish to remain quiet.

Judging from what members of the Opposition have said, the Attorney-General should not at the moment be sitting in his office shaking too much because the motion actually refers to providing information to the Parliament. I would have thought it was the Attorney-General's responsibility-indeed, the very essence of his job-to ensure that if he provides information he is at least confident of its authenticity. No proper, honourable or competent Attorney-General could do anything less. Given the opinions of Ms Mary Gaudron that I have read out, one wonders just how the Attorney-General would go about providing authenticated material to this Parliament, especially when the information on these transcripts and tapes can damage irreparably the reputations of people in high public office and ordinary citizens alike. In this case, of course, it is the person in high public office who has received the most notoriety. That relates to the point I made about settling old scores. But surely the reputation and the integrity of the Senate and the Parliament as a whole are more important than just settling old political scores or making new points.

Having pointed out the worthlessness of this material at law, one wonders why, if the material could not be used in even the lowest magistrate's court, let alone a district court, a Supreme Court, or the High Court, it should suddenly be sanitised enough for use in either House of the Parliament. Why should either House of the Parliament entertain the tabling of this material? Why should the Attorney-General entertain answering all of the Opposition's queries when there is absolutely no hope of authentication? In the New South Wales Parliament only a couple of weeks ago the Premier, Mr Neville Wran, quoted Mr Collins, an independent expert briefed by a Canberra solicitor who had run a test on these tapes via computer signals. Mr Wran reported that Mr Collins had said 'there had been a conspicuous change in the nature and amplitude of the background noise occurring'. Further, after his computer analysis-something I do not think any member of the Opposition can claim to have done thus far-he said that he had detected evidence 'strongly indicative of tampering'. Not only do we have tapes that are unauthenticated but also we already have expert opinion which at least points to a very grave and serious doubt as to their authenticity. Can this ever come within the ambit of reliable information? I would have thought that if the Attorney-General were to provide information to the Senate its reliability ought to be established before he did so.

How can the Senate or the House of Representatives pretend that the allegations in these tapes and transcripts amount to reliable information? There is so much doubt about them, and that doubt can never be erased. The Parliament's dignity should not be lowered or dragged down any further in the public's esteem by being pushed into the role of a kangaroo court to hunt down, to besmirch or to kill off the reputation of political enemies, some of whom might have been members of the Senate. Those enemies-past, present or future-should not be subject to the abuse of their name and to what in some cases amounts to their name never being able to be restored to its former glory. The abuse of parliamentary privilege that has gone on in the parliaments of New South Wales and Queensland for some time unfortunately has been carried on in our Parliament in recent times. A vicious attack in another place last week upon a senior member of the judiciary should never have been contemplated. In this chamber in the last few days we have seen some members of the Opposition descending into a degree of muck-raking that really surprised me and I know surprised some of their own colleagues. All it can do is serve to undermine the public's confidence in its institutions-the Parliament and the judiciary. That is something to which I would have hoped none of us would be a party.

For the Attorney-General to agree to the Opposition demands to name names and destroy reputations would be to demean his office and to demean the institution of Parliament as well. The Attorney-General acted promptly and properly. His propriety cannot be questioned. He has a long record of defence of civil liberties. His concern for that matter has been shown in his handling of the tapes as he has gone through the last few harrowing weeks. The real question is: Should anyone be tried by the Parliament or the courts on the basis of this material; material which was thrown over a journalist's back fence, transcripts of conversations without tapes and a few highly doubtful tapes, all illegally obtained?

Some honourable members and honourable senators seek to pretend that the process by which this material was obtained is irrelevant. But if honourable senators opposite bat on with attempting to censure Senator Gareth Evans or if parliamentary committees begin examining these tapes this will encourage the law breakers. They will know that they can get away with monstrous invasions of privacy. What is more, if anyone wished to set up an opponent, or anyone wished to do some enemy damage, this would be giving that person the perfect blueprint. The sorts of proposals which the Opposition is coming up with will allow the unscrupulous to flourish and the innocent to suffer. I would have thought that it was the job of the Attorney-General to prevent that very thing happening. That is what he has been doing over the last couple of weeks. I, all members of the Government and, I am certain, the majority of Australian people support him in his endeavours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —Notwithstanding the fact that the Attorney- General (Senator Gareth Evans) has been forced to admit that this Parliament is solely responsible to decide the question of a prayer for the removal of a judge , the Attorney-General refuses to supply this Parliament with the material necessary to enable it at least to consider that question. That is why the Attorney-General is facing a censure motion in the Senate today. We have not seen the tapes and the transcripts. One gathers, from the debates, that some 300 conversations have been recorded. Apparently there are 524 pages of transcript and 12 tapes. I understand that they contain prima facie evidence of prostitution, drugs, horse race rigging and bribery in the State of New South Wales. Of course, they support the charge of corruption in New South Wales which has been established by inquiry after inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: Notwithstanding the flimsy attempts on the part of Government senators in this place to protect their Premier, Mr Wran, and his Government, that corruption has been established-so much so that it is evidenced by the fact that genuine policemen, sincere in their efforts in New South Wales, realised it was hopeless getting the Government to do anything and so they leaked this material to sources. Those sources realised it was hopeless to get even the New South Wales newspapers to publish it; so they arranged to provide the material to a Victorian newspaper. The corruption in New South Wales must surely be one of the things which the Australian Labor Party in this Federal Parliament ought to be ashamed of. It appears that the tapes and transcripts contain material relating to members of the Australian Labor Party. One thing is certain: They do not contain any material in relation to Mr Ian Sinclair, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in this Parliament. If they did, the tapes would have been tabled in this Parliament a long time ago.

However, it appears also that the tapes contain allegations of improper actions of a judge. I ask the Senate: If there is nothing in those allegations, why did Mr Temby, who considered these tapes, advise the Attorney-General that he ought to tell the judge to discontinue his association with a solicitor whose name apparently figures very prominently in the tapes and transcripts? Further, the Attorney-General told this Senate that the judge claimed legal professional privilege in relation to his conversations with that solicitor. So one must presume that there is a solicitor-client relationship between the solicitor and the judge. Recently the High Court of Australia narrowed the definitions and application of legal professional privilege. I ask the Attorney-General whether he believes that legal professional privilege applies to these conversations or whether, under the recent case held in that regard in the High Court, that privilege should stand.

As I mentioned earlier, apparently in some ways these tapes and transcripts relate to people involved in other criminal activities, for example, Mr Trimbole who is involved with drugs and other criminal activities. The Attorney-General has, quite properly, sent the parts of those tapes which relate to these matters to the various investigators concerned. But what did the Attorney-General decide to do in regard to the allegations relating to the judge? He decided to become the chief investigator. He told us yesterday that in this role he was acting as the Attorney-General, the first law officer of the country. But when he went to see the judge did he warn the judge that any statements which the judge might make to him might subsequently be used in evidence? Of course, they might subsequently be used in evidence. If the solicitor, under investigation from the joint task force of Commonwealth and State police, gives admissions to the task force which involve him in some criminal activity, then the link between the solicitor and the judge will be the evidence of the Attorney-General.

I wonder whether the Attorney-General gave the judge the normal warning which members of the police force are required to give to a person whom they are questioning? Apparently the Attorney-General did not even have the intelligence to ask the judge whether it was his voice on the tapes. Did the Attorney-General believe that, having heard the tapes, there was no question that it was the voice of the judge and he did not need to ask him that question? I do not know and neither does the Parliament because the Attorney-General refuses to tell us. Did he take any of these matters which were raised in the transcripts and the tapes and ask the judge whether he denied them? Apparently, he did not or he certainly is not prepared to tell us that the judge denied them. It now appears that the judge does not deny them. That can be the only conclusion we can draw after the debate in the Senate this week on these matters.

As we come to the end of this debate, it becomes perfectly clear that the Labor Party is not prepared to support the Attorney-General. We have heard the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) and the Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Grimes, neither of whom has stood up for the Attorney-General. They have attacked the Opposition. In particular, they have turned on Senator Sir John Carrick. They have savaged Senator Sir John Carrick, but at no stage did they attempt to defend the Attorney-General's actions in this matter. They have talked about smearing tactics and all that sort of thing but they have not turned to the defence of the Attorney-General. Why? Because they know that the Attorney-General has acted improperly in this matter in not providing some scheme or making some arrangement, whether it be a select committee or whatever. They know that it was the Attorney-General's responsibility to this Parliament and to the nation to provide the Parliament with the material, in some way or other, that the Parliament is entitled to have in order to consider the questions raised concerning constitutional responsibility. As neither Senator Button nor Senator Grimes defended the Attorney-General, it will be interesting to see how Senator Gietzelt might defend the Attorney-General.

This morning Dr Paul Gerber, apparently an expert on constitutional law, was interviewed on the radio program AM. I can recall, when he was in practice in Victoria, talking to him socially from time to time. This morning on AM he said some things which I would like to read to the Senate. Dr Gerber said:

We have, we that is the population as a whole, have hitched our judges to a higher star behaviour than we expect from the rest of us. On any view, if the allegations are genuine, this judge has evinced mortal foibles, if you like, of a kind which we do not expect our judges to indulge in.
Later on he was asked:
Of course the Attorney-General has said that judges are real people; they do live in the real world. Why should they be held accountable for things which are quite normal for us mere mortals?
In response Dr Gerber said:
Well, I think the answer to that is that I view judicial office--

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. I have been listening to what Senator Lewis has been saying and I have raised the point of order because I heard the same program. What Dr Gerber said this morning was plainly defamatory. Senator Lewis at present is introducing this matter and giving it the cover of privilege . I say that that is a matter he ought not to pursue. I think it is a very serious matter. Dr Gerber, at his own risk and at the risk of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, was giving currency to a defamatory matter without proof.
—Senator Lewis is entitled to conduct his speech in the way he chooses.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. I have the greatest admiration for Senator Georges in many respects but in this particular matter he is quite wrong. Dr Gerber has already gone public. If people wish to take action against him, they may do so. I am quoting Dr Gerber's opinion of these matters. I am not trying to do what Senator Georges suggests. Dr Gerber stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I view judicial office in a different plane from Mr Evans. These conversations if they can be attributed to the judge show the kind of behaviour which I would regard as lese-majesty, in other words, a High Court judge has got to be the kind of person who can always voice his thoughts on the public telephone. In this case, I think that has not happened.
Finally, he stated:

. . . indeed, I understand that Mr Evans in fact went to see the judge and confronted him with part of the allegation. The judge, as I understand it, whilst being outraged on the basis of an assault on his personal liberties and freedoms, did not disclaim the substance of the conversations although he said they were taken out of context.

TALK.START.PARA: —Again, I rise to a point of order. Senator Lewis is proving exactly what I was saying.

—Senator Georges, I have already ruled on your point of order. Senator Lewis is entitled to make a speech as he chooses, provided he is within the Standing Orders. He is not exceeding the Standing Orders in his speech at the moment. You cannot keep on taking the same point of order.
—I am entitled to raise the matter a second time.
—You have raised it and I have ruled on it.
—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. Senator Georges has achieved his aim. I have run out of time and I must now sit down.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is dealing with a censure motion against the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans). The Attorney-General has been on trial in the Senate yesterday and today. I believe parliamentary democracy is on trial as a result of the dastardly, disgraceful and disgusting tactics of members of the Opposition. We have seen evidence in recent days of the dregs of parliamentary democracy. I refer to the National Party members in Queensland attempting to use parliamentary privilege for the purpose of besmirching the reputations of citizens to whom no charge or trial has been afforded. They have made statements of a disgraceful nature against members of this Parliament. A statement was made against the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan), describing her as a bitch, and statements were made by Mr Jennings, a turncoat Liberal and now a member of the National Party in Queensland, and by Mr Lane, a turncoat.

SPEECH.PARA: Having seen the muck-raking, having seen the dirt and filth which emanates from that Party, we now have the pious and so-called Liberal element of this national Parliament endeavouring to take advantage of that situation. They are speaking on constitutional matters, suggesting that all of those statements have a certain credence, a certain validity, and that this Parliament, made up of party political representatives, should therefore take the next step of putting these citizens on trial in this place and using constitutional legal mumbo-jumbo to establish some validity for the statements made in another place. I believe that parliamentary democracy has been weakened, has been demeaned, has been put in an indefensible position. I quote from an editorial in the Sydney Daily Telegraph to which one of my colleagues referred previously. It states:
The Opposition has used parliamentary privilege to impinge the reputation of a citizen. Now their credibility is on the line.

What did Senator Evans do with the very first publication of these alleged unauthentic unauthorised tapes? He presented a statement to Parliament, and he has been subjected to a concentrated barrage of questions which I believe he has answered with candour and frankness. In some respects, he answered very fully the questions put to him, but his answers were designed to protect the interests of the citizens who have been named in these unauthorised tapes and transcripts. If anybody should be on trial in this place it is the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Senator Durack, because, clearly, it was during his reign as Attorney-General that the tapes were made. He has not made any criticism of the fact that the tapes were made. The Parliament has passed legislation setting responsibility for phone tapping in the office of the Attorney-General. No speaker on the Opposition side has suggested that there has been laxity or the commission of a crime in respect of these tapes, which were made in 1979. Yet Senator Durack, in seconding the motion that the current Attorney-General should be censured and criticised for his behaviour on this matter, has not sought to explain his lax administration in the period in which the tapes were made.

As I understand it, the tapes were known to the Liberal-Country Party coalition . They were in fact referred to a Cabinet committee back in 1980, and the then Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, refused to have anything to do with them. So Senator Chaney, Senator Peter Baume, Senator Sir John Carrick, Senator Durack and all the other front bench Opposition senators who were members of the previous Government knew of the existence of the tapes but did absolutely nothing about them at the behest of the former Prime Minister, Mr Fraser. He did not accept their authenticity and did not want to have anything to do with unauthorised eavesdropping by telephone tapping in this country.

We have a situation where guilt by association seems to have its place in the thinking of honourable senators opposite or, should I say, dishonourable senators opposite, who have attempted to traduce and besmirch and smear the character of prominent citizens without any prima facie evidence. Senator Missen suggested that he was not prepared to say there was a prima facie case against any person in this dispute. Nevertheless, he is prepared to lend himself to the suggestion that somehow or other Mr Morgan Ryan might be a person of some disrepute and, because he has some association with a member of the judiciary, that that places the member of the judiciary also in some state of disrepute.

I remind honourable senators of a letter dated 21 June 1982 from E. K. White, a founding member of the Liberal Party, to Malcolm Fraser. He set out a character reference for Morgan Ryan and suggested certain things to the Attorney-General at the time, Senator Durack. The consequence of that correspondence to the Prime Minister was that the principal charge of forgery against Morgan Ryan was dropped and the other charge that was levelled against him was reduced in severity to the point where only a minor fine applied.

The Opposition is not prepared to undertake the hard, slogging work of a creative, responsible Opposition. We do not hear it talking about the state of the economy; we do not hear it talking about unemployment; we do not hear it talking about the nuclear problems in existence throughout the world; we do not hear it talking about the poverty areas of Australia, the iniquities in our taxation system and all of the other areas in which the responsibilities of the Opposition are clearly as great as those of the government of the day. Rather, since the Parliament resumed, it has talked about the matters allegedly associated with the tapes and transcripts-tapes and transcripts that have been clearly doctored. It has suggested that the Age newspaper is the epitome of respectability; that because the allegations were published in that paper they have some measure of respectability and should therefore be a matter for the national Parliament. But one of the statements in the original Age article was shown to have been nothing more than an incorrect transcription of the tapes. As Senator Evans has consistently pointed out, thousands and thousands of conversations were involved. Persons other than the couple of names that have been mentioned may be affected. It may well be that other people's names were mentioned in the telephone conversations.

Mr Deputy President, is the Opposition conscientiously saying that your Party believes that every time there is an unauthorised taping of telephone conversations, it becomes the responsibility of the national Parliament to concern itself, to set itself up as a higher court of appeal and to sit in judgment upon what is said on such tapes and in such transcripts? Are we saying that we come here as men and women with open minds, as does a jury in every other legal circumstance, and that we are capable of making value judgments about what a person may say, or did say, in respect of the transcripts? We know that that is hogwash. We know that there is no substance to that view. We know quite well that this is a party house, that the attitude that has been taken by the Opposition has been determined in the party room and that the Government's is clearly defending the position and judgment made by the Attorney-General who, I believe, has been very frank in the way in which he has dealt with this matter and whose behaviour throughout this incident has been satisfactory. His behaviour cannot under any circumstances be regarded as unsatisfactory in respect of his responsibilities to this Parliament. We are beginning to see a backlash amongst the Australian people about this matter and about the reputations of prominent citizens. I refer to an article in today's Australian, which states:
But there are many lawyers-including some close to the High Court-who say it is grossly improper for the parliamentary Opposition to drag out the issue the way it has.

Those lawyers believe that the standing orders of Parliament, which require any criticism of the judiciary to be undertaken by substantive motion rather than by questioning or innuendo, should be rigorously applied.

Of course that is the case. But members of the Opposition have relied upon the dregs of parliamentary democracy in the Queensland Parliament because they did not want to put themselves in the position of mentioning names in the Parliament . But once persons had been named, they took the next step of moving a censure motion against the Attorney-General without any substance at all. The Attorney- General has taken the correct procedure in seeking information about these matters, in seeking the advice of reputable people who have been appointed to assist him in the processing of the claims, innuendoes and smears that are characteristic of the tapes. Those tapes are illegal. They were improperly taken . They were not authorised. There has not been a word from the Opposition about the legislation for which this Parliament was responsible which relate to inquiries that are available to satisfy any sensible, reasonable person about the authenticity of the tapes.

I do not want to enter into the smear campaign being carried on by National Party members in other places and the innuendo by members of the Liberal Party. However, if that is the way the Parliament is to operate, we will be able to put together any amount of cases of irregularity and improper procedure by other people in public life in Australia, including those on the High Court. Do we want to apply that sort of standard to parliamentary debate, or do we want the Parliament to carry out its proper responsibility of introducing legislation and looking after the interests of the Australian people? I find it distasteful that people for whom I had some respect, even though I did not share their philosophy or ideological position, should allow themselves to be pushed into this sort of character assassination in the belief that somehow or other it would help their colleagues in the State election in New South Wales. It is without doubt a coincidence that on the last day on which the Senate proceedings were to be broadcast, Senator Chaney moved that sort of motion, knowing full well, or hoping that it would have some impact on the State election.

Anybody who listened to PM and AM would have heard discredited individuals such as Jennings and Francis. They were associated with graft and corruption in Victoria to such an extent that they were expelled from the Liberal Party. They tried on AM and PM to give some sort of justification for this muck-raking process. The pattern that is developing is that anything is good in love and war . In politics, one can throw whatever mud or human excrement that one likes, as long as a little bit of it sticks. That is the way to achieve an objective. I believe that people outside who look to parliament for some inspiration and assistance in the way in which the country should be governed are appalled at the behaviour of the Opposition in this place. It used members in another place as a front to name people. Until that happened I respect the fact that in this place Senator Chaney and others refrained from naming people. But once it had been done, they jumped on the bandwagon, determined to extract every bit of political mileage possible.

I am absolutely disgusted with National Party members-even those in this place- who countenance the behaviour exhibited by their colleagues in the Queensland Parliament. Once the muck-rakers have done their filthy, underhand work it is no good for the goody-goodies of the Liberal Party in this place to take advantage of that situation and to try to extract some political gain. It is a disgrace to the Westminster system. It is a disgrace to the fundamentals of British democracy and British justice.

The principle that nobody is guilty until so proven seems to me to have been forgotten by some of those who pose as Liberals in this place. Let us look at what has happened recently. I will conclude on this note, because I realise some time limitations have been placed upon us. There was a case involving a Mr Anderson, a person about whom I make no comment. When his trial had been almost completed, certain utterances were made on television by public figures in New South Wales. What did the judge do? He dismissed the jury because of the influence and innuendoes that were inherent in the television reports because they could have prejudiced Mr Anderson's right to a fair trial. The judge correctly took the important step-it is one of the safeguards in our legal system-of dismissing the jury so that there would be no undue or other influence upon the deliberations of the jury. Does anyone suggest that in the Senate, where the Government lacks a majority, the same sort of approach to human decency and fundamental human rights, the principles of democracy and British justice, will be available to any person who has been named in the tapes and transcripts? Any honourable senator who believes that believes in fairy stories.

In my belief this has been a very sorry and dark week in politics. I am glad that it is the last day of this sitting period and that when we come back the New South Wales election will have receded from the attention of the Senate and the House of Representatives and we will be able to get on with the job that we are here to do. We are here to pass legislation and to carry out properly our parliamentary responsibilities-not to be in a cesspool of excrement, which has been the tactics followed by the Opposition in this place. All I say is thank heavens the balance of power rests with the Australian Democrats and not with those in the Liberal-National Party ranks who seem to believe that they have the right to besmirch and destroy the reputation of any person just for political gain.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-We have had a very lengthy debate on the motion which I moved to censure the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans). The debate has been lengthened because a significant number of honourable senators felt they had to or wished to make a contribution to a debate which we regard as very important. Like Senator Gietzelt, we might all wish we had been able to spend the week on other matters. The Opposition simply says that we have spent so much of the week debating this matter because it is important and because the Government has not faced up to its responsibilities, and in particular the Attorney-General has not faced up to his. I think it is the universal wish of those in the chamber that we should take a vote on this motion by 12.45 p.m. Hence my response to the very many points which have been made in the course of the debate will be brief, as will my summing up.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to deal with the complaint of the Attorney-General and other honourable senators who allegedly spoke in his defence that the Opposition has concentrated its attention solely on the small number of tapes and transcripts involving the judge and has paid little or no attention to the approximately 3,000 tapes which involve other serious allegations, such as prostitution and SP bookmaking. I simply remind the Senate that the fact of the matter is that all of those matters, other than the allegations relating to the judge, are under a police inquiry headed by a special prosecutor. The Opposition has at all times said that it believes that is appropriate and that the Government was right to set that course of action in train. Our main concern is with the fact that as long ago as 17 February, in a statement put out by the Attorney-General and the Special Minister of State, Mr Mick Young, it was made quite clear that there would be no further investigation of the behaviour of the judge. That matter was excluded. It is therefore that matter which is of concern to the Opposition. It is properly our concern also because it is that matter which is peculiarly within the responsibility of the Parliament. It is the Parliament which has the responsibility of taking action if a member of the judiciary behaves improperly.

That is our responsibility. We cannot escape it. While all of us might wish to be off doing something else, I remind the Senate that it is quite clear that unless the Parliament takes its responsibilities in this matter seriously they will not be dealt with satisfactorily. I was appalled to read in this morning's Australian Financial Review a well sourced article by Mr Hywood in which he said that the Federal Government's attitude is that it will defend somebody but it will not be making information available unless the Opposition tables material. Does not that go to the sort of complaint the Opposition has been making that the response of this Government and preparedness of this Government to make information available depends on whether the Opposition is prepared to do things which the Government senators have been telling us would be quite improper? We are in an awkward position as an Opposition where to get the Government to give a response we are being challenged to do things which the Government would then say is muck-raking.

The whole of this debate on the Government's side has been characterised by a refusal to face up to the issues and, indeed, a preparedness to discuss anything but the issues. I will use the brief time that I have to use not the words of the Opposition but the words of other observers about the Government's conduct in this matter. As the Opposition has been continually met by abuse of the sort that was so common in the debate yesterday, when it was accused of muck-raking, I will put the views of some other people as to the inadequacies of the way the Government has handled this matter. I thought there was an excellent summary, as recently as this morning, of the sorts of complaints we have made about the Government and its handling of this issue. I quote from an article in the Sydney Morning Herald by Mr Les Carlyon, which I think puts it particularly clearly. Talking about Neville Wran and Gareth Evans and their response to these matter, Mr Carlyon stated:

All through, it's seemed as though both men, on finding a body on their front doorstep, have been concerned not so much to discover what's going on-but to rail against the neighbours for having the gall to tell them the thing's lying there. Don't worry about the news: kill the messenger.

That is what we have seen in this debate. We have been told not to worry about the substance of the matter and the allegations that there has been behaviour on the part of a judge that does not measure up to the high standards which Senator Evans himself said are required, but to kill the messengers and to abuse them and say there is something wrong with them. Mr Carlyon continued:

It gets more serious. The story broadened, the messengers refused to cringe, so the Premier hauled on his overalls and began a litany about filth and muck, and even said: '. . . at times I feel like giving the whole thing away.' Then, next thing, he's holding an election, a victory in which would presumably stop him giving the whole thing away for another four years. A victory would be a fine achievement-except he'd still have to step over this body on the doorstep. A proper legal inquiry, rather than an election, would have removed it.

Senator Evan's behaviour has been just as curious. The Attorney-General, a great civil libertarian (remember the Bill of Rights?), said the material shouldn't have been published. It invaded privacy. He didn't mention that he was responsible for the release of the Combe telephone show. He was incensed that The Age report contained an error. He didn't mention that the Combe transcripts contained many errors. The senator gave a homily on 'reasonable journalism,' all the more terrifying because he seemed to think the press an arm of government.

The reponses of the Premier and the Attorney-General have been misguided all along. Terribly misguided. Week after week, they side-stepped the substance-the 10 lines of legal inquiry suggested by the New South Wales Solicitor-General and the Commonwealth Special Prosecutor-in their attempts to maim messengers.

What a perfect summary of this debate! Do not bother with the issues. Maim the messengers. Complain about the fact that the issues have been raised. Again I will quote the comments of a series of newspapers on the matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is a journalist, is he? Is that all you have to rely on?
—Senator Gietzelt quoted from newspapers in his speech. He should not complain when I do that in response. The Australian Financial Review, in discussing the allegations about the judge, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: This is probably the most serious aspect of the reports based on tapes. For if it should emerge that a 'senior judge' was in fact behaving in this fashion, then there is absolutely no doubt that he is not fitted for his office, and should be removed from it at the earliest opportunity.
That was one comment in one of the leading articles of the Australian Financial Review. The Melbourne Herald of 22 February stated:
. . . there has been a concerted effort by the NSW Government to divert attention from their substance.
It was referring to the substance of the tapes. It continued:
If genuine, the contents reveal an alarming state of affairs.
It is vital we establish whether the matters now raised have substance, and where they fit this pattern. It is the kind of job a National Crimes Commission could handle.
On 29 February the Age said of the Attorney-General:

He is more outraged by the invasion of privacy and the damage to reputation- although we have not named or precisely identified those involved-than by the evidence of crime, corruption and impropriety which the telephone tapping revealed.

I could quote the opinions of many people who have nothing to do with the Opposition, who have had no political axe to grind and who are totally dissatisfied with the failure of the Attorney-General to come to grips with this matter and who are totally dissatisfied by the Government's failure to come to grips with the matter. I believe that the motion of censure is properly brought against an Attorney-General who has failed to meet the demands that he act in the public interest and not in party interests and partisan interest.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Chaney's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate and the House of Representatives have agreed to new sitting hours which involve each chamber continuing its sitting through the lunch period on each Thursday. The decision not to suspend the sitting of either House for lunch on Thursday creates difficulties for the Hansard staff. The staff is not large enough to permit continuous manual reporting during the lunch period while at the same time allowing reporters, typists and other Hansard staff to have an uninterrupted meal break. Accommodation constraints within the Hansard offices also preclude the recruiting of staff in numbers sufficient to enable this to be done.

INTERJECT.PARA: Under these circumstances, I have approved the Principal Parliamentary Reporter 's proposal that the proceedings of the Senate on each Thursday between 12.45 p. m. and 2 p.m. be tape-recorded. The Principal Parliamentary Reporter has advised that this arrangement will not interfere with the reporting of the Senate. Honourable senators will continue to receive pinks, although perhaps somewhat later than at present, and the tape-recorded segment will be included in the Hansard in the usual way.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to make a brief statement on the last vote. I abstained from it. I had hoped to advise the Senate of the purpose of my abstaining but the debate petered out earlier than I thought it would. I believe I will have the opportunity of stating why I abstained because it involves an interest that I have in one of the persons named on the tapes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not take the opportunity of the first reading to speak on an issue other than the issues regulating to the Bills but I take this opportunity now of raising an issue since the Parliament will rise for a couple of weeks. It relates to the Dried Fruits Levy Amendment Bill. I do not wish now to rehearse the comments that I will make during the second reading stage of the Bill, but since the Government is intending to double the current maximum rate of the levy in relation to dried fruits, which of course are levied for research purposes, and given the consideration that the 1984 season has been the worst season on record for the dried fruit industry, during the second reading stage I will be asking the Government to provide a financial impact statement on the financial impost on the industry of the increased levy.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to make only one other comment and that relates to a series of Press reports about the Democrats' position in relation to these Bills. If one reads them one is greatly confused as to what precisely is going on. Indeed, in some of the newspaper reports there were contradictions within the item itself. On 29 February I issued a Press release, which was not carried in any of the newspapers, but which related to the fact that the Bills that the Government was about to introduce in the House of Representatives arose out of the razor gang report. The criticism contained in that Press release related to the fact that the current Australian Labor Party Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Kerin, at the time of the introduction of the razor gang report had said that the measures -measures which he has now introduced in the House of Representatives-were mad and crazy. The Government now proposes to introduce six Bills which when in opposition, it severely criticised. This is the first reading stage of those six Fraser razor gang Bills.

As I say, I issued that Press release on 29 February. Obviously Mr McVeigh read my Press release because he certainly did not make any statement about those Bills prior to the 29th. He made a statement in the House of Representatives that the Australian Democrats would support the Opposition in referring the matters to a committee of the Senate. A number of people in the Press contacted me about this issue and I felt that it was useful to put on record our position. Briefly, that position, as set out in my Press release of 7 March, is as follows . Firstly, the Opposition has not approached the Australian Democrats in relation to the reference. Secondly, the Democrats object to the notion of House of Representatives people suggesting what Senate committees should do. Any reference to a Senate committee will be determined by the Senate, not by Ministers or shadow Ministers in the House of Representatives. I made the point that we were not going to be a party to the Fraser operation, when he was Leader of the Opposition, of running this place from the House of Representatives. Thirdly, the Democrats believe that the problems that emerged with the honey Bill last year, which is part of this package, can be met by amendments which we intend to move, amendments which I have to hand and which will meet the issues. However, I went on to say-and this is the first point in which I raised what our response would be in relation to the Opposition's notice of referring these Bills to a Senate committee:

If approached by the Opposition and if the Opposition have good reason for taking up the Senate Committee's time to look at these Bills over and above the problem that emerged last year-our amendments would easily overcome that problem -we will, however, give it favourable consideration.

The Canberra Times has an article headed 'AD will not support Opposition move'. The Australian has one headed 'Democrats won't help ''delay'' export charges bill'. The Australian Financial Review has one saying 'Democrats opt out'. I remind honourable senators of what I said in my Press release in regard to this matter:

If approached by the Opposition and if the Opposition have good reason for taking up the Senate Committee's time to look at these Bills over and above the problem that emerged last year, we will, however, give it favourable consideration.

I will be rehearsing in the second reading stage a range of these matters. We will be seeking to look not only at that issue which was raised in the honey Bill but a whole variety of other issues. We believe that this is an important matter because it affects the livelihoods of a lot of people in Australia. But while this Parliament has been engaged for hour upon hour with matters which ultimately, I predict, will affect nobody in this country, because we have not the capacity to do so, we have put aside, have not debated, something which in fact could end up ruining people in this country and taking away their chance of a livelihood. I believe that they are important matters and unfortunately, because so much time has been taken up, we will not have a chance to discuss them in depth.

I went on to make the further point that the Democrats believe that the reason behind Mr McVeigh's actually suggesting this is that the Opposition parties do not want a vote on these particular Bills because as Mr McVeigh has indicated, the Opposition parties will support the increase in the levies. They will vote to increase all of these levies and the last thing that the National Party of Australia requires in an election in New South Wales is to have voted for an increase in these levies. I also indicated to the Press that we would be seeking to contain these levies in the same way that we sought to contain them in relation to the meat inspection levies last year. We were defeated on that, when in fact the Labor Party, the Liberal Party and the National Party voted to double the levy proposed in the Democrat amendment. We will seek yet again to contain these inspection charges, some of which of course are completely new. They are charges indicated by the razor gang as new avenues for taxation in the primary industry area, charges which were condemned at the time by the Labor Party but which it now has introduced into the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take advantage of this first reading debate to make some remarks about a recent announcement made by the Special Minister of State, Mr Young. The Minister announced that a plain English project under the direction of Professor Robert Eagleson has been established by the Federal Government, and I would just like to quote some of the remarks that were made in the Press about Mr Young's announcement. An article in the Canberra Times said, amongst other things:

SPEECH.PARA: A plain-English project under the direction of Professor Robert Eagleson would aim to ensure that government publications were comprehensible. Also a special team would review all government forms, including the Australian Taxation Office 's Form S.
Mr Young said the review of forms and the use of simple English in all government material meant that the public could look forward to a much easier time in dealings with the Government.
Simple forms were not only easier to complete, they were also cheaper, because people made fewer mistakes trying to fill them out and less time and money had to be spent following them up.

I would like to congratulate the Government and Mr Young for this initiative. About five years ago in this place I raised the matter of incomprehensible government prose. I read to the Senate a letter from the Australian Taxation Office and indicated that the particular letter went almost off the scale of a well-known reading ease score. I should mention that it almost went off the scale the wrong way. It was exceptionally difficult. That speech, for those interested, is on pages 976 to 980 of the Senate Hansard of 27 March 1979. I am aware that some government departments are doing their best to communicate clearly with the public. The Department of Social Security is a case in point. Its pamphlets have been much improved in readability over recent years. Unfortunately, difficult to read prose still rears its ugly head.

I recently encountered an excellent example of what is now commonly referred to as gobbledegook. Having exhausted my reading material on an Ansett flight, I glanced at the small print on my ticket. I imagine that very few people ever bother to read the terms and conditions on their tickets but if they do, then they are to be complimented for their tenacity. One sentence on this ticket runs to 197 words. It includes so many obscure qualifications and parenthetical comments that it requires both a high degree of literacy and industry to read it . It reads this way:

Subject to the foregoing and to any other conditions imposed by any of the said Acts, the Companies accept no responsibility for damage of any kind whatsoever ( including death injury delay or loss) arising out of, or incidental to the carriage or any services ancillary thereto (including embarking and disembarking and the transfer of the passenger and his baggage to or from an airport, taking off or landing place) whether or not such damage be due to negligence on the part of the Companies, their servants or agents or otherwise howsoever, and the passenger for himself and his executors administrators and dependants expressly renounces all claims against the Companies in respect thereof (other than claims made pursuant to the provisions of any of the said Acts) whether they may be due to negligence on the part of the Companies their servants or agents or otherwise howsoever; notwithstanding anything herein contained the Companies will be under no liability for loss of or damage to registered baggage occurring more than 12 hours after such baggage became available for collection or for loss of or damage to any baggage resulting from the inherent defect, quality or vice of the baggage.

To calculate the reading ease of that sentence is an exercise in futility. There is no ease at all. I did calculate a score for the sentence but the score went off the scale backwards. What it means is difficult to interpret. What it could mean is that one has to be an intellectual genius to read the sentence with complete comprehension. It does indicate that the sentence is unnecessarily difficult. It is obvious that plain English is required not only in government departments but in many public and private organisations as well. However, if the Government takes a lead, as it apparently has done, it may be that other organisations will also see the benefits of writing in plain English.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity of this first reading debate to make a few comments in relation to the Government's housing policy. I will be reasonably brief in my remarks. I think it is worth while pointing out at this stage that the Hawke Labor Government's first home owners scheme came into effect in October and it is probably one of the most effective and fairest schemes that the country has ever seen. It is a major component of the Government's housing program and is playing a key role in Australia's economic recovery. It has been designed to ensure that Australian families in particular will be able to gain access to adequate housing at prices they can afford. It has been designed so that young couples purchasing houses can afford to raise the deposit to make a purchase of a dwelling and gain a home for themselves.

SPEECH.PARA: Since the inception of the first home owners scheme some five months ago, the scheme has been a stunning success. The figures show this statement to be correct. Figures available to 17 February are testimony of the scheme's success and I am happy to note that roughly a quarter of the applications and approvals belong to my own State of Queensland. By 17 February, there were 42,629 applications for first home owner assistance and 8,205 of these applications were in the State of Queensland. So far, 16,560 applications have been approved throughout Australia, 4,246 of which were in the State of Queensland. The value of these approvals over the next five years is more than $81m Australia-wide and more than $20m in the State of Queensland. The total number of inquiries that have been received by the Department of Housing and Construction by 17 February is a staggering 317,857, and that does not include the inquiries received by banks, building societies, lending institutions, real estate agents and other people involved in the building industry. I think that number certainly shows that the scheme has caught on and that it has been very successful in relation to the financing of new dwellings being constructed.

New home approvals during December 1983 represented an increase of almost 50 per cent over the figure for December 1982 yet the Government still faces a huge backlog of housing needs. I think some of that backlog was created by the non- activity of the previous Government. In the 1983-84 Federal Budget the Hawke Labor Government, aware of this appalling neglect, increased funding for housing by 50 per cent to $500m. The results of the statistics I have just cited clearly show that this scheme is doing something to alleviate the housing problems or the shortage of housing that we have in Australia. The December 1983 improvement in housing statistics is in stark contrast to the situation in the final year of the Liberal-National Party Government. Australian banks approved housing loans last December totalling $510.5m. This was $154.8m more than the previous December in seasonally adjusted terms. The December figures brought the total value of approvals for 1983 to $5,021m. Building societies lent $304m in December 1983, more than double the amount for December 1982. Lending by savings banks and total lending for housing by all other lenders were both at a record level in December 1983. Total dwelling approvals for 1983 were 133,300-up 13 per cent on the 1982 figure. The interesting point here is that the improvement was most pronounced towards the end of 1983 when the scheme came into operation. This is evidenced by the fact that in the six months to December, approvals were 30 per cent higher than for the corresponding period in 1982. But in the three months to December, the corresponding increase was 41 per cent. I think that it is quite apparent from those figures that the first home owners scheme is certainly playing a role in the development of the housing needs of Australians and that it is also playing a role in regard to the lifting of the economy throughout the Commonwealth of Australia. The scheme has enabled the housing sector to join the rural industry as a pacesetter for economic recovery in this country.

It is also worth noting that the industry is also responsible for creating employment in many related fields. For every job created by the Government's economic and housing policies on a building site, one full job is created in other industries, such as the production of building materials or fittings for home furnishing. There are something like 26 allied trades tied to the building industry, so one can see that any increase in the participation of the building industry in the construction of homes certainly has a marked effect on the employment of people in the trades that are tied to the building industry and generally as an assistance to the growth that we are now experiencing in the economy. We have such allied trades as plumbers, painters, carpenters, builders, labourers and tilers, who are particularly tied to the building industry. But beyond that are the people who are in the real estate industry and in the lending industry, the financial world. There are people who are tied to the activities of the building industry in furnishing and retailing, et cetera. These sections have started to gather some growth because of the growth in the building industry.

I believe it is fairly important at this stage to make one further point and that is that under the Commonwealth housing agreement, the Commonwealth Government should take a very strong look at the question of public housing as well as housing in the private sector. I think there needs to be some alleviation of the problems that exist in the public sector for those young people who cannot gain enough money or borrow enough money to build a house of their own in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is, of course, a first reading debate when senators have an opportunity to speak on any matters of interest or concern to them and it is the first occasion that we have so had this sitting. I want to use it to speak of what to me is one of the most disappointing events to occur during the recess and that was the overthrow of civilian government in Nigeria. When I last spoke on Nigeria in October 1982, it was after returning from a parliamentary delegation to Africa and I observed the factors, particularly economic factors, that were placing great stress upon that country. I was concerned then, and expressed my concern, for the possible consequences of such economic stress, because the delegation had witnessed in that country a strong commitment to democracy and a desire as Nigerians to make it work and also I believe, a recognition that the military experience that they had had for 13 years had so patently failed.

SPEECH.PARA: For 13 of its 22 years since independence it had experienced military rule and it was clear to the delegation the possibility that such could return if the civilian government was unable to meet the aspirations of the Nigerian people. That unfortunately did in fact occur in the early hours of 1 January this year when the military left the barracks and the government of President Shagari re- elected only last August was forcibly usurped. The great tragedy is not only the loss for Nigeria but the loss for the whole of Africa. When President Shagari was re-elected a second term only last August he was reported to have said:
This is not a victory for me alone, but a victory for democracy in Africa. The lesson is that if Nigeria can run a democratic system, there is no reason why other African countries should not.

The coup that toppled Shagari therefore dealt a blow to the hopes of a black Africa that looked to Nigeria as a trailblazer for democratisation. The failure was regrettably just the most recent recurrence of a pattern of failure that has gripped the continent, a failure which has led such as Eden Kodjo, the former Secretary-General of the Organisation of African Unity, to say:
Our ancient continent is now on the brink of disaster, hurtling towards the abyss of confrontation, caught in the grip of violence. Gone are the smiles, the joy of life.

Mr Deputy President, I give a few brief statistics in support of what he says. In the last 25 years more than 70 leaders in 29 African nations have been deposed by assassination, purges or coups. Among the 41 major independent black African nations only seven allow opposition political parties, 17 are single- party states and another 17 are ruled by military regimes. But this was a particularly significant coup, not, if I might use the language of the Economist , a 'run of the mill coup in a third world Statelet where guns were better than the ballot boxes'. Nigeria last Christmas was in fact the world's fourth largest democracy. It had provided vital leadership in Africa, particularly in the OAU. It was a significant voice in the Commonwealth, maintaining strong and implacable opposition to South Africa's apartheid policies. It had the status of a member of the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries. It is a major trading partner of Britain and the United States of America. It played a leading role in the non-aligned movement and through it in the United Nations. On a continent increasingly dominated by nations under military or one-party rule, Nigeria was providing a working example of a democratic way. For four and a half years an experiment in democracy was being tried, and now the soldiers have regrettably closed the experiment.
It is disappointing to see the response by Western nations and observers to the military takeover in Nigeria, as one of either disinterest or cynicism. I understand that the United States said:
We regret the removal of Nigeria's Government by unconstitutional means.
But it quickly added:
We are looking forward to working with the authorities there.
