Although I have searched I have been unable to find any statement by the Australian Minister. To imply, as this does, that a military government would be no worse than the democratic government of President Shagari displays a disturbing acquiescence to authoritarianism being triumphant over democracy.

The point I wish to make, Mr Deputy President, is that too much has been expected of democracy in Africa too soon. Winston Churchill's dictum that ' democracy is the worst form of government except for all others man has ever tried' remains true. But democracy is a new concept for Africa. Suitable institutions must evolve and experiments must occur. Mistakes will be made, and there is no doubt that this has happened in the Nigerian experience. But the process demanded much more respect and support than the Western World has given. As Hilary Ng'weno, Editor in Chief of the Weekly Review in Nairobi, recently wrote:

If democracy is worth fighting for in South Africa, it is worth fighting for in the rest of Africa. The indignation that Africans justifiably direct at undemocratic developments in South Africa should be directed at similar development elsewhere on the continent.

The same indignation should be expressed by those of us fortunate enough to live under the freedom of liberal democratic governments. It is not true that Africa' s men in uniform know more about governing society that their civilian counterparts, nor is it true that they are cleaner and more devoted to the national interest than politicians. Soldiers claim, as soldiers often do, that they alone can clean up corruption. But it is worth remembering that the military juntas in Nigeria of 1966 to 1979 included and patronised as many crooks as their civilian predecessors and successsors. As the Economist said-I think in most eloquent terms-in the article to which I earlier referred:
Now the hands in the till will again have braid on their sleeves.

The new leader, General Buhari, as with the former President Shagari, although appearing personally untainted was, when the military was last in government in Nigeria, the person who presided over an oil sector beyond argument corruptly inefficient.

I do not intend to stand here, and say, as I did not in October 1982, that all was well in Nigeria. The economic position was disastrous; inflation was heading back to the levels that Shagari inherited from the military, and corruption was rife, as it is all over Africa and in many other places. Democracy itself must be conceded to have been rough around the edges. There are widespread allegations of vote rigging at last August's election but in balance there were many factors in its favour. I mention just a few. There was a system of courts in which the Government itself could be challenged. It is worth noting that in the case of at least one of the rigged ballots at the last August election the decision was overturned in the courts. The country had free Press that was able to and often did criticise the Government. It had a number of opposition parties which had won power in seven of the 19 states at the last August elections. It is worth noting also that it was a country with no political prisoners. These freedoms are rare in Africa and I think it might be reasonably contrasted with what happened in the early hours of 1 January this year when the armed forces closed all airfields and seaboards, severed communication links to the outside world, banned all political parties and imposed a dusk to dawn curfew warning that anyone caught 'misbehaving' would be executed summarily.

What is also important, is that at the time of the coup steps were being taken to address the accepted difficulties in Nigeria. Shagari had made it clear both before and following his re-election that corruption and inefficiency within the bureaucracy would have to be eliminated. He undertook a major Cabinet reshuffle following the August election when only eight of the previous Ministers survived . He also set about establishing a ministry specifically charged with fighting corruption, and on the economic front he had brought down a severe Budget only two days before his overthrow, including a 40 per cent cut in imports, together with a 30 per cent reduction in government capital spending. Significantly, the new leadership in Nigeria announced its own economic program which did not vary from that proposed by Shagari.

I know that it will be said that these reforms should have come much earlier but such statements fail to appreciate the position of Shagari in his first term of office. He was virtually drafted into the job; he did not come with any great personal authority and his party had only about one-third of the seats in the two Houses of the Parliament. His own election had to be settled in the courts because he did not completely meet the unique constitutional requirements necessary to overcome tribal and regional rivalry. Additionally, he had to wrestle with the rapid change on the world economic scene, particularly the oil slump which had detrimentally affected his country. There is no doubt that Shagari's achievements during his first term of office were modest, but it is significant that in contrast to his first term he had put down this positive program to which I have referred, to combat the accepted evils. He was and is a respected and idealistic man. It was clear that it was he as a person who was re -elected last August, rather than his party. Whilst he was carefully putting down his program to combat Nigeria's difficulties for the next four years, less patient men usurped it.

I conclude by reminding the Senate that the coup in Nigeria coincided with the second anniversary of the coup in Ghana in which Flight Lieutenant Jerry Rawlings brought an end to a similar democratic experiment. Ghana has since moved from poverty to destitution. One must be concerned for the future in Nigeria and as was said in an excellent article in the Times of 2 January this year:

If a man with a gun and a military following can impose his will on a nation when he disagrees with the actions of the elected government, then another man with a gun and a military following is entitled to replace the present ruler when things become too much for him in his turn. Major General Mohammed Buhari and his friends have much to answer for.
Sitting suspended from 1.22 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Attorney-General to the story which he appears to have given to Mr Gregory Hywood in this morning's Australian Financial Review. It is stated that the Government is prepared to release details of comments by the judge whom the Attorney met to discuss the allegations in the Age tapes and transcripts. Is it true that the Government will not do so until the Opposition tables any material which the Attorney- General claims it has in its possession regarding the judge? Has he spent the last several days attacking the Opposition for relying on this material and deploring in the strongest terms any suggestion that it should be made public? Does the withholding of information to which the Parliament is entitled unless action is taken which he has so strongly condemned highlight the double standards which the Attorney has applied throughout the current debate? Finally, will he without further delay make available to the Senate the aide-memoire and any other relevant material regarding the discussions he had with the judge on February 15 and 24?

—I do not know the source of Mr Hywood's story in the Australian Financial Review this morning. I do not propose, nor does the Government propose, to take any steps to make public any of the material in this matter, for all the reasons that have been stated with nauseous frequency in this place over the last two weeks.

—Would the Minister for Industry and Commerce draw upon his photographic memory to give me the latest labour force figures, which I believe were released today? I ask whether these figures are consistent with the Government's economic strategy and commitment to growth in employment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Georges for the kind way in which he phrased his question. I do not, in fact, have a photographic memory but I do have a bit of paper here with the figures written on it to which I will refer. I am, of course , aware of the latest figures. They confirm the Government's view that the labour market is continuing to recover. Seasonally adjusted employment increased by 21,000, the eighth increase in 10 months, which more than offsets the decline in January and reinforces the view that the January figures were nothing more than the traditional blip. Since April 1983 more than 140,000 new jobs have been created. On average, over the three months to February employment has grown by 60,700, while unemployment has fallen by 38,400. New jobs in the financial year to date number 116,200, with four months to go. That figure is already ahead of the Budget estimate of around 90,000 additional jobs during 1983-84. Unemployment is currently at 9.4 per cent, down from 9.5 per cent in January of this year.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course, in giving those figures I express some caution as to whether the recent rapid employment growth can be sustained. The Government has been encouraged by the figures in the last few months, but we again make the point that economic growth will have to be sustained. One might expect, in relation to the consideration of employment figures, that participation rates will increase as the recovery proceeds. Recent trends in employment have exceeded the most optimistic expectations of the Government. Taken with other indicators, the evidence is that the Government's economic policies are working. Nonetheless, I reiterate that we must approach these figures not only with optimism but also with caution. It is the Government's belief that the recovery can be sustained and that will have a steady effect on reducing unemployment and increasing the number of new jobs available in the community. We look forward to that happening . Of course, the elements of the Government's economic policy have to be kept in place if that is to happen and that, of course, concerns many areas of the economy outside the area of government administration. We are very pleased with the figures and we look forward to a greater improvement in later months this year.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Attorney-General. I ask whether he is aware of the views expressed by Dr Paul Gerber, a former Reader in Law at Queensland University, on this morning's AM program. Referring to the standards expected of judges, Dr Gerber said:

QUESTION.PARA: Now, true it is, they are made of flesh and blood, but once they take judicial office they assume a degree of probity rightly so, I think, which does not entitle them to the kind of eccentricities which are revealed in these tapes.

I ask the Attorney: Does he agree with the view of Dr Gerber, who, I believe, accurately reflects the feeling of community repugnance and concern at the conduct of the kind alleged on the part of the judge in the Age tapes and transcripts?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the views of Dr Gerber, as expressed on AM this morning, so far as behaviour falling short of constitutional misbehaviour is concerned. I do not share those views. I take the view that judges, like everybody else, are entitled to their privacy, and that extends to enabling them , in circumstances where they are entitled to rely on privacy, to blow off steam or in other ways use language that might well be inappropriate in a public context, where there could be expected to be some damage to the reputation of the institution of which they are members. Private behaviour is a very different thing from public behaviour. Where that private behaviour does not bear upon their capacity or integrity in the performance of their judicial functions or does not constitute the kind of criminal misbehaviour such as would clearly be inappropriate for continued membership of the Bench, I think private behaviour should remain just that and should be recognised as such by this Parliament.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I refer the Attorney-General to the fact that I was not talking about those aspects of the conversations which might be said to be blowing off steam. I was referring to those aspects which relate to external conduct being discussed by the judge.

—I do not think anybody, least of all Dr Gerber, is entitled to make any assumptions at all about what conduct might have occurred on the basis of the material in those tapes which, as we all know, is and remains totally unauthenticated and certainly has not been the subject of any admissions as to it having occurred by the judge in question.

—Can the Minister for Veterans' Affairs clear up the apparent confusion amongst some repatriation beneficiaries regarding their treatment entitlements now that Medicare has been introduced? Have any repatriation beneficiaries, including war widows, been disadvantaged in respect of those treatment entitlements following Medicare's introduction?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Contrary to a lot of misunderstanding by certain medicos and their associations, treatment entitlements for repatriation beneficiaries have not changed in any respect at all as a result of the introduction of Medicare. Repatriation beneficiaries have gained an advantage as a result of Medicare in that they are now free to choose between the two systems at any time for their treatment needs. In other words, a veteran living a considerable distance away from a repatriation general hospital who is entitled to treatment is able now to go to a public hospital of his or her choice. The Government still accepts the financial responsibility. I take advantage of Senator Giles's question to refute the blatant untruth that veterans now need to take out private insurance in order to receive their previous entitlements. That has created a great deal of confusion and has allowed a number of medical associations to suggest in advertisements in the newspapers that veterans' entitlements have changed. Of course, that is not the case at all. The entitlements are unchanged and there is no need for veterans to take private insurance to preserve their existing entitlements.

ANSWER.PARA: Many veterans are likely to find this freedom of choice to use Medicare or their repatriation entitlements for their treatment to be a very good change, and a very valuable choice. That is particularly likely to apply to veterans who live in country areas or a fair distance from repatriation hospitals. For example, some figures which came to my office within the last few days show that nationally 45 per cent of the Department's treatment population live in rural areas and a further 34 per cent in metropolitan areas, most of them more than 10 kilometres from the nearest repatriation general hospital. In New South Wales the respective figures are 50 per cent and 35 per cent, in Victoria 44 per cent and 38 per cent and in Queensland 55 per cent and 23 per cent. The proportion is somewhat lower in the other mainland States. I reiterate that the decision as to which system repatriation beneficiaries want to use, Medicare or the repatriation system, is now a choice for them to make personally.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PAPER CURRENCY FOR THE VISUALLY IMPAIRED

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware that there is no adequate means for over 100,000 people in Australia with limited sight to distinguish the difference of denomination between Australian bank notes and that, as a result, they are forced into the demeaning position of having to rely on persons with whom they are conducting financial transactions to get the correct change? Is the Minister also aware that in countries such as Switzerland , Israel and the Netherlands bank notes are also distinguishable to the blind by raised markings on the notes and to those of limited vision by very conspicuous numbering? With your indulgence, Mr President, and for the interest of the Senate, I exhibit a Dutch bank note with its touch sensitive indications and its prominent numbering which show that it is a 25 guilder note. Is the Minister considering the long overdue redesign of Australian bank notes? If so, and in view of the previous Government's conspicuous and consistent ignoring of this issue, will he consider the introduction in Australia of similar raised markings , either embossed on the bank notes or provided by different numbers of metallic strips, to enable those with limited sight to distinguish more easily and reliably between the notes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that some 100,000 people or thereabouts are sight impaired to the point that they probably would not be able to distinguish between notes of different denominations, at least if they were the same size. Therefore, the question that Senator Mason has raised is quite important to quite a significant number of people. I have been advised by the Treasurer that the notes used by the Netherlands, among other countries to which Senator Mason referred, are satisfactory when new, but that when they have been in circulation for some time the dots tend to be erased and other distortions take place. This could even add to the confusion when they are severely worn. The present view, I understand, is that the most practical and foolproof device currently available is to have notes of different sizes for different denominations, which has been the Australian practice for some time anyway.

ANSWER.PARA: The United States, of course, has notes not only all the same size but also all the same colour, regardless of denomination. However, the United States Bureau of Engraving has investigated various methods of affording assistance to the blind. A recent survey in the United States of some 22 organisations concerned with the blind resulted in no group responding in favour of special tactile markings on currency to assist them and a significant proportion, I understand, opposed the use of Braille-type markings.

The Reserve Bank of Australia is not proposing to incorporate markings on Australian notes at this stage. But the bank is, of course, sympathetic to the problems of the visually impaired and, as such, will carefully monitor technical developments in this area of note differentiation. I will pass on Senator Mason' s request to the Treasurer to ensure that, when a technically feasible method of identifying with some certainty notes of varying denominations is developed, it is implemented as speedily as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate: Is the Government aware that the Commonwealth heads of government at their meeting in Jamaica in 1975 decided that the second Monday in March each year would be designated as Commonwealth Day? As the Parliament will not be sitting on 12 March, will the Leader of the Government in the Senate consider making an appropriate statement supporting the Commonwealth's aims and ideals before the Parliament adjourns?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is aware about Commonwealth Day and the decision made in the 1971 declaration of Commonwealth principles. Rather than make a statement at some length later in the course of this most important session of the Parliament which has devoted itself to so many constructive issues, I propose to answer Senator Elstob's question at some length. The present Government values the contribution which the Commonwealth makes to upholding human dignity and equality, to combatting racial prejudice and to assisting smaller States. The Commonwealth association is based on consultation and co- operation. Consultation occurs on a number of levels. First, the two-yearly heads of government meetings provide a useful facility for open and frank discussion with over one-quarter of the world's leaders. Equally importantly, they provide an opportunity for Commonwealth leaders to meet and get to know each other in an informal atmosphere.

ANSWER.PARA: I should also mention the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association which provides a forum for discussion and consultation for parliamentarians throughout the world. There is also a web of valuable non-Commonwealth professional consultation in the Commonwealth which underpins the official Commonwealth activities. The Commonwealth, through programs such as the Commonwealth Fund for Technical Co-operation, provides much needed assistance to the developing country members of the Commonwealth. An essential element of these programs is mutual assistance whereby all members, including the developing country members, contribute to the well being of other members. This Government welcomes the expansion of the activity of the Commonwealth secretariat in the areas of manpower development, human rights, employment and labour, functional co- operation and women's affairs. The Government is aware of the high regard that many of our neighbours in the Pacific, particularly the islands states, ascribe to the Commonwealth links. We will be pursuing a constructive and pragmatic approach to enhancing consultation and co-operation within the Commonwealth. We are, as I said at the beginning, aware of what happened in 1971, and this is an appropriate question to be directed to a Minister of this Government. The answer which I have given reflects the Government's concern about the matters raised by Senator Elstob.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Attorney-General whether he was correctly quoted in the Sydney Morning Herald on 6 April last year as follows:

QUESTION.PARA: One of my very real idols in politics remains, surprisingly enough you might think, Lionel Murphy whose style was very far from being that of a mellow reflective pragmatist.
I ask him whether he also recalls writing in the publication Labor: Directions for the Eighties:
The Murphy years of marvellous, lasting, recognised achievement.
Does the Attorney-General still hold these views about Mr Justice Murphy? Does he accept the description of himself as being a protege of Mr Justice Murphy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do indeed still hold the views ascribed to me by Senator Lewis which I believe were accurately quoted by the Sydney Morning Herald. I have in front of me the whole quotation-it goes for about a page and a half-from the Labor: Directions for the Eighties chapter.
—Read it all out.

—I might just read it all out for the benefit of the Senate because I think it puts some of the allegations presently being made in public about former Senator Murphy in a little better context. It says:

ANSWER.PARA: In office between 1972 and 1975, the Labor government set about implementing- under the direction of its impetuous, but extraordinary imaginative, energetic and effective Attorney-General, Lionel Murphy, a set of law and justice programs , which, while not especially systematic, were sane, humane, civilised and far- reaching.

Being accustomed to the sonorous and reactionary banalities usually uttered by lawyers of stations high and low, inside the Labor movement as well as outside it, very few people had, before Murphy, appreciated the potential for sweeping and radical social change locked away in the Attorney-General's portfolio. Murphy changed all that. The Family Law Act revolutionised the law of divorce and matrimonial relations. The Racial Discrimination and Queensland Discriminatory Laws Acts gave racial and national minorities important new tools with which to combat discrimination in law and practice. The Human Rights Bill, had it survived the hostile environment of the Senate, would have provided powerful tools for challenging infringements of fundamental liberties across the whole spectrum of political and civil rights. The Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act (together with the Ombudsman Bill, before parliament the day it was dissolved) created a whole new machinery for remedying bureaucratic maladministration. Restrictions on public servants' free speech were abolished and moves were set in train for full-scale freedom of information legislation. Appeals to the Privy Council from the High Court were finally abolished. Customs administration was changed so as to relax almost completely federal censorship of films and publications. Amendments to the Electoral Act were passed to provide for equality of voting power. The Australian Legal Aid Office was established, making the right to representation for the first time a reality to thousands of Australians. The Australian Law Reform Commission was set up as a dynamic and innovative agency for on-going reform. Murphy-and Whitlam, whose own personal contribution to Labor's law reform programs should never be underestimated-encouraged the testing of Commonwealth constitutional power to its fullest limits, not only in the law and justice matters within his own immediate domain, but also in the measures promoted by departments dealing with economic management, commercial regulation, environmental and resource management and social welfare. These were years of breathless and unparalleled activity. The changes they wrought were always progressive and usually fundamental, and their full impact is in most instances just beginning to be felt and understood.
There is one more paragraph, Mr President, and I shall finish with this:

The Murphy years had about them all the exhilaration, and a good deal of the danger, of a downhill sleigh ride. They were not a time for legal wowsers. Public opinion, in the Murphy philosophy, was there to be led, not cautiously and nervously followed a step at a time. It could all have gone disastrously wrong: become a succession of A.S.I.O. raids-entirely defensible in principle, but conceived in a hurry, embraced with excitement, executed with vigour-and repented at leisure. But somehow it all came together. The Murphy years-
to use Senator Lewis's quotation, selectively extracted-
were years of marvellous, lasting, recognised achievement. As a demonstration of the art of the possible in government, they provide a model, and a touchstone, for any Labor reformer of the future.

The prose is somewhat purple, I readily acknowledge. This was in my youth, three or four years ago. But I would be inclined to be equally graphic in my descriptions of Mr Justice Murphy's role on the bench since his elevation there. Indeed, there is a parcelful of quotations from newspapers in recent days-John Slee in the Sydney Morning Herald a couple of days ago, and Bill Goff in the Australian this morning-which I think properly recognise the character of Mr Justice Murphy's achievement since his elevation to the Bench and properly point to the way in which so many lawyers, of stations high and low and of various political hues, have come to eat their words about his quality as a lawyer. I have no regrets at all about having expressed my admiration in the past for Mr Justice Murphy. I have no hesitation in expressing my respect and admiration for him now.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Arising out of the Attorney- General's answer, I ask whether, during those years in which Senator Murphy was Attorney-General, the current Attorney-General worked for Senator Murphy, and, if so, for what period and in what capacity?

—It is a question that I answered yesterday, but I appreciate that Senator Lewis's memory these days is somewhat fading. I worked as a consultant for the Attorney-General, and more particularly for the Attorney -General's Department, from 1973 to the end of 1975. I was employed to work on matters related to the racial discrimination legislation and the Human Rights Bill. That involved my coming to Canberra never more than one day a week; in fact, rather less than that over that entire period. During that time I worked out of the Department rather than the ministerial office, although there were, of course, a number of conferences involved in dealing with and developing that legislation with the Minister. As I said yesterday, I did not have any role in day to day matters of the administration of the portfolio and certainly had no role, as I also said yesterday, in relation to the particular matter which has been the subject of so much enthusiastic and misguided attention in this Parliament.

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. The log hauling industry in Tasmania is urging the State Government to allow log road-trains on Tasmanian roads. There is already deep public concern about the dangers of present log trucks, as many of the roads in Tasmania are unsuitable for such heavy traffic. Has there been any evaluation of the cost to the taxpayer of providing the additional cost of building and maintaining roads for such use as log road-trains or of the impact upon the tourist industry in Tasmania?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided me with a number of briefs, including one on the problems of log truck operations in Tasmania. It is clear from reading that brief that there are problems of excessive speed, excessive loads and excessive traffic which beset many of the citizens in various parts of Tasmania. Nevertheless, the brief indicates that the responsibility for this lies largely in the State Government's area. No restriction is placed upon the log trucks when they are travelling on private roads, but when they go on to public highways and the public road system the State Government gives permits and it provides for some control of the use of the public road system. However, it must be said that there is abundant evidence that this creates a feeling on the part of many private motorists and the public generally of a degree of intimidation and concern at the extent to which these permits have been granted in the past.

ANSWER.PARA: The most that the Federal Government could do would be to draw the attention of the State Minister for Transport to the nature of the problem. We recognise that most of the roads that are being used by the log trucks were not constructed for such heavy traffic or for the quantity of traffic movements. Consequently, that creates difficulties with reconstruction of the road system. One would have thought that a State government worthy of its name would be insisting that a great proportion of the logs used for proper purposes in our economy be handled by the railway system. If the State Government were to insist that more of them be carried on the railway system, that would provide much needed revenue and such traffic therefore would not be a problem to the average motorist using the road system, which is clearly being excessively used by log trucks.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Attorney-General whether he recalls telling the Senate on Tuesday, when asked about possible conflict of interest which might have arisen in his dealings with the judge referred to in the Age tapes:

QUESTION.PARA: No, there is no foundation on which any reasonable person could possibly come to the conclusion that there is any conflict of interest in this matter.
Does he still stand by that answer? If he does, what sort of personal or professional relationship could or would give rise to a conflict of interest?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I stand by that answer. I will leave the development and refinement of hypotheses to others.

—My question is addressed to the Attorney-General. Is it a fact that a former Queensland Special Branch policeman, Don Lane, when contesting the 1972 State election for his seat of Merthyr, discovered by some dubious means that a postal vote cast overseas by the late Mr Justice Douglas had gone to his Australian Labor Party opponent, Mr Dennis Pie, and that Mr Lane then made his information available to the Queensland Premier? Is it also a fact that the same Mr Justice Douglas was later to be politically bulldozed out of contention for the position of Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of Queensland, a position for which he was not only qualified but also for which he was next in line in the traditional terms of seniority with the support of the legal profession in that State? Can the Attorney-General verify whether this is the same Don Lane who is currently engaging in another attack on the judiciary as the Minister for Transport in the Queensland Government?
—Before the Attorney-General answers the question, I draw his attention in the first instance to standing order 418. I call the Attorney- General.

—Thank you, Mr President, I have no direct personal knowledge of the matters to which Senator Jones has referred but I am informed that it is a matter of some notoriety in Queensland that Mr Don Lane is indeed the same Mr Don Lane as the present Minister-

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I wish to raise two points. The first is that I was curious from the formation of the question as to in what way it impacted on matters which were within the ministerial responsibility of the Attorney-General. The second point is that, the question having been asked, the Attorney-General said that he had no personal knowledge of it. I assume that he was also saying that his Department has no role or has provided no information for him. On that basis, I suggest that there is no ground for a question to be asked of the Attorney on that matter.

—I wish to speak to the point of order, Mr President. Of course, it is not the case that direct personal knowledge of matters has ever been a requirement for an ability to answer questions technically in this place. That cannot possibly be a ground for objection. As to the foundation for the question more generally, clearly it goes very directly to the credit of Mr Lane in his current attack on a member of the judiciary, an attack which was directly motivated by and related to events in this place and to matters which are presently the subject of debate in this place. As such, it is perfectly appropriate that the Parliament should have the benefit of such knowledge as I possess about the character of this man who is so willing to assassinate the character of others.

—Order! I will allow the Minister to develop his answer but I remind him, of course, that there is a distinction between a question and a debate. I suggest that the Minister bear that in mind when he is answering the question.
—I am informed that the Mr Lane in question, good McCarthyist zealot that he is, did breach-
—Order! The Minister will withdraw that remark because it is in breach of standing order 418.

—I will withdraw it. He did breach the hallowed rule that every man's vote is secret and he did inform the Premier of Queensland that the late Mr Justice Douglas was a Labor supporter. Of course, the Queensland Premier , with his usual approach to these matters-I hesitate to use the expression ' bigotry'-used this information to prevent this distinguished judge from becoming the Chief Judge of the Supreme Court of Queensland, a position for which he not only was eminently qualified but also he was next in line in the traditional terms of seniority and had been supported by the legal profession. It is evident that there is much else that I could say but, on looking at my notes, I see that it comes within the character of debating material rather than giving further information to the Senate. I will save that up for a more appropriate occasion, but I think the point is clear.

—I refer the Attorney-General to the Sala case and ask him: Why was Mr Ramon Sala released from custody and his passport returned when there was an outstanding inquiry with Interpol as to the bona fides of that passport? In view of the fact that the Interpol report confirming the suspected forgery was received only days after Sala's departure from the country, does the Attorney agree that former Senator Murphy was clearly in error in ordering Sala' s release and the return of his passport?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already answered this question at some length in various ways. I do not believe that he was in error, for the reasons I gave before. One might take the view that it is proper to keep people cooling their heels in gaol under cover of a deportation order when they have already been dealt with by the courts of the country on all outstanding charges, as was the case with this gentleman. One might think it appropriate to keep a person in gaol cooling his heels because of the possibility that the police might get around at some stage to charging that person with another offence. The police on this occasion had had the passport in question for some weeks and had had an opportunity to check out such suspicions as they had in relation to it. The Interpol response came, I am informed, six days after the man was released from gaol and had left the country. From my knowledge of the files and the events at the time, I do not think anybody had any reason to anticipate just when the Interpol reply would have been received at the time Mr Sala was released.

ANSWER.PARA: I repeat: The principle in issue here is the propriety and legitimacy in the Australian system of criminal justice of keeping people in gaol with their freedom denied, for the reason-the only reason-of enabling police inquiries to take place. That is simply not a principle which has hitherto been regarded as acceptable in the conduct of our criminal justice system whether for Australian citizens, residents, tourists or anybody else. Although there may be different views about the decision that was made-certainly, different views were taken at the time-there is no way in which the judgment of the then Minister can, I believe, be properly called into question.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Was there any knowledge in the Attorney-General's Department as to the likely contents or the contents of the Interpol report prior to its being formally lodged with the Department?

—I have no reason whatsoever to believe that there was any advance knowledge of the likely content of the Interpol report. The information available to me was that the report was received six days later. I presume it was telexed, vocadexed, telegrammed or transmitted in some other way, but I do not know. I will find out and give the honourable senator better and further particulars in that respect. Certainly, there is no reason to believe that anyone had the hard information in question other than a mere suspicion of something being the case at that stage.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs. Has there been an increase in Federal Government spending on education in New South Wales this year? What percentage of non-government schools in New South Wales have been advantaged by the new Federal funding arrangements for education? Have any New South Wales non-government schools been seriously disadvantaged by these new financial arrangements?

—Yes, there has been an increase in funding both for government and non-government schools in New South Wales. The Government is providing over $ 237m for non-government schools in New South Wales in 1984, which represents an increase in real terms of over $4m on what was provided in 1983. In terms of capital projects, since 5 March 1983 the following have been approved: Three new schools projects totalling $2,630,700, 11 projects for new places in existing schools totalling $3,969,900, 19 major projects for improved facilities, 62 minor projects for improved facilities and 26 library projects. With respect to the percentage of schools that have received improvements, I am advised that 89 per cent of all non-government schools-that is, 683 schools-will receive increased grants in 1984. Only 15 schools in New South Wales will have their recurrent grants reduced and these schools will still receive over $4.7m from the Commonwealth in 1984 and thus cannot be said to have had their operation seriously affected.

—My question is directed to the Attorney-General. Did Mr Menzies in his investigation into the Sala case receive information that an attempt was made to bribe police officers handling the case? If so, did Mr Menzies find the allegation proved? If that is the case, is any action planned against any person or persons?

—One of the elements in the oceans of scuttlebutt which surround this matter, for reasons which one can only guess at, was that some attempt was made to bribe a police officer at one stage of the proceedings. The allegation, such as it is, is that the bribe offer was made indirectly and at a very low level. Certainly, there is no question of involving senior departmental officers, let alone the Ministers at the time. Reports were made by the police officer in question, as I recall from Mr Menzies' finding. The senior police officers given the job of investigating the matter found that there was no basis on which any further action could then properly be taken. Mr Menzies in his recent report tracked back over this territory and found no evidence whatsoever to justify his concluding that there had been such a bribe offer or that anything required further police-type investigation in this respect. So there would not appear to be any foundation whatever for the currency that is being given to this aspect of the matter.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Health aware that a French pharmaceutical company has been granted permission to import into Australia a flu vaccine known as vaxigrip? Is it also a fact that the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories has built up very considerable facilities and expertise for the production of sufficient vaccine to meet the surges and variability of strains of influenza which hit Australia from time to time? Does the Minister agree that the introduction of French vaccine puts the commercial viability of CSL in jeopardy, given the fact that maintenance of a state of readiness and, indeed, overproduction is required if this national organisation is to guard against epidemics of new strains of flu? Will the Minister consult with his colleagues with a view to preventing this serious threat to this facility so important to the health of all Australians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that an application for the marketing of vaxigrip, which is a French-produced flu vaccine, was considered by the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee in July 1983. The Committee, which comprises experts in the fields of pharmacy, pharmacology and clinical medicine, advises the Minister for Health on the suitability of imported drugs for marketing in Australia. It is that Committee's task to be satisfied that, on the evidence available, the therapeutic substance is acceptable on the grounds of quality, safety and efficacy. Marketing approval was given by the Director-General of Health who, in accordance with the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations, may refuse to grant the application in respect of the substance only for reasons related to quality, safety and efficacy. No other consideration can be taken into account in this decision.

ANSWER.PARA: The charter of the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories requires it to conduct its business in a manner which is commercially viable. I understand that the efficacy of production of influenza vaccine by the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories is such that it has recently been able to reduce the price of the vaccine. The question the honourable senator has raised suggests that the production of influenza vaccine by the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories may be of special national interest. I advise honourable senators that over a period of some years successive Ministers have determined that a level of reserve stocks of influenza vaccine should be maintained at CSL in order to meet any anticipated demand caused by epidemics. The Government reimburses CSL for the maintenance of such stocks. The Minister for Health has recently received a submission from the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories on this question, which his Department is examining. The Minister has assured me that he will give full consideration to the options available.

I will certainly convey to the Minister the concerns expressed by Senator Tate. As all honourable senators I am sure are aware, the Government wishes to see the development of high technology skills in the Australian economy. The production of vaccine and medical research in general offers great scope for the encouragement of these skills and processes. The Government is, therefore, closely interested in this matter, not only from the public health point of view , important as that is, but also to ensure that no steps are taken which may adversely affect the ability of Australian companies such as CSL to acquire new advanced technology capability.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Attorney-General, follows the answer he gave to the question from Senator Crichton-Browne about the Sala case. Accepting the explanation he gave of the reasons for the then Attorney- General's release of Mr Sala on the basis that there was no reason for his liberty to be taken from him, why did the then Attorney-General order the return of the passport prior to receipt of the Interpol report which covered its status ? That seems to be a quite separate issue and I ask the Attorney to address himself to that.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a separate issue and it is one that I addressed in answer at some length to Senator Hill, if Senator Chaney was not listening, just a couple of days ago. To the extent that it is possible to reconstruct what occurred, because people's memories are less than sensationally precise after a 10-year period, it seems clear that two separate factors were at work here. One was the routine bureaucratic consideration that deportees, if they seek a capacity to leave the country voluntarily, paying their own way, are very often allowed to do so, if not actually encouraged to do so, in the interests of the Australian taxpayers and also in the interests of making easier some of the bureaucratic difficulties associated with deportation. Those difficulties were present here, given the problems it appeared were occurring in getting the appropriate entry papers from Spain, which is the only place to which the person could go if his French passport was not given back to him.

ANSWER.PARA: The second matter that was clearly in circulation as a relevant consideration, because it had been the subject of a detailed psychiatric report to the court at the time of the sentence for the offences for which the man was convicted, and is part of people's recollection of the case, although it is not carefully or fully documented in the files, is the consideration that the person was claiming to be a political exile; someone who had suffered punishment for various sins at the hands of Franco's regime; someone who had a conviction outstanding against him for failing to report for military service; someone who had not only suffered formal punishment in the sense of deprivation of liberty but also claimed to have been cruelly physically treated in the way that I described the other day.

Under those circumstances one can readily imagine a Minister, and this is the former Minister's recollection, taking that into account as a further consideration for allowing the man to take a passport, particularly since the Department of Foreign Affairs had raised no objection on the ground of possible implications for foreign relations if the passport proved to be false. Under those circumstances one can readily imagine the Minister taking the view that that in itself was excellent reason for allowing the person to leave voluntarily rather than be deported. I make the point, as I did yesterday, that the only written representation that is on file is a telegram from the solicitors for the man in question, which refers specifically to deportation rather than to seeking the return of the person's passport.

I really believe, with the utmost respect, that the details of this matter have been plumbed with quite extraordinary and irrelevant and unnecessary fervour by the Opposition on this occasion. There is very little more to say about the merits of the particular case. They seemed to me, as they did to my senior officer, to be very obvious indeed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. It is not absolutely clear to me from that reply but I have drawn the inference that information was known to the Minister and/or his Department at that time that there was a possiblity that the passport was not valid, or was forged or fraudulent. Is that so?

—There is no doubt that it was the opinion of several police officers-I cannot recall how many-some officers in the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and at least one officer in the Attorney-General' s Department, that the passport was probably invalid, although nobody had the proof and the police did not seem to carry their beliefs to the point of being willing to charge the man. There was certainly the view that that was possibly the case, but against that were the competing considerations I have been endeavouring to point out at some length which made the decision one that perhaps other Ministers might not have made with equal confidence. There were obviously considerations that had to be balanced. One can disagree with the decision, as a number of departmental officers obviously did, without in any way taking the view that there was any impropriety or worse involved in the making of that decision. That is clearly Mr Menzies's conclusion and that is a conclusion which I share, having seen the files, his report and his accounts of witness interviews and having myself spoken to the former Minister.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs seen the publication called New Times, published by the Australian League of Rights, and the material published in it, particularly addressing questions of human rights, racial equality and the right to no discrimination on the grounds of sex? Is he aware that such rights regularly come under attack from the Australian League of Rights? In the light of this Government's commitment to policies and legislation supporting human rights, can the Minister make clear what is this Government's attitude to these attacks?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I answer this question also in my own right as Attorney- General because there are questions of human rights and racial discrimination legislation here involved. I have seen the issue of New Times to which Senator Crowley refers. Regrettably it is the case that the League of Rights remains an organisation dedicated to racial intolerance, political and religious obscurantism and voodoo economics. It sustains a vicious line of anti-semitism, supports racially unjust societies, particularly South Africa, and projects a perception of world affairs which would be laughable were it not so anti-human and calculated to arouse division and hatred. I will give the Senate examples. The January/February issues of New Times, the League's organ in Australia, as Senator Crowley said, contains a series of quite odious anti-semitic articles. I think the following quotations convey the general flavour:

ANSWER.PARA: 'Judiaism is implacably anti-Christian and it is by definition an Incarnate Lie ;'

'Mr Michel Fribourg, who controls 90 per cent of U.S.A. grain and is the agent for all U.S.A. grain sales to the Soviet, is one of those Zionist Jews who have permanent luxury residences in the Soviet and who come and go as they like;'

'One of the major factors of the American Christian scene is the growing number of Christians who are starting to reject the widely held belief that the people known today as Jews are God's Chosen People . . . If only those nations which accept the Jewish Chosen Race dogma can prosper, why then has the U.S.A. been in a state of decline?'

There is a considerable degree more of contemptible material of this kind in the publication. It does, therefore, come as a great surprise and a disappointment to me and to the Minister for Foreign Affairs that the same issue of this disreputable publication publishes a message of greeting from Senator Bjelke- Petersen to an International League of Rights seminar being held in Canada. In a message the good senator states:
the League of Rights stands for many good principles, one of which is of course , supporting so strongly State Rights.

One trusts that Senator Bjelke-Petersen's association with this organisation represents simply poor judgment on her behalf and a failure to really appreciate what the organisation does stand for rather than support for its anti-human principles. If this is the case, one would hope that she might be now prepared to dissociate herself publicly from the organisation and to repudiate the message of support which she has sent to it. If she does not do so, one might hope that certainly the Leader of the Opposition and perhaps even the Leader of the National Party might be prepared to dissociate themselves and their parties from that organisation.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have done it before. We have done that many times.

—Well, it might be time to do it again, given that it is the January/February 1984 issue of this particular publication that we are now talking about and still this Opposition and its members are on record as supporting the organisation. I mention finally--
—I raise a point of order.
—Is this a point of order?
—Yes.
—The honourable senator can get up and make a personal explanation.

—No, it is a point of order. I find it personally offensive to me, as the only Jewish member of this Senate, to have Senator Evans saying that the Opposition associates itself with that organisation. I find it personally offensive and ask you, Mr President, to ask the honourable senator to withdraw that remark.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—I am indebted to Senator Baume for his contribution to this debate and I would welcome other such contributions after I have sat down. It might help establish the proper situation. I mention finally--

—I raise a point of order. I suggest that this is a general reflection on the Opposition. I strongly object to those comments as a long term enemy of that organisation. I ask that the honourable senator be made to withdraw the remark.
—Order! Senator Missen has asked for a withdrawal on the ground that it is personally offensive to him. Under standing order 418 I therefore ask you to withdraw.
—I am very willing to make--

—I raise a point of order. I think this is an important point of order and it is something that I have asked for for a long time. If Senator Missen is to have the capacity to ask for a withdrawal of a statement made on this side which referred collectively to the Opposition, that is a great change from the practice in this place in the past. Senator Sir John Carrick, the former Leader of the Government in the Senate, almost daily used the technique of blackguarding people collectively without anyone having the capacity to seek withdrawal. I would agree very much if we had a standing order which prevented that sort of behaviour, but, in the past, Presidents in this place have consistently ruled that collective impressions were not the subject of this standing order.
—The advice given to me is that these sorts of objections, when taken, have been allowed in the past.
—When?

—That is the advice given to me. I am advised that in ruling that way I am carrying out past practice. However, I agree that it is a matter that needs to be looked at and I certainly will look at it. Meanwhile, Senator Missen has asked for a withdrawal and I would therefore ask the Minister, under standing order 418, to withdraw his remarks.

—I certainly withdraw any suggestion of Senator Missen in any way giving aid or comfort to this. Indeed, I doubt that more than a handful of members on the other side of this chamber would in fact subscribe to the values that I have here described. I mention finally, in answer to Senator Crowley--
—Which handful? Come on-otherwise we are all involved.

—That is up to the honourable senator. The final point I make, since Senator Crowley asked what the Government is doing about this sort of stuff, is simply this: The whole question of race hatred propaganda, which is obviously a very difficult and a very sensitive one raising the whole question of balancing rights of free speech on the one hand against the legitimate interests of minorities against this sort of scurrilous material on the other, has been the subject of a recent report from the Human Rights Commission and is now the subject of active consideration by a human rights task force that I have established within my Department which has called for and received a number of submissions from the public and which I hope will be in a position to suggest possible legislation later this year as part of a review that is going on of the whole Racial Discrimination Act.
—As a Liberal senator I dissociate myself entirely from the remarks attributed to the Opposition. I make that statement only because I happen to be the next senator called by the President.
—Order! The honourable senator will ask his question.

—My question is addressed to the Attorney-General. There has been reference today and on earlier occasions this week in Question Time to the Menzies report into the handling of the Sala case. Will the Attorney-General forthwith table the report?

—No, I will not forthwith table that report or anything else . What I will do is what I am doing, that is, giving the matter consideration and preparing a Cabinet submission for consideration by the Government next week . As I have made perfectly clear by my willingness to give a great deal of detail in answers to questions about the Sala matter, I believe there is much in the report that could quite properly and indeed could quite helpfully be put on the public record. The difficulty, as always with this kind of report, embodying , as it does, references to internal departmental files and a number of allegations that are made by particular individuals about things that they believe may or may not have been the case, is that a number of individuals are named in circumstances where it is perfectly clear, when one looks at the evidence, that the material was quite unjustified in relation to them. So one has this dilemma, this difficulty, about people's names being trailed around publicly in circumstances where, ultimately, the material is not such as to justify that. It is that sort of question which is making difficult the instant answer to what is quite a reasonable request that has been made by the Opposition for the tabling of this report. It is against that background that I am genuinely trying to work out what it is that can be quite properly put on the public record without giving rise to these other difficulties.

—I ask a supplementary question. Will the Attorney-General be able, having already had 48 hours notice of that question, to give a firm answer to the remaining matter for consideration, that is, the sanitising of names, before the Senate rises today?
—No.
—Before I call the next question I must point out that there have been nine questions from members of the Opposition today and five supplementary questions.

—My question, which is on jobs and the economy and is of interest to the Australian people, is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. As the first meeting of the China/Australia iron and steel industry joint study group is scheduled to be held in Peking in the first week of April, can the Minister give the Senate any further information about the general initiative on the steel industry taken by the Prime Minister when he was in China recently?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is scepticism from people who were in government for seven years and who took no initiatives on anything in relation to Australian industry . I expect that to last, because it was the most deplorable seven years in the history of this country, when numerous opportunities were lost. If any evidence is required of that, it can be found in the comments of the former Prime Minister, Mr Malcolm Fraser, on the Science Show a week ago, when he put forward a few ideas about Australian industry and was asked: 'Why didn't you do something about this when you were in government?' He said: 'It would have been a good idea if I had thought of it eight years ago'. That is the fairest description we can get of the performance of the Liberal Party in respect of industry policy when it was in government for those seven years.

ANSWER.PARA: Insofar as the particulars of the question are concerned, the Prime Minister, when he was in China, took an initiative in opening up discussions with the Chinese Government about the possibility of having some integrated mechanisms in relation to the steel industry in Australia and the steel industry in China. That was an initiative taken at the political level. When he got back to Australia he discussed that matter-indeed, I have discussed that matter-with representatives of the Australian steel industry and the Australian iron ore industry. There are currently two Australian officials in China discussing with Chinese Government officials the follow-up to the Prime Minister's visit and the political initiative which was taken. It is the view of this Government that no opportunities should remain unexplored in terms of developing Australia's industry and in terms of developing our export capacity. We do not pretend for a moment that any one, or all, of these initiatives will succeed. But in the view of this Government none of them should be left unexplored. Therefore, officials are in China at present having discussions with Chinese officials. The reports from those officials are that there is a lot of interest at the official level in the political discussions which were undertaken between our Prime Minister and the Premier of China in relation to this question.

The question of most importance and relevance which has been discussed is the time framework for the implementation of any possible future arrangements of benefit to both countries. It has been agreed, as I understand it, that there can be an increase in technological exchanges on a commercial basis between the two countries in the immediate future and that later there can be further discussions relating to the export of the Australian finished product and, more particularly, the export to China of Australian iron ore. The joint study group will meet in China in the first week of April. I am happy to say that the Chinese Minister for Metallurgical Industry, Li Dongye, will be visiting Australia in the near future. He has accepted an invitation which has been sent to him to visit Australia to have discussions with the Australian Government and the Australian steel industry and we believe he will visit Australia in May. We look forward to that visit. As I said, all these opportunities are being explored. Again, in this area there is room for cautious optimism that benefits will be brought to the Australian iron and steel industry, to the community as a whole and to the Australian-China relationship as a result of the efforts which have already been undertaken.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I welcome the fact that during Question Time the Leader of the Government in the Senate ( Senator Button) responded to a question about the Commonwealth in very positive terms and acknowledged the fact that it is Commonwealth Day next Monday. On behalf of the Opposition, I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a brief statement in similar terms expressing the Opposition's support for the Commonwealth, and its view that in 1984 it remains an important body which should have the support of this Parliament and of all parties in the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

Mr President, next Monday is Commonwealth Day. On March 12th, the peoples of an extraordinary diverse group of nations dotted round the globe will commemorate the foundation and ongoing work of the Commonwealth of Nations. The Commonwealth is unique in form and function amongst world bodies. In a world filled with tension and the threat of the ultimate armed conflict we need the Commonwealth. We need the dialogue it promotes and the understanding which results.

Australia has played an important part in the work of the Commonwealth. We have contributed to its development as an effective international forum. The Regional heads of government meeting is an Australian initiative. Australians have come to recognise that our future is bound up with that of the Pacific Region. The ever increasing trade amongst nations of the region underlines that. The opportunity for the Leaders of Pacific Commonwealth nations to exchange views freely is one which we must continue to take advantage of.

In a broader context, the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meetings fill an equally important function. The outstanding success of the Melbourne CHOGM in 1981 gave all Australians added insight into the importance of the Commonwealth. Australia's own stature and influence in the world would be smaller if the Commonwealth did not exist or if we failed to continue to play an active part in its work. With some 75 per cent of the Commonwealth composed of Asian and African nations our good relations with the countries of those regions would be less well advanced. We would be denied a major line of communication with significant portions of the Third World. The Commonwealth is about people of diverse cultures and backgrounds. It provides forums in which people in a variety of careers and professions can meet and exchange views with their colleagues in other countries. In this context, the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association plays an important part in bringing together those nations whose governments are based on the Westminster system.

The CPA of which you, Mr President, and the Speaker are Joint Presidents, has for many years enabled matters of legislative and Parliamentary importance to be discussed. Many senators have benefited from active participation in the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association. Although there have been some who have questioned the relevance of the Commonwealth in the 1980s, its record of effectiveness in solving international problems and promoting much needed understanding effectively answers the doubting Thomases. I point to the positive role played by Commonwealth countries, including Australia, in solving the conflict which preceded the emergence of Zimbabwe.

Zimbabwe itself is now part of the Commonwealth. If anything, the Commonwealth of 1984 is even more important as an instrument which we, along with others, can use to promote co-operation and reason in a world so much in need of them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement announcing the Government's legislative program for the current period of sittings.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to have the text of the statement incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

Last year the government established the practice of announcing its legislation program at the start of each period of sittings. It remains our view that the parliament and the Australian people should know about the program at an early stage. We believe that an informed and open public debate about major national issues is an essential ingredient for effective government.

In this way members of parliament will be better informed and able to organise their own priorities and the community at large will be better able to understand the timing of the implementation of government policy.

The government's legislation program for the current sittings is aimed at consolidating the record established last year for economic management and social reform. A number of the Government's priority objectives have already been achieved.
Legislation introduced last sittings has recently been passed
to overcome the problems associated with sex discrimination
to protect Australia's trading interests and policies against the extra territorial enforcement of foreign laws
to strengthen anti dumping procedures.
In the budget sittings last year we introduced bills to:
establish a national crime authority;
give effect to the law reform commission recommendations for the insurance industry;
enable ratification of the Torres Strait treaty;
facilitate the management of supplies of fuel in emergencies
remove discrimination in relation to citizenship between British subjects and other immigrants;
The Government attaches importance to these elements of its program and debate will be resumed on these matters during these sittings.
It has already been announced that the assets test legislation, also introduced last sittings, will be considered further by a consultative committee.
I shall now outline briefly the new legislation which we intend to introduce.
Welfare and Community Development

As the first stage of national land rights proposals, Aboriginal heritage protection legislation will be introduced relating to sacred sites and objects. This measure will ensure a consistent national approach to site and object protection. Further land rights legislation may also be introduced if time permits.

Legislation already introduced gives legislative backing to Aussat as a publicly owned company and allows Telecom to hold a percentage of Aussat shares and persons using the satellite system to erect their own telecommunications facilities related to the satellite.
Legislation is also expected to be introduced to
re-establish the curriculum development centre
establish an Australian National Gallery fund by which non-government moneys can be accepted and invested.
Environment

The Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act will be amended to implement Government policy including its reponse to the recommendations of a number of parliamentary reports. The changes will increase the opportunities for public participation in commonwealth environmental assessment and provide a better basis for reconciling economic and environmental considerations.

Related legislation will assist in the protection of people and the environment from damage caused by various contaminants. It will provide for an assessment of the hazards in new chemicals being introduced into Australia and for the regulation of chemical substances.

Another measure being considered would regulate the development of tourist structures beyond the limits of the territorial sea. Proposals have been put forward to develop resorts on the Great Barrier Reef. There is currently no legislation which could be used to adequately control such developments.
Constitutional and Law Reform
Major legislation in this area will
establish an Australian Bill of Rights which will meet our international obligations under the international covenant on civil and political rights
upgrade the structure, role, jurisdiction and enforcement powers of the Human Rights Commission.
Further important measures will
apply the new electoral laws to the conduct of referendums as relevant
establish the Australian Government Solicitor as a corporate body in place of the Crown Solicitor
facilitate the use of extrinsic aids in statutory interpretation.
Other legislation will
establish a new Federal Guarding Service
widen the High Court's powers to remit matters to other courts thus improving the efficiency of the judicial system
enable ratification of The Hague Convention on marriage
give effect to international agreements on extradition

allow confidentiality orders made on grounds of national security or to protect the safety of persons by Victorian Criminal Courts in proceedings arising out of the Sheraton Hotel incident to be enforced throughout Australia.
Financial Measures

In addition to the Appropriation and Supply Bills and important cost supplementation legislation for education, the Government will introduce a number of taxation measures including measures in relation to superannuation and taxation avoidance.
Other legislation will
enhance the Commonwealth's ability to collect air navigation charges
amend the Co-operative Companies and Securities Scheme to deal with
registration of charges under the Companies Act
corporate membership of stock exchanges
implement a number of double taxation agreements.
External Relations
Bills will be introduced to
appropriate funds for Australia's contribution to the International Development Association
restrict the use of Australian passports to Australian citizens and remove the distinction between immigrants who are British subjects and those who are not
register the deaths of Australians travelling overseas.
Public Service

The Government will introduce major legislation to implement its plans to reform the Australian Public Service. The statement of the Government's intentions which was issued in December 1983 has been the subject of wide- ranging consultations, and the package which will be introduced will provide for a more responsive, accountable and efficient Public Service employment which will be open to all Australian citizens on the basis of merit.
Other measures will
arise from any report of the Remuneration Tribunal which might follow the forthcoming National Wage Case
update legislation relating to the Defence Force.
Assistance to Industry
Important measures relating to primary industry will
restructure the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation to increase its effectiveness and restrict its role to commercially oriented activities

establish a meat livestock policy council and a joint industry selection committee to advise the Minister for Primary Industry on Meat and Livestock Policy issues and on the composition og the Board of the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation
provide assistance to the States for soil conservation
clarify the borrowing power of the wool corporation (already introduced)
provide for new arrangements for the sugar industry
increase penalties for breaches of the Quarantine Act (already introduced).
Other measures will
implement various Bounty Measures approved by the Government
correct problems in regard to sites for the retail marketing of petroleum
exempt small vessels from the requirement to register under the Shipping Registration Act (already introduced)
regulate patents with regard to micro-organisms
reform road contract tendering requirements
discourage the underlifting of indigenous crude oil and offset the cost of coastal freight paid on deliveries of crude oil
prevent unauthorised use of the Advance Australia Logo
update national measurement legislation.
In addition the usual statute law (miscellaneous provisions) bill will include a number of matters of minor significance.

As always, unforeseen circumstances may give rise to additional legislation and pressure on the Parliamentary Counsel and other people's time may not enable all matters to come forward as soon as we would like. In addition, the government is still considering other reform measures which may result in legislation in the current sittings. But the program I have outlined continues the direction established by the Government in its first year and will put into effect a number of social, environmental, legal and institutional reforms to which the Government is strongly committed.
I commend the Government's program to the Senate and look forward to the assistance of Honourable Senators in its implementation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the first report of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills concerning the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1983, the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Miscellaneous Amendments Bill 1983, and the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1983.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.
