SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elstob Sen R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the seventh report of the Publications Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Report-by leave-adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the 223rd report of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts on the Committee's inquiry into HMAS Tobruk.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-This report details the findings of the Committee's inquiry into the amphibious heavy lift ship-HMAS Tobruk-project of the Department of Defence. The inquiry was commenced following the Auditor-General's critical report on the HMAS Tobruk project in March 1982. Initially the Committee planned to report on the findings of this inquiry in conjunction with its findings on other references from the Auditor-General's March 1982 report. However, because of the magnitude and the seriousness of the problems associated with the project the Committee decided to issue a separate report on the matter. Among the issues reported on by the Committee are: HMAS Tobruk's excess weight; the Defence Department's poor quality assurance and grossly inadequate on-site representation at the shipyard; Tobruk's inoperable davit hoist system for its landing craft; several alleged major design faults including a lack of watertight integrity following damage; major deficiencies in the Defence Department's overall approach to project management; and the history of design related problems with HMAS Tobruk's air conditioning system; the engine control system; the deck mounding of the ship's forward cranes; the ship's excessive vibration; its underdesigned auxiliary boilers; the ship's dangerous sewerage system; and its inadequate kit lockers.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee is most concerned about the variety of serious problems that were revealed during the course of the inquiry. The Committee questions the failure of the Department of Defence to rectify technical problems which emerged during the HMAS Tobruk project. The Committee would not have expected the Department to have mismanaged the acquisition of a major piece of equipment. During this inquiry the Committee found that many highly significant events and documents were not readily brought to the attention of the Committee by the Department. Rather, their existence was revealed only after prolonged investigation and probing inquiry by the Committee. The Committee was not satisfied with this aspect of the Department's conduct for it believed that a committee of the Australian Parliament should be given a full and frank account of all relevant events and documents pertinent to the matter under consideration. It is not a matter of receiving information on a need to know basis. It is for the Committee only to decide what material is relevant.

I wish to comment further on two matters raised in the report. First, during the course of the Tobruk inquiry the Committee learnt of the tragic death of Naval Reserve cadet Kenneth Dax and the critical findings of the subsequent board of inquiry and the Department's review of that board of inquiry. While the Department is to be congratulated for the thoroughness of the review of the board of inquiry report it is, at the same time, to be severely censured for the deficiencies and mismanagement reported on by the review. The Committee is concerned at the way the Department handled the Dax family's request for information and compensation following the tragic death of their son Kenneth. The Committee has carefully considered this issue and concludes that the amount of $3,550 is not an adequate amount to compensate for the death of a 14-year-old naval cadet and the subsequent distress to his family. The Committee recommends that the matter should be looked at again and a more adequate amount determined.

Secondly, during the course of the inquiry a question on HMAS Tobruk's watertight integrity following damage was raised. The Committee heard evidence on this serious matter from a variety of sources at both public and in camera hearings and carefully considered this allegation. The Committee remains doubtful about HMAS Tobruk's watertight integrity in certain circumstances. In this report the Committee makes 33 recommendations for action by the Defence Department. Of these I wish to highlight one recommendation which states:

That rectification of HMAS Tobruk's many serious technical problems should be carried out in advance of the scheduled refit. In the meantime consideration should be given to the operation of the ship to ensure its safety.

The Committee wishes to emphasise that it does not question the concept of, or the need for, a ship such as HMAS Tobruk. Clearly, the existence and operation of a heavy lift ship like HMAS Tobruk is of benefit to the Australian defence forces and the Australian community.

Similarly, the Committee in reporting on the findings of this inquiry does not question the role of the Australian shipbuilding industry in defence projects. The Committee emphasises that it does not wish to prejudice shipbuilding in Australia. It recognises the valuable contribution to the Australian economy made by Australian shipbuilding companies and their employees, and welcomes the development of this industry. The Committee believes that the recommendations of this inquiry will go some way towards improving overall project management and administration in the Department. However, there still remains a need for project management in the Department of Defence and its related organisations to be further improved substantially. As honourable senators will be aware, the Committee will be undertaking a detailed and comprehensive examination into the Defence Department's overall project management and administration this year. With this in mind the Committee requests that the response to this report be available to the Committee on or before 1 September 1984. In commending the report to honourable senators I will add some further comments.

I cannot put the report down without giving credit to the secretariat of the Committee and those who have worked on this long inquiry for the manner in which they produced the report to enable it to be tabled this week. I wish also to put on record my personal admiration for the efforts of Mrs Dax, the mother of Kenneth Dax, the 14-year-old who died in such unfortunate circumstances. Since 1981 Mrs Dax has persisted with great courage in bringing to the public's attention and to the attention of this Parliament the circumstances which led to her son's death. Unfortunately it is not to the credit of the Department of Defence or in fact those who represent the Department in this Parliament to have revealed the manner in which that family was treated.

Mrs Dax had to persist against great odds in order to get the information concerning the circumstances of the death. Mrs Dax with great effort obtained co -operation from the Department in her family's time of need. It does not reflect any credit on those concerned when one looks at the family's treatment. As the report reveals, the death of the lad was the result of an unfortunate series of events, design faults, misjudgment and errors. It is a death that could have and should have been avoided. However, the death having occurred, surely the Department could have responded as it should respond to the families of all Service personnel when something tragic occurs. If this case is any example of how the Service departments respond to the death of one of their number, of course, as the Committee report recommends, such responses will have to be substantially altered and corrected.

One finds it hard to accept that Mrs Dax should have had so much difficulty. One finds it hard to accept that she was not given consideration. One can talk about compensation but compensation is secondary. I do not think the Dax family or Mrs Dax are concerned about money. There is really no amount that would compensate them for the tragedy. Nevertheless, it is my belief that they seek to create a precedent in this area. It is for others to determine how the compensation can be increased. Many simple things should have been done in an understanding of the trauma which that family, in particular the parents, suffered. The report gives the whole chronology of the exchange of correspondence between that family and the Department over two years. One incident seems to indicate the lack of sensitivity of the Department. When the lad suffered the accident he was rescued by one of his fellow cadets who went into the head or the toilet area and brought the boy out at great risk to himself. The Dax family recommended an award for bravery. The Department accepted that and made an award for bravery to the cadet concerned, but it failed to advise the Dax family until after the award had been presented. That seems to me to demonstrate such a lack of sensitivity, understanding and co- operation. Even when the Department was trying to do the right thing it failed to carry out the details.

In the report I would say that we have hammered the Department rather remorselessly because, in a way, our approach may have been affected by the tragedy of Kenneth Dax and our belief that those errors should not have occurred . We felt that that toilet should not have become a trap and that those who altered the design of the system should have known, as the report shows, that certain consequences would flow from that change in design. They should have been aware, if they were changing the design, that the seal in the toilet head was only 17 millimetres of water, not 35 millimetres as in a domestic toilet. They should have known that the seal was less than that, and that when considering the pressures that built up there was not sufficient seal to counter those pressures. They were simple, ordinary problems of design that should have been recognised. Unfortunately, throughout the whole project there appear errors of this type.

Having gone through this whole exercise, I feel that the Department of Defence will respond not only because of the criticisms of this report but also because of its own review. The report of the inquiry by the board of review into the death of Kenneth Dax was the document upon which the Committee depended greatly to expose the serious problems of the Tobruk. There is the expertise within the Department to counter these problems and to solve them. I hope that as a result of this report that will happen.

I have spoken for longer than I intended, but I think it is necessary to indicate to the Parliament the serious deficiencies which occurred during the construction of Tobruk and subsequent to its commissioning. The matter is serious and ensuring understanding of that seriousness has been very necessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-After hearing the remarks of Senator Georges in relation to the parents of Kenneth Dax one can understand the reason why he spoke with such emotion yesterday, with the expectation that Mrs Dax would be listening to the parliamentary broadcast. The forms of this place are such that it is unfortunate that situations like that have to occur. I support the remarks that were made by my colleague Senator Georges, who is Chairman of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and who guided what was at times a highly technical investigation. Seldom has the Public Accounts Committee come up with such a concentration of criticism of a matter under review. The building of HMAS Tobruk has reflected very poorly on sections of the defence forces, on their project management, on the lack of communication between the personnel at the shipyard and the central co-ordinating authorities. It is a matter of some concern that when the matter was earlier under investigation by the Committee, the naval authorities did not draw to the Committee's attention the death of naval reserve cadet Kenneth Dax. In fact the existence of many significant events and documents was not readily brought to the attention of the Committee. They were revealed only after prolonged investigation and inquiry. This is tragic and reflects poorly on the Department.

SPEECH.PARA: It should be emphasised that the Committee does not question the concept of or the need for a ship such as HMAS Tobruk, nor does it wish that its 223rd report be used to prejudice shipbuilding in Australia. The Committee recognises the valuable contribution to the Australian economy made by the Australian shipbuilding companies and their employees, but there is a need for an overhaul of project management and shipbuilding techniques be applied within Australian defence establishments. It is unfortunate that because of the low level of shipbuilding activity in Australia much of the expertise has been lost through personnel resignations, retirement and transfer. There are now serious deficiencies in the adequacy of skills needed to build a large vessel in Australia. It is regrettable that a country with such a large coastline as Australia's has to defend itself with so few vessels which are so poorly equipped.

Although not covered by the report, on the information gained by me through my participation in this investigation, I would like to express the view that the Tobruk in the event of war would have to rely very heavily on other ships and aircraft for protection since it has so few capabilities for protecting itself. A vessel of this kind is a number one priority for an enemy attack. I believe that many needless lives could be lost because of the defence forces' decision to try to save money. I also wish to take this opportunity of thanking Commander Moreton for his help to the Committee while some members sailed off the Queensland coast aboard HMAS Tobruk. None of the criticisms should be taken as criticism of the crew, which certainly while we were aboard showed professional seamanship and dedication to the job.

I now think it is relevant that I list to the Senate some of the shortcomings which are outlined in the report in the hope that others may be induced to read it and note the seriousness of the matter. I also hope it will lead to a thorough reappraisal of many of the current policies and practices, which the Committee thinks should be radically overhauled. There is the question of the Department not allocating sufficient resources to develop such things as quality assurance programs for monitoring, particularly matters of weight control procedures. An unauthorised weight increase was due to the Department not ensuring that the correct specifications were met, something pretty fundamental and elementary to most people. The Department did not give adequate consideration to the commercial practicalities of converting a particular specification from an imperial old design to metric measurements. The Department did not realise the consequences of what might be termed soft or appropriate conversions when dealing with very narrow tolerances. Given the magnitude and obvious implications of converting the ship's design from imperial to metric measurements, the Department should have monitored more closely the contractor's conversion processes and material acquisitions. In this respect the Department was derelict in carrying out its contract supervisory role.

There is little purpose in building a specialised beaching design vessel such as Tobruk if the resulting ship can use the specified design only in a secondary role and then under restricted circumstances. The number of on-site departmental representatives at the ship yard, at practically all times, was grossly inadequate. The level of on-site departmental expertise and experience was inadequate given the task in hand. The Department's tender specifications were deficient and not correctly oversighted. As these matters are quite extensive and because of the pressure of time, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard my other remarks.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
the Department has been dilatory in devising a remedy for HMAS Tobruk's contaminated hydraulic system;

continuing problems with HMAS Tobruk's devid hydraulic system, point to a lack of expertise with hydraulics in the Department or inefficient systems in the Department to rectify defects in well known engineering technology;
the problems experienced by HMAS Tobruk since commissioning are not minor teething problems;
many of the major problems HMAS Tobruk has suffered since its commissioning stem from design related causes;
the ship's existing air conditioning system is unsatisfactory and in need of replacement in the long term;
problems with the ship's engine control system, partly attributable to the use of a mixture of ferrous and non-ferrous pipes, contravene the contract specifications on dissimilar metals;
the problem of HMAS Tobruk's excessive vibration has not been resolved;
the ship's excessive vibration may constitute a long term health hazard to the crew;
there is little doubt that HMAS Tobruk's excessive vibration will increase the ship's maintenance costs and reduce its life;
problems with HMAS Tobruk's auxiliary boilers typify the difficulties of producing spare parts from overseas manufacturers;

HMAS Tobruk's sewerage system was not adequately understood by the Department's designers, the contractor's designers and installation staff, the ship's company and the Department's maintenance personnel during the building of the ship;
HMAS Tobruk's poorly designed kit locker spaces have led to the development of a potential safety hazard in the form of congested troop passage ways when troops are on board;

the Department proceed as a matter of urgency to thoroughly research questions surrounding HMAS Tobruk's potential for lack of watertight integrity and initiate corrective action as soon as possible if needed;
the Department research the risks associated with HMAS Tobruk's external PVC Piping;
the amount of $3550 is not an adequate amount to be paid for compensation to Mr and Mrs Dax given the circumstances;
a more adequate act of grace payment should be made to Mr and Mrs Dax.
From the evidence of poor project management manifested throughout the inquiry into HMAS Tobruk, the Committee is embarking on a new reference-Project Management in the Department of Defence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

If other senators wish to speak I will certainly not pre-empt them. Senator Mason wishes to comment on this report and I hope that in two weeks time, when the Senate resumes, we will be able to continue the debate. I hope that the last speaker in this debate will enable that to occur. I intend to make some brief comments on only one part of the report of which I have any knowledge and that relates to Kenneth Dax. On many occasions I have spoken in this chamber on this matter and have probably annoyed many Ministers by constantly bringing up this problem that occurred. This is another step in what was an unsatisfactory method of dealing with such a difficult and tragic problem. I am glad that Mrs Dax took up the fight. It is not something that I think many people could have done or would want to do. The fact is that Mrs Dax did it. If, as I hope, the recommendations of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts which are set out on page 118, are taken on board, it will mean that her fight will bear fruit not only for her and her husband but also for others who may be caught in such tragic circumstances. I believe that the recommendations of the Committee are very sensible and reasonable and meet the issue we face.

I too would like to echo the sentiments expressed by Senator Georges as Chairman of this Committee. One of the things that struck anybody who had to deal with this case was the complete lack of sensitivity involved. The aspect which struck me as being the worst was not that which Senator Georges raised, but the letter which was sent by the then Minister for Defence to Mrs Dax saying that there would be no ex gratia payment. Anyone reading that letter cannot but be struck with the fact that it was written with callous disregard to its contents. It was as though somebody had applied for a licence, a contract or some inanimate object and was simply turned down. It seems to me that the person who wrote it almost totally lacked any feeling and sensitivity. From talking to Mrs Dax it became very evident that she would not have pursued this fight if there had been some sympathy, some understanding and some compassion at the outset. The fact that she had to deal with a total lack of those qualities on the part of the bureaucracy and the feeling that she did not have a need to know anything drove her on in her desperate fight.

I am buoyed up by the fact that a committee of this Parliament can spend time on one citizen's problem and hopefully, if these recommendations are accepted, help to resolve it. After some of the things that have happened this week I think that the activities of the Parliament in relation to this matter concerning one citizen show that there are people here who will fight these types of cases on behalf of ordinary people and who, if these recommendations are accepted, will win. It adds to the good name and reputation of this House that one person in this country can get that type of support from his or her elected representatives, can pursue an issue to the point where one of the most important committees of this Parliament spends much time considering it. I believe that that reflects a great deal of credit on the institution of parliament in a democracy such as ours.

I urge the Government to accept the recommendations of the report. They seem to me to have been compiled by people with a very detailed understanding and knowledge of the case and with an eye to future occurrences of this kind. I believe that if these recommendations are accepted Mrs Dax will be satisfied that at long last the problems that she encountered have been recognised and that the treatment she received is recognised as having been wrong. I believe that the Parliament, and the Government in particular, will also accept the errors made by the Executive, both in the previous Government and the current Government. I am sure-certainly, Senator Grimes, the Minister for Social Security, has expressed this view-that there will be a review of the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act. I hope we will see that review come to fruition in this session of Parliament.

I conclude on a word of commendation to the Committee which I feel has tackled this problem with great vigour. I have looked at the rest of the report as well and it seems to me that if any report has substantiated the work of the committees of this Parliament it is this one. The work it undertook in ferreting out information, reducing it and compiling its recommendations shows that the Public Accounts Committee of this Parliament is second to none in the history of a committee which has had a long and fairly illustrious history. I expect that any government would be hard pressed to turn down any of these sensible and reasonable recommendations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elstob Sen R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to say a few words in regard to the findings of the Joint Committee of Public Account's inquiry into HMAS Tobruk. First of all, I congratulate Senator Georges and every member of the Public Accounts Committee for bringing down this report. I believe it is in the finest tradition of the Australian Parliament's committees. I believe that everyone on that Committee has to be congratulated. I believe that the injustices caused to the parents of young Kenneth Dax are a disgrace. I also congratulate the Committee for recommending that the Government look seriously at increasing compensation in such matters. Although I realise that such compensation will never replace the life of Kenneth Dax I believe, as Senator Georges has said, that it will at least show some concern. I believe that there will have to be caning in the Department of Defence. The handling of this case was a disgrace.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not wish to say any more than that but I want to indicate that if no other senator wishes to speak I shall seek leave to continue my remarks later. I believe that we would be paying a tribute to the Dax family if a tape recording of the remarks made could be forwarded to them. I propose to move accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Leave is not granted, Senator Elstob, as someone else wishes to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Joint Committee of Public Accounts for its report. I do not know anything about the aspects of the report concerning the Department of Defence, hence I do not intend to comment on them. I assume that the Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes) will comment on them in another place. A matter which does arise in the recommendations and which does concern me is the question of compensation for the Dax family for this most unfortunate incident. Some time after becoming Minister for Social Security I had this unfortunate accident drawn to my attention. There was no provision under Defence Department legislation or under Commonwealth compensation legislation for compensation to be paid for the death of a minor in such a situation who had no dependants. I found this a somewhat difficult situation.

SPEECH.PARA: There is obviously a deficiency in the legislation and I was determined that an ex gratia payment should be made. The difficulty then arises as to how much that ex gratia payment should be. The Department, in this one-off case, chose to look to other compensation legislation in this country and, as the report says, we chose to use the Queensland Workers Compensation Act 1916 which provides for a payment of 10 per cent of the maximum death benefit under these circumstances to the parents of a minor leaving no dependants. That resulted in a payment, with the approval of the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins), of $3,550 to Mrs Dax. As I said to Mrs Dax at the time, it did not seem like very much of a compensation payment, but it was a compensation payment under legislation similar to the Commonwealth compensation legislation.

We intend to amend the Commonwealth employees compensation legislation to make provision for such payments, but I merely point out to the Senate what is obvious from this report: It is not easy. It is easy to say that $3,550 is not enough. It is easy to say that 10 per cent of the maximum death benefit is not enough. The Committee has been unable to decide what is a reasonable payment. In fact no reference is made to what might be a reasonable payment. The only reference the Committee made was that it found the Queensland Workers Compensation Act, provided as a guide, was not relevant to these conditions. I am not quite sure what that means, but clearly the Committee came to the conclusion that that Act in some way was not relevant. We will put our minds to it. I hope that the members of the Committee will put their minds to it so that, when we come up with a decision as to just how much the compensation might be, we do not have too much difference of opinion. I notice that everyone is willing to say that it is not enough but that no one is willing to say what is enough. I dare say that is what governments are about and what Ministers are for.

I have only one other remark. It was unfortunate-I think the Committee should look to its procedures-that this Committee report was released to the Press under embargo before either honourable senators or Ministers were able to look at it. I am sure that was an accident and I hope that in the future we can look at that. If the Press is to have reports, senators and members should have them also.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to correct what might be a misunderstanding on the part of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes ) as to the release of the report. There was some confusion about the release of this report yesterday, possibly because of the postponement of its consideration by the censure motion. When I was sitting in my room waiting to hear the tabling of the report in the House of Representatives, which would have made it a public document, I was surprised that the report was delivered to my room. It may be that the few remarks I made yesterday before the censure motion triggered off the release of the report. I heard that a complaint was made to the Speaker that a copy of the report was in the hands of a reporter prior to the tabling of the report.
—Several reporters, not just one.

—I am not quite certain how that could have occurred. The matter is under investigation, but the Joint Committee of Public Accounts did not release the report under embargo. I make it clear that, if the report reached the hands of any reporter prior to its tabling, that would have happened between the moment it left the Committee secretariat and the time it was received at Parliament House. I do not know how long before its tabling the report was released. It might have been only 10 or 15 minutes. I do not know when it was brought to the notice of the Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes) that the report was in the hands of a reporter. I am trying to ascertain that now. But the report was not released under embargo.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt that there has been speculation in the Press about the report and there was also in the Bulletin a report which seemed to indicate some knowledge of the contents of the report. But that Bulletin report was written by a reporter who had followed this inquiry from the beginning and was able to assess much of what was in the Committee's mind and much of the evidence before the Committee. In fact the journalist concerned wrote the article which attracted the Committee's attention to the fact that the Defence Department had not given it all the information. That reporter who was very close to it wrote the article in the Bulletin which seems to indicate that she may have had access to some information she should not have had.

The report was not released with an embargo. If the Committee or any committee believes in future that should be done, the matter should be brought before the Senate which can then debate the procedure we should follow. If that is to be the case, such an embargo would have to be as secure as the embargo placed on the Budget Papers before they are delivered in the House. We cannot trust an embargoed release of a report without such careful precautions.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present the official report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to the spring meetings, Helsinki, and the seventieth Inter-Parliamentary Union conference, Seoul, in 1983, together with the summary record, results of the meetings and the minutes of the Inter- Parliamentary Council.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-In presenting the report of the Australian delegation to the Inter-Parliamentary Union meetings in 1983, I wish to make a few comments concerning the role of the Union and the results of the seventieth conference. The purpose of the Union as defined in Article 1 of the Statutes is:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to promote personal contacts between members of all Parliaments, constituted into National Groups, and to unite them in common action to secure and maintain the full participation of their respective States in the firm establishment and development of representative institutions and in the advancement of the work of international peace and co-operation, particularly by supporting the objectives of the United Nations.

In relation to the Union's Statutes' relevancy to the Australian Parliament, I would like to draw the Senate's attention to the words of the leader of the delegation in 1983, Mr Ralph Jacobi, who is present in the gallery today, in the foreword of the report, in which he said:
Joint Committee of Public Accounts
Joint Committee of Public Accounts
Joint Committee of Public Accounts
Joint Committee of Public Accounts
Joint Committee of Public Accounts
Joint Committee of Public Accounts
Joint Committee of Public Accounts
Joint Committee of Public Accounts
Joint Committee of Public Accounts
Joint Committee of Public Accounts
Joint Committee of Public Accounts
Joint Committee of Public Accounts

Through their meetings the IPU provides a unique opportunity to Parliamentarians world-wide by formal and informal personal contact to share views and to better understand each others problems. The difficulty for many in approaching the IPU from a Western standpoint is the measure of unreality about an organization of 'parliaments' which includes most of the Eastern Bloc as well as many other Nations with a dubious claim to the practice of multi-party parliamentary democracy as we know it.

In my view the diversity of parliamentary systems and political ideologies of the member nations in no way weakens the Union as an effective organ for the meeting and exchange of views between Parliamentarians; it is, perhaps, its strength. As in the United Nations where representatives of Governments meet to debate world issues, the IPU provides a forum where Parliamentarians can discuss world events and problems. It provides for a meeting of minds between East and West and North and South where matters ranging from disarmament to poverty in the Third World can be debated and resolutions formulated for submission to the Parliaments and Governments of the National Groups represented.

The IPU also provides an opportunity for work in specific areas. One of the most important and successful of these areas is in the pursuit of the human rights of Parliamentarians. The Committee on the Violation of Human Rights of Parliamentarians, under the chairmanship of Mr van Dam (Netherlands), investigates cases which come to attention and reports to the Council. The Special Committee, in Helsinki, reported that 37 Parliamentarians had been released since the Rome Conference while at Seoul, reported that a further 10 Parliamentarians had been released following negotiations. In this work the Committee works in close liaison with Amnesty International.
I endorse these remarks made by Mr Jacobi and urge all honourable senators to participate fully in the activities of the Union.

I turn now to the results of the seventieth Conference. The Seoul Conference produced a number of worthwhile resolutions relating to youth unemployment and the work of UNCTAD VI-the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development. I note the participation and useful contributions by my colleague Senator Elstob, who is also in the chamber today. It also produced a resolution condemning the act of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republic in shooting down Korean Airlines Flight 007. Australian delegates, under the leadership of Mr Jacobi, played a prominent role in ensuring that this resolution was strengthened and passed by the Conference.

I wish to mention briefly the work of the Economic and Social Committee which dealt with the problems of the world's economic system and the work that UNCTAD VI undertook to overcome those problems. Many speakers expressed the wish for the rapid creation of a new economic order, particularly by means of the effective implementation of the agreement establishing the Common Fund for Commodities and by the adoption of concrete measures by UNCTAD. Two themes emerged from this. The first was the role that parliaments and governments of all countries could take to ensure that action be undertaken for the establishment of a new international economic order which would enable all countries to develop, particularly the developing countries, for the signature and ratification of the agreement establishing a Common Fund for Commodities, and for the adoption by UNCTAD VI of a program of action strongly in favour of a reduction in the military expenditure of all countries and of the utilisation of the resources thus released for the development of the developing countries. The second theme was the role that the parliaments and governments of the developing countries could take to initiate national programs which used all possibilities for the enlargement of mutual co-operation and which consolidated international economic co-operation.

UNCTAD VI was held in Belgrade in July 1983. Although UNCTAD VI failed to achieve the high goals many countries placed upon it, there has appeared a willingness by all countries, both developed and developing, to come to some new arrangements to ensure that the world economy does not collapse. The resolutions of the Conference point to the development of this new economic order, and I recommend that all honourable senators read these resolutions.

I wish to thank the organisers and peoples of the host countries for their wonderful hospitality and work to make the work of IPU in 1983 so successful. Helsinki was a most appropriate city in which to hold the spring meetings, where parliamentarians from around the world could meet and seek solutions. Finland so often has shown commendable application of the democratic processes amid tremendous pressures. Finland presents to the world some of the answers which I believe the world is seeking at a time of tremendous pressure and turmoil. I particularly thank the people of the Republic of Korea, who persevered with the seventieth Conference following the tragic and brutal act of terrorism perpetrated against the people of that country during the Conference. It is to their credit that the ideals of the Union were upheld amidst national grief and mourning.

During the visit to Seoul, one of the highlights for all members was the opportunity to visit the Commonwealth War Memorial at Kapyong and for the delegation to present wreaths commemorating the deaths of Australian and Korean soldiers during the Korean War. This event was attended by the whole of the Australian delegation, who were escorted in a dignified manner through a guard of honour of Korean school children in national dress and Korean soldiers to appropriate music played by the local school band. Later we were led through lines of thousands of school children along the road. They welcomed the Australian delegation. It was a most moving occasion. I place on record my thanks to Congressman Chi and the War Veterans' Movement of Korea for their courtesy in arranging this.

Finally, Mr Deputy President, I wish to pay tribute to the leader of the delegation, Mr Ralph Jacobi, who was able to achieve a high degree of success in ensuring that Australia's point of view was heard and noted. He was ably supported by all members of the delegation and the accompanying staff who worked together in a co-operative spirit enabling the delegation to take a strong and united approach. I emphasise the term 'united approach', because although we represented people from the respective parties, we put a solid and united Australian point of view on all issues which were raised in 1983. I commend the report to honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elstob Sen R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I add my comments to those of Senator Watson, the deputy leader of the Inter-Parliamentary Union delegation, led by Mr Jacobi, to Helsinki and Seoul. Other delegates in the past returning from Inter- Parliamentary Union meetings have made derogatory remarks. Until I was involved in the IPU meetings, I believed also that perhaps Australia should withdraw from these meetings. I now have a totally different view since attending the meetings in Helsinki and Seoul. I believe that the IPU gives an opportunity for politicians all around the world to meet and discuss the problems that beset our world. If young people, such as those in the gallery listening to this speech today, are to have any chance at all, we must reduce the possibilities of war and reduce ignorance and poverty in the world. That is the only way we can have peace. I believe that the Inter-Parliamentary Union is a venue for politicians from around the world to get together and help solve the problems that beset us. I urge strongly that Australia keeps on sending delegates to the IPU.

SPEECH.PARA: I endorse what Senator Watson has said, that is, that all the delegates, irrespective of what political parties they came from, represented this country. It was the very solid approach taken by the Australian delegation which beefed up the resolution regarding the destruction of the Korean airliner, which was a terrible occurrence. I believe that the world should be outspoken on such occasions. There were many issues discussed-better education, how to lift the Third World countries, how to get employment for young people, how to reduce world tension about war, and how to reduce world spending on armaments. All these things are vital to the world if we are to survive.

I congratulate Mr Jacobi, who led the delegation. His voice in the Ten Plus meeting was heard with the greatest respect. Australia is respected by the majority of countries in the world. We have no axe to grind, as have many other countries. Australia has a role to play as a peacemaker and in bringing sensible decisions to international meetings such as those of the IPU. I also congratulate the staff who accompanied us. Every one of them acted in a very admirable way and gave us all the help that was necessary. I believe that the IPU meetings are valuable. Australia has a real role to play. My advice to the Australian Government is that it ensure that we keep on sending delegates to attend the IPU meetings.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Dried Fruits Corporation annual report for 1982-83 shows clearly that there is presently a world oversupply of approximately 145,000 tonnes a year and that this is now virtually fostered by the European Economic Community, which is supporting the overproduction, particularly in Greece. The Australian industry is still working hard to improve its quality, to develop new varieties and new markets, to rationalise costs, and to upgrade the various methods of production involved. At the same time, it is trying to advance its markets in South East Asia, where there is some potential, although the best market still seems to be in Australia. Australian sales of dried fruits, have increased from about 13,500 tonnes in 1975 to over 22,000 tonnes in 1980 and last year sales were up to 31,000 tonnes. Approximately 35 per cent of the total production is consumed locally and the balance, 65 per cent, is exported.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1983-84 about $350,000 is to go to dried fruit research. At this stage we can only hope that that sort of expenditure will show results while there is still an industry. Judging by the way in which the industry is going, I am not sure that the expenditure of $350,000 will be of value. Some very positive action will have to be taken and government will need to become really involved. The industry will have to come up with solid propositions and constant watching of the overseas market will be required. I believe that we are not doing enough at present to see that this happens. I see the dried fruits industry as a very vital small industry and I believe that Australians generally want to see it maintained. I think it needs far greater recognition in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few brief comments on the annual report for 1982-83 of the Australian Heritage Commission. I congratulate the Commission on its work over the year. I particularly draw attention to several comments made in the annual report, first of all about South West Tasmania. I think it needs to be noted that the Heritage Commission's activity in relation to the saving of the Franklin River and the preservation of South West Tasmania was an important factor in that event. I draw attention to the Commission's belief that consideration should be given to the revision of boundaries to include a wider area. The Commission makes that opinion clear and I think it ought to be supported in that recommendation. Another issue to which it refers is that of the National Estate being constantly under threat. Rainforest logging is one of the issues to which it draws particular attention. I think all of us need to be continually vigilant about threats to both the built and the natural environment throughout the nation.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite the comments that have been made in Tasmania in recent days about the inhibition on development because of the existence of the National Estate listings, I suspect that the inhibition is not very great at all. Whether we like to think so, or not, the powers of listing do not mean that development is automatically prevented. Concurrent legislation is needed in some of the States which have not yet legislated to establish heritage protection. I regret to say that Tasmania is one of those States in which State legislation is lacking.

One needs also to draw attention to the very worthwhile Commonwealth grants that are made through the Australian Heritage Commission to State government authorities, local government bodies and other bodies such as the National Trust and the Conservation Trust in Tasmania to help in the preservation of important aspects of our national heritage. There is not time in a debate in which one is allowed only a few minutes to go through all of those valuable grants. They are generally small, of the order of $2,000 to $20,000. They are very worthwhile, but in the overall scheme of things not nearly large enough to make sure that the things we all want to keep are preserved.

One other issue that I would like to raise in this debate was referred to in the Heritage Commission's report a couple of years ago and I think was raised in the Senate on Tuesday. It is the question of Commonwealth statutory authorities and their funding for the preservation of historic buildings. A couple of years ago the Australian Heritage Commission referred to the post offices at Cambell Town and Oatlands in Tasmania, beautiful old stone buildings which were an integral part of the streetscape of those two historic towns. Unfortunately, in the 1950s and 1960s some unfeeling person--

TALK.START.PARA: —Vandalised.

—Yes, vandalised. Senator Archer agrees with me. They vandalised the facade of those buildings by putting on a so-called modern exterior that destroyed the overall appearance. The Australian Postal Commission would like to restore the original appearance of those buildings but it claims not to have the funds to do that as soon as it would like. I think the Senate, the Australian Heritage Commission and anybody else who believes that those two post offices are examples of buildings that ought to be restored should insist that action be taken to do that.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking briefly to the seventh report of the Australian Heritage Commission, the report for 1982-83, I think the Australian Heritage Commission, its chairman and commissioners are to be congratulated for the work that they have carried out during the year. Australia and its people can be well pleased by what has been achieved by the Heritage Commission in its seven years of activity to protect the National Estate. In particular I commend the Heritage Commission for the work it is carrying out in education in publishing booklets listing nominations. This is excellent material . Honourable senators will note that material has been put out in regard to three Australian sites-the Willandra Lakes Region, the Great Barrier Reef and Kakadu National Park. As I have said, the work is excellent and is invaluable. In the education area, the Commission hoped to have its school kit ' Investigating the National Estate' updated by the end of 1983. I do not recall having seen the updated material but no doubt it is available. I commend the Commission for its efforts in this area as this material is spread far and wide amongst the schools.

SPEECH.PARA: I note that this year the Northern Territory has received very many grants. Various Northern Territory authorities, such as the Conservation Commission, museums and art galleries, the Sacred Sites Protection Authority and the National Trust have been funded. I commend also the work that the National Trust is doing. Funds have been made available and this has allowed many of the old buildings and valuable sites in the Northern Territory to be protected.

I wish to mention a matter that has arisen between the Heritage Commission and the Northern Territory. I do not say that there is confrontation but it appears that some legislation is required to bring about better teamwork with the Commission. I wish to read from a letter written by the Northern Territory Government. It states:

Dear Prime Minister, I wish to draw your attention to a matter of some uncertainty in the provisions of the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975 which my Government believes should be resolved by legislative amendment.

The issue concerns the application of the Act to the Northern Territory and its statutory authorities. The scope of the definition of ''authority of the Commonwealth'' (section 3 of the Act) is uncertain. It appears that there is a conflict of legal opinion as to whether the definition extends to Northern Territory statutory authorities. I understand it has even been advanced that the definition is sufficiently wide to encompass the Crown in right of the Northern Territory-a simplistic approach which entirely overlooks the fundamental changes effected by the Northern Territory (Self-Government) Act.

Legal advice suggests that the Act's definition of ''authority of the Commonwealth'' does not extend to either the Northern Territory as a body politic or its authorities. However, I believe there would be little merit in legal advisors to our Government engaging in a long and tedious technical debate which appears unlikely to reach finality short of a judicial ruling.
The present situation is clearly unsatisfactory. The Commonwealth Act is undoubtedly uncertain on the issue and, unless amended, inevitably will remain a source of friction.

The Australian Heritage Commission, while adopting an interpretation of its Act at variance with that of my Government, has recognised that the self-governing status of the Northern Territory is inconsistent with application of Commonwealth legislation to entirely ''State'' administrative decisions.

As long ago as 1979, in a submission to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation, the Commission stated that it would be appropriate to amend the Act to place the Northern Territory in a position similar to that of the States. The Standing Committee, in both its first and second reports (1979 and 1981) agreed that there was no reason why the Territory should not be treated in the same manner as the States. The Committee also suggested that complementary Territory legislation should also be introduced. However, this is entirely a matter for my Government's consideration and should not be adopted as an excuse for inaction in removing the present ambiguity from the Commonwealth legislation.
I hope that the two authorities will come to some agreement on this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —The 1982-83 report from the Barley Industry Research Council is again a good report. Like the wheat industry the barley industry seems to manage its affairs very well. SPEECH.PARA: The Barley Industry Research Council is a quite substantial organisation. Its total receipts for the year were $704,892. I believe that the Government provided $350,000 of that. That the Senate take note of the papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to enlarge a little on the comments I made in a question to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan ), who represents the Minister for Science and Technology, about the effect on Commonwealth employment in Tasmania of the report of the Committee of Inquiry into Commonwealth Laboratories. I asked the question on Monday. I do not wish to be critical of the very full work of the Committee of Inquiry. It was given a job to do by the previous Government, a job that was continued under this Government. I do not pretend to have read all three volumes of the report. I want also to emphasise that I am not opposed to sensible rationalisation of Commonwealth laboratories or of any other Government activity. But I was pleased to hear Senator Ryan say in answer to my question the other day that there was not, as yet, any Government decision on the report and that the aspects that I raised will be taken into account.

SPEECH.PARA: The problems that the report refers to in respect of Tasmania concern, in particular, the Armed Forces Food Science Establishment at Scottsdale, which has been referred to by other Tasmanian members. There is also mention of the section of the Australian Government Analytical Laboratories in Hobart and the future of the Commonwealth Department of Health Pathology Laboratory. These matters seem to come under the general recommendation of the Committee of Inquiry that there should be a concentration of Commonwealth laboratory service activities in larger and more viable laboratories. One needs to ensure that in Tasmania, as in other small States and in the regions of this country, there is a correct proportion of Commonwealth employment. We have been pushing for this for many years.

Honourable senators may recall that the Australian Labor Party initiated the policy of taking into account regional needs, in Tasmania in particular, when considering the distribution of Commonwealth activities. Arising out of that initiation there was the report of the Callaghan Inquiry into the Structure of Industry and the Employment Situation in Tasmania. The first move was the location of the Antarctic Division's headquarters in Tasmania. I was proud to be associated with this. It arose out of a suggestion in the time of the McMahon Government that the one small part of that Antarctic Division which had been located in Tasmania should be moved to the mainland and concentrated in Melbourne. I am not suggesting that there should be a section of the Australian Government Analytical Laboratories in every town in the country, but there should be some balance of distribution of Commonwealth services and employment around the country. I ask: Why cannot Hobart be the location of the section of the Australian Government Analytical Laboratories which specialises in certain tests where it would not be efficient to duplicate expensive equipment? I do not automatically believe that it is necessarily most efficient to transfer all activities to Canberra, Sydney and Melbourne. While rationalisation may well be useful, one can rationalise in ways which do not affect Commonwealth employment. My understanding is that the State does not want to take over the Commonwealth pathology laboratory in Hobart. It is important that pathology not be left to the major private laboratory alone. At least the existence of the Commonwealth laboratory provides medical practitioners with a choice as to the body they send their samples to for testing.

I will mention very briefly the Scottsdale research laboratories. As everyone will appreciate, defence expenditure in Tasmania is very low. I am not pushing for having any major base. The existing operation, especially as it is an ideologically sound component of defence expenditure, should be allowed to continue in a town which, to a large extent, depends on it for its existence. It should not be moved to the mainland just for the sake of centralisation. That does not mean that it should necessarily remain within the Department of Defence . Perhaps it ought to be a Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation activity. But I do not think that a closure at Scottsdale would necessarily go along with that other rationalisation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to support the remarks made by Senator Coates. Although he and I are on opposite sides of the chamber, we both come from Tasmania and have common interests in the welfare of that State. I support his remarks about the low level of Commonwealth involvement, particularly from the defence forces, in infrastructure and personnel in that State. So the recommendations of the Committee of Inquiry into Commonwealth Laboratories should be deplored by all Tasmanians. Earlier I commented publicly in support of my colleague the honourable member for Bass, Mr Newman, whose constituency covers the Scottsdale area, where one of the recommendations is to take effect. The transfer of the laboratory would have a detrimental impact on the Scottsdale community. The personnel in that establishment have developed a world-wide expertise in the area of the preservation of food. Its techniques have been adopted by the Australian Army in a great number of cases.

SPEECH.PARA: We often criticise the fact that only a low level of research and technology has taken place in Australia. Associated with that criticism we say that research and development in the laboratories, et cetera, should be where the operative manufacturing takes place. We have a food processing company in Scottsdale. So it is highly desirable that the Commonwealth laboratory specialising in the preserving of food for a long time, the manner in which that food is packed and carried, the nutritional value and all the associated matters be located in an environment which has not only a high level of expertise but also is cost efficient. So often we find when we centralise all these sorts of things that there is a lack of dedication and specialisation and sometimes other areas which happen to be popular at the time get prominence. A fairly low level of priority is given at the moment to defence and related matters. I hope that is not a reason behind the Committee's recommendations for the transfer of the laboratory and the unit out of Scottsdale.

We must encourage specialised institutions which are close to the area of activity. I believe this is in conformity with the view of the current Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones). I might be wrong, but I have read a lot of his papers and he seems to subscribe to the theory that we should encourage science and technology and that this should be done essentially at the place where the main activity is carried out. I hope we will get a wide level of support from Tasmanians in this place. I know the Minister for Social Security ( Senator Grimes) has publicly supported the need for the maintenance of this particular unit in Scottsdale. I also support the continuation of the other laboratories and centres in Hobart. After all, we are trying to develop a high level of expertise at the Antarctic Division laboratories in Kingston. Such a closure of facilities would have a detrimental impact on the whole concept of trying to decentralise some of the activities of the Commonwealth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak to the report of the Independent Committee of Inquiry into Commonwealth Laboratory Services and Facilities, as a parochial Tasmanian but with the wider Australian view in mind. I find that whenever an inquiry such as this is set up, all it seems to do is to recommend centralisation. It does not really matter what we do. How often do we find an objective assessment that says it would be better if we did not put these facilities into the cities? It is important to look at this report in light of that attitude. We went to a lot of trouble to decentralise at places such as Albury-Wodonga. We have had government decisions stating that we need to send industries to South Australia, Tasmania and the like. This is such a case.

SPEECH.PARA: I pay tribute to the tremendous skill and dedication of the officers at the Armed Forces Food Science Establishment in Scottsdale. Of course, not only do they operate a first class plant and have the dedication to back it up, but also they are situated, funnily enough, in what happens to be the best place to grow vegetables. Any talk of moving the station to somewhere else and then probably having to take vegetables to it would be absolute nonsense. If we mean what we say on these various issues, we must follow through. We need to utilise the plant and the people in these areas. We still need to see how best we can utilise the less populated parts of Australia. We need to see what else we can take into such places to make such facilities even more viable than they are. My understanding of the food processing plant is that we have a great opportunity, properly handled, to produce foodstuffs for all sorts of organisations, such as the armed forces and scientific expeditions of countries around the world. It is a great organisation. Any talk, even in jest-I doubt whether the report was prepared in jest-should be totally ignored and the whole approach should be broadened and strengthened in any way possible.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5 March, on motion by Senator Robertson:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the response by the Government to the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs. Honourable senators will note that the report was brought down by the Committee in October 1982. Therefore, it was presented to the previous Government. I join with the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding ) in commending the work done not only by the Committee, but also, in particular , by the then Chairman of the Committee, Mr Phil Ruddock, who is a member of the other place. The Minister in his statement has made some very commendatory remarks about the work done, even though there were two or three dissenting reports. I join with him in those commendations. Honourable senators will recall that the report deals with a most difficult area, that of Aboriginal people living in what we used to call fringe camps, but which the report has called town camps. The problems with which the people living in such areas have to deal are graphically illustrated by the comments made in the Minister's response. On page 2 he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Name a disadvantaged, or a social problem and the town campers suffer it: Offensive unsanitary conditions; abominable housing (if the pitiful shelters can be called that in many cases); virtually no employment prospects; inadequate education; and all the physical and mental health problems including alcohol abuse, social tension and frequent violence that accompanies despair, anguish and hopelessness.

This was the task which the House of Representatives Committee originally set itself to look at. The recommendations with which it came up, I feel, have been fully dealt with by the Government. I think the Committee will be very pleased with the response which has come down. Quite clearly-I have no doubt that the Chairman in the other place made this comment-more can always be done. I agree wholeheartedly that more can always be done. Nevertheless, I think the Committee would be gratified at the number of recommendations that the Minister has agreed to not only in principle but also by setting in motion the provision of finance. The only limitation-this is accepted, I think, on both sides of the chamber-in this area which is essentially a bipartisan one, is that of finance.

The problems faced by the town campers, if we can call them that, differ significantly from those of the Aboriginal people living in the non-urban areas, for want of a better phrase-the Aboriginal communities, outstations and so on- although there is some similarity among them. The report calls for consultation. When we look through the Minister's response we see that the Minister who, incidentally, was a member of the original Committee, has accepted a good deal of the recommendations and has worked towards consultation. I suggest that honourable senators study the schedules which have been attached to the response to see the extent of the recommendations involving consultation. It is interesting to see how other Ministers have gone ahead with some of the recommendations of the report even before this response was issued. I make reference to Yipirinya outside Alice Springs. The Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) has agreed that money should be made available to it. In fact, this was done last year. It was one of her first actions after becoming Minister. I commend her for making the money available to Yipirinya as an experiment. I know that Senator Peter Baume and others on the other side of the chamber would accept the proposition that this is a most worthwhile experiment.

I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presentation of the schedules which show, first, the Government's response to each of the recommendations and secondly, a summary of existing situations in respect of town camps that were mentioned in the report. I congratulate those who were responsible for the preparation of this material for the good way in which it was presented. It is easy to read and it enables us all to have a quick look, first, at the way in which the recommendations have been accepted, modified or not agreed with and, secondly, to see the present situation in the town camps.

I make only one criticism, and it is a general one. I ask the Government to adopt the use of the noun 'Aborigine' rather than 'Aboriginal'. I know that the Department of Aboriginal Affairs adopted this in the early 1970s and both the Department and governments have continued to use this word. I think it is obviously more appropriate, as suggested by the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies, to use the noun 'Aborigine' and the plural 'Aborigines' and retain 'Aboriginal' for the adjective. I commend the Government for its response to this report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join in saying something about the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs which is before us. I have particular pleasure in seeing this report because when I was Minister for Aboriginal Affairs I sent the reference to the Committee. On that occasion I was concerned that the House of Representatives Standing Committee should receive not just a nuts and bolts kind of reference stating: 'Here is the problem'. I did not want the Committee to come back with a shopping list of some kind, saying: 'The way to solve it is to spend money on the following 20 things.' Rather, I wanted it to take under study a matter of real significance to Aboriginal people-and, because of that, to Australia-a matter which it could address in terms of the concepts involved and on which it could make an attempt to advance our thinking and our understanding.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the work done-the Committee attempted to take on the task-is to the credit of the Committee and its Chairman, Mr Ruddock. Any solution which it reaches will involve a set of programs and expenditure proposals. That is inevitable. But the importance of a report like this in the long term will be the extent to which there has been an attempt to derive concepts, to alter our means of thinking, to clarify our understanding of the issues. It is this aspect of the report to which we should turn our attention. Far too often standing committees of the Parliament take on tasks which are not really worthy of their time or effort-jobs which are what one might call pot boilers. This report, which has been done so well, with such application and dedication by the Committee, is not such a task. The very idea of making us think of town campers, to concentrate our minds by way of that description, on where the problem lies is an example of the way the Committee has addressed the real problems which the reference threw up.

There is always a compromise, in terms of a report such as this, as to how far they take the lofty intellectual road to try to make us understand things but do nothing to help the people involved and how far they take the program road which sets out a list of particular proposals. I believe that this is probably the best report the House of Representatives Standing Committee has produced. It is certainly very satisfying to see and to read. I say again that I am very grateful to the Chairman and members of the Committee for what they have produced. I find that I do not agree with some of the dissenting reports, but that again is not in itself a bad thing. They represent certain divisions of view within Australian society. While I do not agree with the members who presented the dissenting reports, I am glad they have taken the matter sufficiently seriously to put down the dissenting reports. I would like to see the many positive recommendations in the report advanced as quickly as possible. I join other senators in hoping that this will occur. Above all, I hope that from reports such as this there can come some real improvement in the problems the Committee addressed so well and so adequately.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too join with Senator Baume and Senator Robertson in congratulating the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs on its report entitled 'The Strategies to Help Overcome the Problems of Aboriginal Town Camps'. I think the Chairman and his Committee have done exceptionally well. The subject is a most difficult one with which to deal and it is very demanding in time. I believe that the Committee has carried out its responsibilities very well. I think the term 'town camps' to some degree is a misnomer in some areas. Although I agree that in some places there are town camps, and 'camps' is the only way of describing them, I think we must look to some of the other places in the Northern Territory where both the Federal Government and the Northern Territory Government have now made very sincere efforts to overcome the housing problem of Aboriginals. Certainly some of the housing projects-I do not like the term 'settlements'-that have been developed in Alice Springs and other places are to be commended. While these projects have come a long way in providing facilities for Aboriginal people and are to be commended I do not say that problem has been overcome; far from it. Much more needs to be done.

SPEECH.PARA: I have also been looking at the Aboriginal Affairs Committee report on Aboriginal hostels. With what has been done in the area of Aboriginal hostels and in improving housing projects for the Aboriginal people, things have come a long way. I believe that the time has now come when we have to extend that development, but I will say more about that when I discuss the Aboriginal hostels report. I say again that it is a most complex situation. Some of the housing projects are working extremely well. Some projects are in tremendous difficulty. I believe that much more work has to be done to ensure that the living conditions of Aboriginal people in town areas is improved. Money is not the only answer. There are also social problems, and I think much more has to be done to assist them.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5 March, on motion by Senator Collard:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been asked to raise the matter of the Industries Assistance Commission report on dried fruits. The report is dated 13 December and it is a very poor, terribly depressing report. I am disappointed that to date the Government has not decided to take some action, contrary to what the report says. We cannot ignore the fact that circumstances over the last 12 months have changed very considerably. There are two main factors affecting this industry. Firstly, there has been an expansion of the world surplus of dried fruits due to the entry of Greece into the European Economic Community, with an expanded production there. Secondly, in Australia, the levying of duty on grape spirit this year will result in considerably less dual purpose grapes going in to spirit and more into dried fruit production.

SPEECH.PARA: The dried fruit industry is demographic by nature. A lot of these areas would be in considerable sociological trouble without the dried fruits industry. Poverty is very high in a lot of these areas. In some places the vast majority of the people involved in the dried fruits business have to seek off-farm income as well. Mr Henry Tankard, the Chairman of the Australian Dried Fruits Association board of management, expressed his disappointment in the Sunraysia Daily of 1 March. He described the response from the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Kerin, as a pathetic non-response. I am sorry that the industry and the Minister are unable to be closer to one another in matters of such importance. I hope that every effort will be made to try to bring the two parties together.

I can quite understand why the industry is disappointed. The three main points that are made in the report are firstly, that rural readjustment is inappropriate; secondly, that there is limited scope for improvement in marketing; and thirdly, that the underwriting situation of 1982, 1983 and 1984 should not be varied. When the industry is in great difficulty as it is now, such negative approach can only make the growers even less inclined to do what they can. What about the positive approach? Who is going to come up with what should be done and how to go about it? I believe there is scope for keeping this industry going. As I said in speaking to an earlier report, Australia produces the best dried fruits in the world. If we are able to develop further the home market and get a reasonable share of the overseas market we should do so. I should have thought that it was far more important for either the IAC or the Cabinet to take some time to determine how we can protect the Australian market, at least for Australian fruit, rather than to sit back and follow its demise. At the same time as the IAC report was being discussed quite substantial quantities of very low priced, very poor quality Greek fruit were coming into Australia. I believe it is important that we endeavour to maintain the standard of dried fruit in Australia. This poor grade fruit should not be brought in. I believe the Government should be monitoring the situation almost on a daily basis. If we can get together over the months ahead I think a plan could be prepared to take care of this situation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5 March, on motion by Senator Colston:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to give a short background to the statement tabled by the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) on 5 March. In October 1979 the Commonwealth and State Minister for Education met as the Australian Education Council. The Ministers decided that college of advanced education and university staff covered by Academic Salaries Tribunal recommendations should be paid the rates recommended by the Tribunal. This decision referred to all staff including vice-chancellors and college principals. The decision of 1979 was confirmed by the Commonwealth and State Ministers in June 1982. Section 42 (2) of the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Act 1981 permits the Minister to reduce grants to tertiary institutions by an amount by which salaries have been paid in excess of those recommended by the Academic Salaries Tribunal. The statement tabled by the Minister sets out the amounts to be subtracted from the various institutions' grants.

SPEECH.PARA: I will mention the situation in Queensland. The University of Queensland had $ 13,000 subtracted from its grant because of overpayments to the vice-chancellor and deputy vice-chancellors. The James Cook University of North Queensland had $ 3,000 subtracted from its grant because of an overpayment to a vice-chancellor. The same amount was deducted from the Griffith University grant and for the same reason. The most amazing consequence of the Minister's announcement was criticism of her by the Minister for Education in Queensland, Mr Powell. I will quote from statements in an article in the Townsville Daily Bulletin that were made either by Mr Powell or the political reporter, John Gagliardi. The article stated:
Senator Ryan has been increasing the strength of her threats over the past six months or so, and has now acted.
By reducing grants to universities, she is imposing what amounts to de facto Federal Government control of university salary levels.
That part of the article was not in quotes so it may have been the political reporter's comments, not Mr Powell's. The article also states that Mr Powell:
. . . told the Bulletin from Brisbane yesterday that Senator Ryan's attitude was ''socialistic'', and she was not recognising the traditional autonomy of universities and university colleges.
Later on the article states:
The amount involved at this stage is believed to be around $20,000.

Of course the amount was not $20,000 at all; in the case of James Cook University of North Queensland it was $3,000. From that article it is patently obvious that Mr Powell does not know that Australia's education Ministers agreed to this course of action. It is also obvious that Mr Powell does not agree with his own Government which has appeared before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission advocating that workers should not get the 4.1 per cent consumer price index increase in their wages and salaries. Apparently Mr Powell applauds the payment of salaries from the public purse above those which are awarded by a proper tribunal. It is time that the Education Minister in Queensland got his act together and understood that if public funds are not being used correctly the responsible Government will act to rectify the position .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue raised by the paper on the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Act is far wider than the issues which Senator Colston has talked about. The issue really goes to questions of institutional autonomy in the tertiary sector. There are some serious unresolved problems, problems which will be very difficult to unravel, which I found difficult when Minister and which I set out to the Australian Vice -Chancellors Committee's conference in 1982. The issue is that the Government paying prices is, in the end, going to want to have some say in certain aspects of policy. On the other hand, the institutions will want to retain for themselves proper autonomy. There is no sharp line between the two and there will be a shifting backwards and forwards on different matters. A very difficult issue between institutions and governments is where the institution can make decisions on its own behalf and put them into effect and where governments, asked to carry the bill, can insist that they have a say in what they see as the public interest. It is a major issue in tertiary education. I say to the Government in a spirit of good will that it is an issue which it will have to take on and consider in some depth and with some sympathy. It is an issue which the former Government had before it.
—Not in Senator Colston's case though. It is quite clear the award sets the wage and they have been giving more.
