—I will come to that in a moment because that is part of the problem. The decision relates to payments made a couple of years ago. I state for the record, because I was approached by one newspaper, that the reason I took no action when I was Minister was that I did not have the returns before me . There is a lag time between the events occurring and the universities and colleges making their returns to the Tertiary Education Commission which, in turn, makes information available to the Minister. The Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, Senator Ryan, has received the information and made decisions which I do not question and with which I have no argument. However the issue does not relate to the James Cook University, the University of New South Wales or Sydney University where small amounts of money were involved. The issue which has been raised is in relation to Senator Crowley's State, to the South Australian Institute of Technology, where a very large amount of money has been withdrawn from its grant. The issue is thrown into sharp accentuation in relation to SAIT. This institution has been caught between the requirements of the Commonwealth Government, laying down a general policy in relation to payments and awards and the Academic Salaries Tribunal, and an institution situated in a State, created under the legislation of a State and required to meet State awards or State negotiations. SAIT has been penalised a very large amount of money for reasons which relate to its position in South Australia as a South Australian institution.

SPEECH.PARA: This issue arises in one other area and that is superannuation payments. The Commonwealth took some action to try to create a new superannuation scheme for tertiary institutions and that scheme was offered to colleges. Many State Governments have refused to allow the colleges to enter that scheme and there could be cost consequences of that State Government decision which could flow to the Commonwealth in years to come. I hope that the Commonwealth will take a similar, firm view in relation to these superannuation matters and will do it perhaps as part of an examination of this difficult interface between institutional autonomy and its needs and the proper role of a Federal Government protecting the taxpayers' interest.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 6 March, on motion by Senator Watson:
That the Senate take note of the papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw the Senate's attention in the time available to me to the fact that there is a continuing problem with Trans Australia Airlines which I believe needs to be rectified. I have spoken to the Senate on a number of occasions about the problems with TAA. I am not talking about its service in any way at all. I am talking about its capital construction , its operating expense construction, the impact of the way in which it draws its accounts on the Independent Air Fares Committee's operations and the comparability between Trans Australia Airlines and the other member of what at the moment is a duopoly, Ansett Airlines of Australia. In particular I draw attention to the Auditor-General's report of 24 February 1984. On page 2, in relation to interest payable, he sets out his disagreement with Trans Australia Airlines about the way in which its accounts are prepared. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: I do not agree with the Commission's treatment of interest payable on moneys borrowed to purchase aircraft that have been brought into service. In my view these expenses are a charge against revenue of the year in which they fall due for payment.

As detailed in Notes 1 (h) and 1 (j) of the statements submitted under sub- clauses 13 (1) (a) and (b) respectively the practice of capitalising interest payment on aircraft had resulted in the total expenses and hence the net loss for the year being understated-
I emphasise this-

That means that the total loss for TAA for the year-if one adds to it the loss disclosed in its profit and loss account which appears on a later page of the document and which shows a net loss for the year of $12,664,000-is $22,284,000. The Auditor-General goes on to say:

In addition the net amount of interest not expended in previous years amounts to $23.977m. This sum, together with the interest expense of $9.620m understated in the current year means that the book value of aircraft and thus the equity of the Commonwealth Government-
that is, the Australian taxpayer-
as at 30 June 1983 as shown in the sub-clause 13 (1) (b) Balance Sheet is overstated by $33.579m.

I do not think that this is a matter for the Senate chamber to debate, other than to draw attention to it-I see that Senator Coates, the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, is present-and to hope that the appropriate committee, which certainly is Senator Coates's committee, will endeavour to bring about some reconciliation between TAA and the Auditor-General so that the accounts can be prepared on an agreed basis and a basis which can be accepted by everybody as accurately reflecting the operations of that airline during the year. We have had a continuing problem in regard to different attitudes towards superannuation which made a difference of some $240m . We now have a further difference of some $24m being referred to by the Auditor -General. These sums just cannot be ignored. They are matters which we cannot just let go by. I do not wish to intervene ahead of the Chairman of the Committee. Therefore I conclude my remarks

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I assure Senator Peter Rae and the Senate that the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations still has this matter under investigation. In fact, it was dealt with only yesterday at a Committee meeting. I hope that it will not be too much longer before the matter is resolved.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That a Joint Select Committee be appointed to inquire into and report upon the conduct of the judge referred to in the tapes and transcripts delivered by the Age newspaper to the Attorney-General on 1 February 1984 and in particular the question whether the judge may have been guilty of misbehaviour or may have revealed any incapacity which could amount to sufficient grounds for an address to the Governor-General in Council from both Houses of the Parliament praying for his removal from office pursuant to section 72 (II) of the Constitution.
(2) That provisions relating to membership, powers and proceedings of the Committee be contained in a subsequent Resolution.
(3) That the inquiry commence after the polling day of the New South Wales election.
(4) That the foregoing Resolution be communicated to the House of Representatives by Message, requesting its concurrence in the Resolution.

The proposal by the Opposition to establish a joint select committee to investigate this matter arises from the debates which have taken place in this chamber over the past two weeks since the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans ) made a statement about this matter on 28 February, the first day of sitting. The attitudes of the Government and the Opposition in relation to these matters are, I believe, very clearly drawn as a result of those lengthy debates, the number of questions asked of the Attorney-General and his answers to them. I do not propose to canvass them again. Suffice it to say that the Opposition first sought to assert the role of Parliament in this matter by moving for the tabling of the transcripts and the transcripts of any tapes that had not been transcribed with the deletion of all identifying names and characteristics in order to protect the privacy of the people concerned and particularly that of the judge, although we are concerned about everybody's right to privacy and not just that of the judge. The object of that exercise was to enable Parliament to make a judgment about this matter for itself. However, the Senate did not agree to that proposition, although on the part of the Australian Democrats there was quite considerable support for the principle behind it. I welcomed that support from them. It seemed to the Opposition that, in the light of the broadly favourable response to its case that the role lay with Parliament, the appropriate parliamentary role should take the form of a joint select committee. That is the object of the motion I have moved.
'Age' Tapes

The reason the Opposition proposes the establishment of a joint select committee is that this is a matter essentially for both Houses of Parliament. Neither one House nor the other can make any effective decisions alone in relation to the question of the grounds for removal of a judge. Both Houses must pray for his or her removal through the Governor-General in Council. I believe that the appropriate first step is for the matter to be fully investigated and a report made to both Houses of the Parliament. On the basis of the committee's report, both Houses will be in a position to make a judgment as to whether they should or should not pray for removal of the judge. The appropriate decision then will be able to be made. In the first instance, of course, the Parliament needs to be advised of the facts. As all parliamentary committees have certain powers and have a fine record of exercising their duty in these matters, the object of this committee will be to obtain those facts. That will certainly involve the question of the authenticity of the tapes. I believe that, on the basis of the motion I have moved, the committee will have those powers. That is the exercise upon which the committee works embark. The role of the committee- although perhaps, as has been pointed out to me, the motion does not quite clearly delineate this-would be to investigate the conduct of the judge as revealed in the tapes and transcripts. That would be the role of the committee and the limitations on the Committee. It would not be a wide-ranging inquiry. I understand that there will be further discussion about that in the course of the debate, but it certainly was my intention in moving the motion that the judge's conduct would be within the four corners of the material referred to in the motion, which material hopefully will be available to the proposed committee. I hope that, if the motion is carried, the Government will co-operate, make that material available and not take the stance that it has been taking here in relation to this chamber in refusing to table it. I do not think other aspects of the motion require any further elaboration by me. We want the Parliament to vote upon the principle of this exercise, and the matters relating to the membership, powers and so on of the committee can be subject to further motions and debate.

The only other explanation I should make is in relation to the third part of the motion, that is, that the inquiry commence after the polling day of the New South Wales election. As events are developing, that would seem to be now inevitable because of time constraints, with both Houses rising later today. Nevertheless, in view of the concerns expressed about this matter being mixed up with the politics of the New South Wales election, we want to emphasise that we do not see this as part and parcel of that election. But it is a very major issue for the Parliament, as it is for the judiciary. It is a question which goes very much to the basis of our Constitution. The standing and independence of the judiciary are, of course, at stake. That is the reason why the Opposition sought to make that matter clear in the third limb of the motion.

One further point I would like to make in concluding my remarks is that we believe it is proper for both Houses of Parliament to be involved in this exercise. Nevertheless, it would be quite appropriate for the Senate itself to embark on this inquiry and to report to the Senate. That would be a second best, but is certainly an altenative which the Opposition has in mind if, in the event , the Government takes the same intransigent attitude to the role of Parliament which has been exhibited not only by the stance that the Attorney-General has taken in this place but also by the stance which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Government as a whole have taken.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support the thrust of the motion moved by Senator Durack, namely, we support the concept of a joint select committee of both Houses to inquire into the matter. However, I will move the amendment which was circulated in my name two or three hours ago and which refines the motion moved by Senator Durack. The cleanest way in which I can do so is to move that all words after ' report upon' be left out and other words inserted so that the motion will read:

SPEECH.PARA: That a Joint Select Committee be appointed to inquire into and report upon:
(a) whether any or all of the tapes and transcripts delivered by the Age newspaper to the Attorney-General on 1 February 1984 are authentic and genuine;

It must be remembered that almost daily in these two weeks of sitting, each of four days, both Houses of Parliament have been dealing with tapes, and transcripts from tapes, and that nobody, to my knowledge, knows who did them. Nobody knows whether it was an Australian Federal policeman off duty, a New South Wales State policeman or a private person. That they were obtained illegally is sure. That some of the transcripts cannot be matched by tapes is sure. Therefore, I would have thought that one of the first functions of a joint select committee would be to discover the authenticity or otherwise of the tapes and transcripts. Notwithstanding the status of the tapes and transcripts, reputations and careers have now been put in jeopardy by statements that have been made on the basis of the tapes in this Parliament, in the Queensland Parliament and elsewhere. Having said that, let me not be regarded for one moment as suggesting, as the Attorney-General did, that the Age newspaper acted in any way improperly or imprudently in publishing the tapes. I commend it again for its actions. It tried to discover authenticity and genuineness to the best of its ability before publication, and I believe that the Age newspaper has done the community an enormous service.

It is unfortunate that the matter has been politicised for two weeks. One can say, with the wisdom of hindsight, that all this garbage we have listened to over the past two weeks could have been resolved on the first day Parliament resumed had the Government adopted this move of referring it to a joint select committee of both Houses or had the Government agreed with my suggestion of referring the whole matter to someone like Costigan. But the Government, for the good reasons that Senator Gareth Evans has advanced, along with other not so good reasons, has decided to sweat it out. The Government ought to recognise that, notwithstanding the New South Wales election, this is one issue that cannot be toughed out. It is one issue that just will not go away. If I could give gratuitous advice to the Government, it would be in its interests to wipe the slate clean as soon as possible and discover the truth. Therefore, the Democrats believe that one of the functions of the committee would be to decide whether the tapes are authentic and genuine. That would certainly give the committee the opportunity of calling before it the solicitor and the judge involved, and of saying to them: 'Did you say something like this? If not, would you like to correct the public record by saying that you did not say it or that you said it in some context other than that reported?'. It seems an eminently fair and proper exercise. Some members of this Parliament owe that judge the opportunity to clear his name of any suggestion of wrong-doing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you accept the appropriateness of those proceedings operating in camera?

—Not necessarily, but it may well be that those proceedings should be conducted in camera. That is why the Democrats are attracted to the concept of a select committee. Even the Attorney-General has been fair enough to agree that Parliament has a responsibility to determine whether the behaviour of the judge involved is such as would offend section 72 of the Constitution.

SPEECH.PARA: What do we mean by the Parliament? I do not think any people in their right mind in this Parliament would suggest that Parliament sit as a whole-all the 64 senators and the 124 members of the House of Representatives-have the tapes dumped on the table and call the judge and the solicitor before it. What an absurd circus that would be. One certain result would be that justice would not be done. It would be the greatest political grandstanding of all time. That is clearly an absurd proposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what you have to do at the end of the road, though , if you want to get right down to section 72.

—Not necessarily. Joint select committees have a reputation in this place of being able to shed party politicking from their activities and approach a problem with an objectivity that we cannot manage on the floor of this chamber. I would hope that there will be a minimum of party politicking when the report of the joint select committee or the senate select committee, as the case may be, is finally laid on the tables of the Parliament. We would support the logical definition of that statement, that Parliament must resolve the issue, in that a committee of the Parliament-preferably, as Senator Durack says, of both Houses-should do the homework. To protect the innocent I believe that some, if not a great proportion, of the evidence would have to be heard in camera. Because of the notoriety of the information given, it would be desirable that most of the evidence be heard in public. I asked yesterday: Why harm people who are clearly and palpably innocent of any wrong doing or guilt by association if in the public interest members of that committee, of all political parties, deem that the evidence could best be heard in camera? Again, after acknowledging the suggestion that Senator Gareth Evans put forward, I say that as far as is possible, honourable and practicable, the evidence should be heard in public.
—Do you mean that your paragraph (a) must be satisfied before you go to paragraph (b)?
—I am coming to that. My amendment, in sub-paragraph (b), will then read:

SPEECH.PARA: whether the conduct of the judge as revealed in the tapes and transcripts referred to in sub-paragraph (a) constituted misbehaviour or incapacity which could amount to sufficient grounds for an address to the Governor-General in Council from both Houses of the Parliament praying for his removal from office pursuant to section 72 (ii) of the Constitution.

Clearly, in answer to Senator Tate's interjection, sub-paragraph (a) does not have to be satisfied before the committee can go to sub-paragraph (b). In the unlikely event that the committee reaches a firm conclusion that the tapes are utterly false, clearly the committee would have no cause to go to sub-paragraph (b). But the Senate will notice that there has been a refinement, by the Democrats' amendment, of the original Liberal notice of motion. We were not satisfied with the original Liberal Party motion, which said that the Committee shall inquire upon the conduct of the judge referred to in the tapes and transcripts delivered to the Age and so on. That seemed to us to be so open ended that it would enable the committee to inquire into the judge's conduct on a whole range of matters over an unlimited period, and on unrelated matters. So we have tied the committee's scope to those allegations as are revealed in the transcripts and the tapes. I repeat: There is no necessity for the committee to prove the tapes to be authentic before proceeding to discuss that. In other words, under both of these headings the committee will be empowered to call the judge, the solicitor, whomsoever it may please, to elicit the truth.

I repeat that I believe the judge concerned will welcome this opportunity, which is virtually the first real opportunity he will have to put his side of the case to representatives of the Parliament, as distinct from a representative of the Executive, in the person of the Attorney-General. We hope that the Government will agree to the House of Representatives joining in this joint House exercise, notwithstanding the immediate response from the Prime Minister ( Mr Hawke) that it would not have a bar of it. I think that those were his words. Without being patronising or seeming to teach one's grandmother to suck eggs, I put this simple point to the Government: If the House of Representatives refuses to join with the Senate in this exercise, one thing is certain. When it comes back here, if the Liberal Party does not move that a Senate select committee be appointed to undertake this task the Democrats will.

TALK.START.PARA: —We shall.

—I acknowledge Senator Chaney's interjection. Therefore, I respond by saying that if in that event the Liberal Party moves a motion along those lines, it will have the Democrats' support. The difference for the Government would be that if it is a joint exercise, I imagine that the Government would have at least some say in the business and control over it. It would be able to appoint its own chairman and would have some say in the running of it. It does not necessarily have that privilege if the matter comes back here and the Senate , in which the Government does not have the numbers, determines the committee's terms of reference and numbers, and so on. I am not suggesting that the Government has anything to hide. What I am suggesting is that about the last thing the Labor Party would want would be a Senate select committee over which it has no control roaming at large in this minefield.
—What if that joint committee had people such as Hodgman on it? Would that not make impossible any rational consideration of this matter? I ask that as a serious question.

—I am very tempted to answer the Attorney-General's interjection, because I think it is a fair question. However, I shall resist the temptation, because I would be hopeful that the Democrats will be represented on the committee and it is not impossible that I might be the Democrats representative on the committee. It would be improper for me to respond to the interjection, tempting though that is, as the Attorney would recognise.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I make this appeal to the Government. The motion will be passed in the Senate this afternoon and will go to the House of Representatives. Clearly, the House of Representatives will not contemplate it this afternoon. So, in the calmer days of the two-week recess it will be contemplated first by the Cabinet. I appeal to those ministerial senators to put to the Cabinet the proposition as put by Senator Durack. I commend him and the Liberal Party for showing good faith in trying to make it a joint house exercise. They could have scored a few cheap political points by moving for a Senate select committee. They have not done that; they have done the decent and proper thing. It gives the Government opportunity to make it an all-party affair, a both Houses affair.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because both Houses are involved.

—Yes, and because of the gravity of the matter. A senior Federal judge is involved. Because of the gravity of the matter, this would be an appropriate course. I hope that the Ministers in the Senate will put that point before Cabinet when the matter is discussed during the next two weeks. Therefore , I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Paragraph (1), leave out all words after ''report upon'', insert:
(a) whether any or all of the tapes and transcripts delivered by the Age newspaper to the Attorney-General on 1 February 1984 are authentic and genuine; and

(b) whether the conduct of the judge as revealed in the tapes and transcripts referred to in sub-paragraph (a) constituted misbehaviour or incapacity which could amount to sufficient grounds for an address to the Governor-General in Council from both Houses of the Parliament praying for his removal from office pursuant to section 72 (II) of the Constitution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will appreciate that I have not entered into the debate on these tapes at any stage. I have deliberately not done so for two reason. One is that along with, I believe, other senators I am deeply concerned about the distribution of documents and tapes which are able to be used publicly against citizens, whether they be judges, racial groups or individuals. Because I have an ingrained aversion to the fact that, presumably, the tapes were illegally provided to the news media I have not even read the publications. I have, of course, heard the debate in this chamber. Therefore, I am aware of the personalities who are alleged to be involved in the tapes.

SPEECH.PARA: I will come shortly to the question of my responsibility and the responsibility of the Senate As somebody said, one cannot just shoot the messenger and forget about the message. One is faced with a responsibility and one must honour one's obligations. But I believe that this Parliament, before today, has been faced with similar circumstances and that action taken in this chamber has not reflected very well so far as human liberties and the free access of the individual to due process are concerned. I will deal shortly with my own individual case. I have been on the receiving end of many anonymous documents over the years.

Racial groups in this community have suffered because trayloads of documents have been placed on the Senate table. Names have been mentioned and that fact has been used against those individuals. It is almost 11 years-it was in March 1973-since, I believe, one of the most disastrous attacks on civil liberties was perpetrated in the Senate when the then Attorney-General, Senator Lionel Murphy, tabled in excess of 2,000 pages of documents. Senator Murphy claimed:
The documents constitute evidence that Croatian terrorist organisations exist in Australia and have so existed for many years.

The documents contained reference to the names of 857 Croatians who were either current or former residents of Australia. The documents had either been intercepted by police or security authorities or obtained in raids on the homes of Croatians. In the subsequent Senate inquiry the then Commissioner of Commonwealth Police and witnesses from the Department of Immigration denied that they had been consulted about the declassification of the documents.

It is clear that the decision to declassify the documents and table them was made by the then Attorney-General himself. In the context in which they were tabled many innocent Australians of Croatian origin and their families and relatives were implied to be somehow involved in terrorist organisations. In some cases the listed names were those of people who had innocently contributed to raffles in fund raising drives not knowing that their contributions might have been misused for other purposes. The 857 people whose names were listed on the 2,000 pages of documents were never given the opportunity to defend their reputations. So great was the interest in the matter that a special committee room was established for persons seeking to obtain those names. The clerks at the table would recall that. It is possible-only history will indicate whether this is the case-that some of the material was used to the detriment of a small number of Australians then in prison in Yugoslavia for political crimes. Certainly, it is public knowledge that three imprisoned Australians of Croatian origin were executed by firing squad around this time.

As I have said, I have been concerned about the distribution of anonymous blackguarding material. I have been in receipt of a lot of such material over a period of years. Some of this material was presented in this Parliament in 1975. Strangely enough, the publication Socialists and Industrial Labour carried a fair bit of this anonymous, slanderous type of material. One day I got a bit sick of it and tried to sue the named publisher of the paper. He had an address in Kings Cross in Sydney. When the solicitor went there to serve the writ he discovered that the chap had been dead for five years. This sort of thing goes on all the time. In fact, accusations went on to such an extent that in 1968 at the Federal Executive meeting of the Labor Party I was declared, by nine votes to seven, not to be a fit and proper person to take my seat on the Federal Executive of the Party. I will come in a moment to the person who cast the ninth vote. The then secretary of the Labor Party, Mr Cyril Wyndham, in a statement to the Melbourne Observer on 15 August 1971, said:

Exactly the same thing happened over the infamous Harradine case. Even now, with so many years passed, I still feel a keen sense of dirtiness about having been a passive participant-passive, that is, at the actual conference table-in one of the most unseemly episodes of sheer naked force and inhumanity that I have ever seen.

During my association with the Labor Party, I have sat through many trials when people were up for expulsion. I have expelled some and even pronounced the sentence. I have also saved some from expulsion.
So disciplinary cases were not new to me. But the Harradine trial was a monstrous occasion.
Harradine sat through gruelling days of what must have been agony-with upwards of 10 prosecuting lawyers, but not one defending council.
Even his co-delegate, Doug Lowe, from Tasmania, was circumvented in what he could do to defend him.
Not once was any specific charge laid against Harradine, but he was remorselessly questioned, and badgered, and hammered.
All the normal laws of evidence and justice were thrown carelessly out of the window as some ruthless men had a heyday at his expense.
Max Walsh, in an article in the Australian Quarterly in June 1968, said:

Senator Murphy, a Q.C. and a prominent defender of civil liberties, demonstrated a surprising lack of sensitivity to either his legal training or moral proclamations when during the process of cross-examining Harradine ( according to the minutes) he asked, ''Was Harradine prepared to withdraw in writing, to be signed by him and for publication the following, that he ' unconditionally and without prevarication that he does not suggest and will not suggest that any members of the Federal Executive or any of the State Executives of the A.L.P. is a communist or a pro-communist or a friend of the communists' ' ' . . . Harradine replied no, because he had not said the things suggested.
Mr Walsh goes on:
The minutes show that Harradine was subjected to a gruelling cross-examination solely on the basis of hearsay evidence throughout Wednesday and Thursday.

For some honourable senators 1968 might be a long time ago but it is very fresh in my memory. That is the second reason why I have refused to enter into any of this debate. I do not believe that the principle of propter affectum applies as far as the Senate is concerned. Fortunately, or unfortunately, it cannot apply because in the end the Parliament must make the judgments. It may well be that this is one of the penalties of appointing active politicians to the High Court of Australia. This is something that presumably did not occur to the founding fathers, who were largely a group of independents loosely connected with trade parties, protectionists and so on. But where one has the situation of a person being deeply involved in the party political toing and froing of a democracy and then going to the High Court, it raises some very important questions.

The dictum of propter affectum applies in respect of jurors. The accused can obviously challenge a juror on the basis of propter affectum either for suspicion or partiality, which is either a principal challenge, as is the case where the juror is of kin to either party or has an interest in the cause, or a challenge to the favour where there is merely a probability of bias.

Even though it is very clear in my mind after all those years, I feel I could put that aside. I suppose without declaring this interest, as I am doing in the Senate, I could have jumped into this debate boots and all and tipped buckets here, there and everywhere, but I believed that that was not my role as a member of parliament. It is my role as a member of parliament to ensure that the rights of all individuals, including judges, and all groups, including racial groups, in our community ought to be upheld and properly upheld.

I understand that one has an obligation ultimately under section 72 of the Constitution. That obligation will be honoured by me if the time comes. At that time and between now and that time I will treat the matters on their merits. But I hope that my colleagues on both sides of the Senate chamber will excuse me from being a member of that select committee if it is established. I would like to see what recommendations come from that committee from persons of good will and persons of reason after having examined the whole case.

I would have hoped that this result could be achieved in some other way; that is, without the establishment of a select committee. However, we have reached this stage. I felt that I needed to explain my situation to the Senate despite the fact that it gives me a little pain to explain it. At this stage I do not desire to be available for the select committee if requested-I will not be-when it is established.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will oppose this motion even in the slightly more acceptable form represented by the Australian Democrats' amendment. I say 'slightly more acceptable' because although, on the face of it, the Democrats' amendment is much more attractive, focusing specifically as it does on the authenticity issue in a way that the original motion does not, nonetheless, as Senator Chipp was frank enough to acknowledge, the language of the amendment is couched in such a way that the committee will not be obliged to satisfy itself about the authenticity of this material before it goes on to consider and draw conclusions about the larger questions as to whether or not misbehaviour has occurred. In a sense, while not quite going so far as to say it is fraudulent to have the references there in those terms, it is the case that the authenticity issue may be one that regrettably the committee, if it is established, will feel itself able to slide over pretty quickly.

SPEECH.PARA: The reasons for our opposition to referring this matter to any kind of parliamentary committee will come as no surprise to anyone who has been following the endless debates on this matter over the last two weeks. Essentially, there are two inter-related propositions: Firstly, there is nothing in the material which justifies a full scale parliamentary investigation given the constitutional responsibilities of Parliament in relation to the judiciary. Secondly, there are very real dangers involved in setting the precedent of a full scale parliamentary committee investigation in the circumstances of this kind of case where the material is, as we all know, anonymous, unauthenticated, clearly illegal to the extent that it is authentic, and manifestly grossly invasive of personal privacy. We believe, and we do so quite frankly and sincerely, that to mount an investigation of the kind that is here contemplated on the basis of material as tenuous and as insubstantial as this will really constitute an open invitation to damaging but ill-founded attacks being made on public figures in the hope simply, of course, that some of the mud will stick. We do not believe that Parliament as an institution should lend itself and its dignity to this kind of exercise.

As to the material that is involved in this case, one or two more things need to be said. The motion quite properly confines its attention to the grounds under section 72 of the Constitution for considering judicial behaviour. But we say that it is clear that section 72 involves only two grounds for possible attack on a particular judge: Firstly, as I have said a thousand times, criminal misconduct of a kind that does not sit with continued occupancy of that office or, secondly, misbehaviour that is directly related to the conduct of judicial office even if falling short of criminality. That is clear, as we have discussed over and over again, from the opinion of the Solicitor-General and the opinion of Mr Temby. Although I know Mr Temby's opinion has been contested in some quarters of this Parliament, nonetheless I believe it has very real force behind it and is such that a committee looking at it carefully and properly would inevitably come to that conclusion. We also believe it is clear on the materials which we have examined very carefully, as have the police, as has Mr Temby, that the judge is simply not caught up in either of those two standard and only components of section 72. That is the position which we have stated over and over again, that at the end of the road, at the end of the day, what one is left with is something much less than criminal misconduct or activity directly related to judicial office-if anything at all.

We ask, as the Opposition has pointed out over and over again, for the Parliament to take us on trust in that respect-if not me, if not the Government on trust, certainly Mr Temby and certainly the Solicitor-General on the question of law involved. The reason we ask Parliament to take us on trust in this respect rather than have Parliament insist on going through the process of inquiry itself, which is its prerogative I readily acknowledge under section 72 of the Constitution, is once again because of the nature of the material here in issue-I can only repeat the point so many times without boring everyone-its anonymity, its unauthenticated character, its illegality and its grossly invasive of privacy character. There are very real dangers under those circumstances of Parliament getting involved in this sort of exercise. We ask that Parliament exercise self-restraint.

So far we believe from asserting the invincibility of parliamentary sovereignty , so far from improving the quality of parliamentary democracy by embarking on this sort of enterprise, the Government believes that to do so is to write a game plan for, ultimately, the destruction of democratic and libertarian values in this country. The reality is that an inquiry like this, whatever its procedures may prove to be, cannot occur without people getting hurt. Even if the people whose reputations are right on the firing line come up smelling like roses at the end of the process of the scrutiny of this inquiry, there is no doubt that they will suffer as people before them have suffered in those series of recent royal commissions which have produced a clean bill of health for the people centrally involved. There is no doubt that the people will suffer hurt, humiliation and pain while that process is working itself out.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are suffering now.

—I do not stop to comment upon the hypocrisy of those who have created the very issue now crying that the issue can be resolved only by some further continuation of the circus that has already occurred. The point I make though about that hurt, humiliation and pain is not simply one that bears upon the personal experiences of those who are involved and are going to be involved. In the case of the judiciary, it has consequences that are considerably more important. It is not just a matter of making the position of the individual judge concerned impossible, but really it goes to the whole question of the credibility and capacity of the judicial institution to stay intact. How can it be business as usual for the court involved, for the judge involved, more particularly, while this particular process is working itself out ? The nature of the whole enterprise is such that that simply cannot be the case . What we ask would appear to be a quixotic question at this stage of the business because minds are apparently made up. The Parliament, this Senate, should think very carefully indeed about whether the likely end of this particular road, given what we know of the opinions, the conclusions of others who have objectively considered this material, justifies the means that are now contemplated.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Senate does vote to establish a joint select committee-we hope that the situation will not arise, but it may well do in a few minutes time-the Government will give very serious consideration to its attitude, both to the establishment of such a committee and its operation before the motion comes on for debate in the House of Representatives. We will do so against the background of Senator Durack's not very subtly concealed threat, reinforced of course by Senator Chipp's comments, to go down the path of a Senate committee in the event that the joint committee is not accepted. Among the matters to which we will be giving very careful consideration if this motion is passed will be the composition and especially the procedures of the proposed committee and whether the proposed procedures-we have no motion before us in this respect-are likely to be satisfactory to protect, so far as is possible to do so, the privacy, confidentiality and liberty of the individuals concerned while the committee is formulating its views.

Certainly I hope that if a committee in any form is established, very careful attention is paid to the principle of avoiding publicity while an investigation is proceeding. There will be no one on trial in the context of a parliamentary committee exercise. Charges have not been laid. It is wildly premature to contemplate their being laid. It may look like a trial in many respects and certainly that has been the experience already in what has occurred. It is one way of characterising it. It will go on being a trial, a trial by media, a trial by innuendo, but it has to be appreciated when one is engaged in essentially an investigative exercise, as this will be, that the same sorts of principles ought to apply as I have argued over and over again should apply to the kind of criminal investigation process through crimes commissions and royal commissions and so on. But they are matters that can be subjects of further discussion should the occasion arise.

I hope and the Government hopes that the situation will not arise, that we will not have to give consideration to all these particular questions. We hope that ultimately the view will prevail in the Senate that there are very real dangers, dangers that are almost impossible to overstate in any further consideration of a matter of the kind that is contemplated. To repeat, I am not asking the Senate to accept my views, the Government's views, but rather to be receptive to the conclusions, the very careful and well reasoned conclusions I believe, of independent credible third parties, men of integrity and competence such as the Director of Public Prosecutions and the Solicitor-General. We hope that for all these reasons, despite the apparent inevitability of it, the committee will reject the motion in question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to say one or two words in reply on the motion. I am pleased that Senator Chipp, on behalf of the Australian Democrats, has indicated his support in principle. He has moved an amendment to my motion which I can only readily concede improves it considerably and gives effect, in very clear terms, to what was certainly always the Opposition's intention. When I moved the motion I understood that the Senate would be acting responsibly, as parliamentary committees do in these matters, and that it would give great attention to the authenticity of the material. I am happy that that has been emphasised. The conduct of the judge would be confined to the conduct as revealed in the material.

SPEECH.PARA: The Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) in his response pointed out that the committee could virtually ignore limb (a) and just concentrate on limb (b) of the motion. I suggest that that would be a totally irresponsible approach by a committee because, as has been pointed out over and over again in these debates, the Constitution requires proved misbehaviour and incapacity and, therefore, the committee's attention, if it has been directed to this question- which is the constitutional responsibility of Parliament-must have regard to the required proof. There is no dispute on the part of the Opposition that the Parliament must be satisfied with an adequate form of proof on these matters. Therefore, the question of authenticity would, clearly, be on the threshold for such a committee.

I am disappointed but not surprised at the response of the Attorney-General, although I felt, despite all the heat, fervour and whatever that has gone on in this place for the last eight days on this subject, that perhaps we are proceeding to a calmer and more rational approach on the part of the Government. I hope that if the motion is passed the Attorney-General and the Government- because this matter does not depend on the Attorney-General alone-will tackle the problem presented by it in an attitude of reason and good will and that this matter may be brought to a satisfactory conclusion.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is: That the words proposed to be left out by Senator Chipp's amendment be left out.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is: That the words proposed to be inserted by Senator Chipp's amendment be inserted.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Durack's), as amended, be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 1 March, on motion by Senator Missen:
That the Senate-
(a) deplores the decision of the Victorian Government to close (and sell) 4 hostels which were used for the accommodation of more than 200 country students in the Melbourne metropolitan area;

(b) condemns the failure of the Australian and Victorian Governments to accede to widespread complaints made by rural councils, student organisations and concerned parents against this decision which is a clear breach of ALP education policy; and

(c) urges the Australian Government to reach early agreement with the Victorian Government providing for the continued financing of the hostels so that essential facilities exist for country students seeking to acquire tertiary education.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have a great deal to add to what I said when we debated this matter last week. The Government is very sympathetic towards the accommodation needs of students and, as I pointed out previously, we have asked the Tertiary Education Commission to review the whole question. It will advise me shortly about what steps we can take in the next Budget to give assistance to students on an equitable basis. The situation with regard to the particular hostels that Senator Missen talked about last week-those hostels which the Victorian Minister of Education has decided to sell-is that the hostels are being sold, but two hostels, Frank Tait House and Minimbah, continue to have places available for students. As at 7 March about half of the 78 places had not been taken up, which is rather an interesting result, given all the news we have had about the shortage of places and the need for students, particularly country students, to find hostel accommodation.

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot explain why half of those places that are available have not been taken up. The Victorian Minister has also had discussions with student housing officers to keep them informed of the State Government's thinking on student housing. The Chairman of the Victorian Post-Secondary Education Commission has commenced discussions with various agencies concerning the possible use of other hostels by students. The Victorian Education Minister has established a steering committee to inquire into student housing problems in Melbourne with particular emphasis on first year students. That committee is chaired by the Chairman of the Victorian Post-Secondary Education Commission. Obviously the Victorian Government is very well aware of the problems that have been created by the decision to sell the hostels and is taking constructive steps to get advice on how they can be overcome. Similarly we are doing this at the tertiary level.

I conclude my remarks by repeating that the Commonwealth had no capacity to purchase those hostels or to run them. The hostels would need to be taken over and run by individual institutions. It is not something that the Commonwealth is able to get into at this stage. The new forms of assistance that we will have available for student accommodation will need to wait until the Budget decisions .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the Australian Democrats will support Senator Missen's motion in relation to colleges in Victoria. Because of the briefness of time available I will curtail the remarks I had intended to make. I want to make some points in relation to previous statements by the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan). The Minister said this in relation to what the Government intended to do:

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Government, having as it does the strategies for increased participation in higher education-in particular increasing participation by previously disadvantaged groups-is very aware of the need to have available low cost accommodation for tertiary students.
I think this is extremely important.

TALK.START.PARA: —They could have put some money out to back that idea.

—I think that is a sentiment which would be supported by all honourable senators in this place. However, the problem facing us in relation to the hostel situation in Victoria is a very pressing one since the auction is advertised for 27 March. Therefore, I believe that urgent action is required. If indeed, as the Minister has indicated, there will be a review undertaken in that area it seems to me to be appropriate that there be a stay of execution on these hostels pending the results of the review. This is particularly necessary because of the make-up of the students. It has already been said but I think it is worth repeating that in the submission by the Students Housing Officers Association of Victoria in relation to the 369 students in the hostels last year it was stated that 63 per cent of them were women. Some 68 per cent of the students had attended State high schools rather than independent schools and 62 per cent were on tertiary education assistance scheme finance. I think that suggests a profile of probably the major disadvantaged group. If one wished to break the students up into the four categories of urban males, urban females, rural males and rural females, obviously the group most disadvantaged would be the rural female group. The profile of the people living in these hostels is precisely that.

SPEECH.PARA: I would have thought that in terms of the oft-expressed wish-I know it is a very firmly held belief in the mind of the Minister in relation to disadvantaged groups-we ought to look again at this profile, particularly as 68 per cent of those students attended State high schools, not independent schools. If one looks at the profile in the institutions that is quite different. We are looking here at a particular group of people who have difficulties.

A further point is that nearly 60 per cent of these students are undertaking teaching courses. The Australian Democrats in Victoria undertook a survey of their own in relation to these students. In the interviews we had with the students the overwhelming majority said that upon completion of their teaching education they wished to teach in the country. As anyone would know, one of the major difficulties in relation to teaching in the country in Australia is that the teachers tend to turn over very rapidly. The quality of education in the country is below that in the city because of the demand by teachers to be transferred back to the city. If here we have a group of people who wish to teach in the country, who come from country areas, who are women and who come from State school backgrounds, I would have thought, putting all those things together, that this Government, in terms of the things it has been talking about , would be most anxious to support them. Indeed, I would have thought that that would have been the Government's No. 1 priority.

I will not have time to raise the various other items that I wanted to. The last point which I think is worth mentioning is that the accommodation we are talking about is for students in colleges of advanced education, not universities. Only a very small percentage-I think less than 10 per cent-of students in that accommodation is going to universities. We are talking about people at CAE level. In Victoria none of the CAE institutions have any accommodation. That is different from universities which have colleges and so on which do take up part of the problem. The CAEs do not have any accommodation. Therefore, these hostels are providing accommodation for a group of institutions which are not provided for. If one looks at the pressure on housing within any of our major cities, the difficulty of finding low cost accommodation which is adequate to the task is very difficult. If this group of people has already had difficulty in getting to the tertiary institution level, to impose this additional problem on them runs against all the policies that the Government has been enunciating.

I believe that the suggestion which has been put forward by Senator Missen, that there be a stay of execution for one year pending the results of the Commonwealth's own inquiry into student housing, is admirable. The total all up cost is really quite small in comparison to the disadvantage that will be felt by a considerable number of people. I would urge, if the Senate supports this motion, that the Minister look again at the problem to see whether it might be possible to hold open these institutions, at least for that short period pending the results of her own inquiry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a motion moved by my colleague from Victoria, Senator Missen, deploring the decision of the Victorian Government to close and sell four hostels which were used for the accommodation of more than 200 country students in the Melbourne metropolitan area, condemning the failure of the Australian and Victorian Governments to get together to try to resolve this problem and urging a solution to the problem. I do not intend to cover the ground already covered by Senator Missen last week in his excellent speech on this subject. As usual he has done his homework well and again has demonstrated his care and compassion. As Senator Macklin pointed out, Victorian country students, and in particular country women, are being discriminated against by both the Federal and State Ministers for Education who have shown callous disregard for the plight of some 300 Victorian country students who, through their actions, have now lost access to low cost hostel accommodation. As Senator Macklin pointed out, unless this matter is resolved by 27 March these hostels will have been sold at public auction and the opportunity will have gone forever.

SPEECH.PARA: On 6 October last year I raised the question of the disposal of a number of hostels in response to representations made to me by many Liberal Victorian members of parliament. I think in particular of John Radford from Bendigo, but others, such as Tom Austin, John Delzoppo, Harley Dickensen, Bill Ebery, Lou Lieberman, Don McKellar, Tom Evans, Tom Reynolds and Adam Kempton, have made representations to us Victorians. They were trying desperately to get the Cain Labor Government in Victoria to have some compassion for country students. The Cain Labor Government was pushing the matter off to the Government in Canberra and it could not get any solution. We could not get any solution to the problem here either. When I put the matter to Senator Ryan on 6 October 1983 she blamed the postal strike for lack of advice from her Victorian colleague, Mr Fordham, and then said:
The provision of low cost accommodation for tertiary students was the subject for a current review by the Tertiary Education Commission.

At the time both Senator Chaney and I asked the Minister what year that would be and she claimed it would be 1983. Subsequently Senator Ryan had to retract that and, in effect, acknowledge that the Tertiary Education Commission would not be completing its investigation of this matter until 1984; that is, this year. So this Government will not do anything for these students before 1985 at the earliest. I ask Senator Ryan, who is in the chamber at the moment, to do something with her Victorian colleague and to have some care and compassion for these students of Victoria by seeing whether this terrible error can be rectified. Subsequently Senator Ryan advised me in a letter:

The matter is entirely the responsibility of the State. There is no justification for purchase of the hostels by the Commonwealth. In the circumstances it would be more appropriate for you to pursue your concern with Mr Fordham

Mr Fordham is, of course, the Victorian Minister of Education. The Victorian Government has been engaged in a spree of employing some 10,000 additional people in the short time it has been in office. The result of that has been that it has run short of money. It has raised taxes in the State to the extent that some people have estimated that it is costing the ordinary family in Victoria an additional $30 a week under this Government. Yet it is still so desperately short of money that it is selling the State's assets to outside organisations and leasing them back, on an operative basis, in order to give it some funds to carry on. What a terrible position for a government to get into after such a short period in office. It is a demonstration not only of its lack of heart and compassion towards these people but also of its lack of communication with the Labor Government in Canberra and the Minister in particular. On 21 February this year Mr Fordham, in a letter to Mr John Radford, the member for Bendigo Province , stated:

As you would be aware the Commonwealth accepted full responsibility for tertiary education some ten years ago and in this sense the accommodation needs of tertiary students is the responsibility of the Federal Government not the State Government . . . while the State Government does not have direct responsibility for providing accommodation for tertiary students we are doing whatever we can to assist.

What the Victorian Government is doing is selling, by public auction, these hostels on 27 March. I ask: Is the Victorian Treasury in such a parlous state that it could not await the outcome of the Tertiary Education Commission's deliberations before disposing of these hostels? What will happen after they have been disposed of? Will the Government have to purchase some other low cost accommodation for country students, or will it perpetually disadvantage these students? What will it do? Certainly whatever it will do will cost more money than it would if the Government had continued with its current accommodation. The absurdity of the situation is perhaps highlighted by the number of Victorian students who are now enrolled at the Australian National University and accommodated in low cost accommodation there. One must have sympathy for many of these students. I have heard of many students who have had to leave educational institutions in Melbourne in particular, who have had to drop out of educational opportunities, because of this problem. We must have sympathy for those who have managed to go on and their parents who will have to supplement their unindexed tertiary education assistance scheme allowances to enable them to pay for the expense of the alternative accommodation which they have had to find.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-In closing the debate I thank my colleagues for their assistance and the further facts which they have given to me. I think it is important that this matter be dealt with today before this situation becomes beyond repair. The two Governments-the Victorian and Commonwealth Governments-cannot let these students and their lives fall between two stools, two governments. Something must be done about it. I urge the Senate to adopt the motion and ask both governments to respond responsibly.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Missen's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 6.30 p.m., pursuant to sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Primmer Sen C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 29 February in a ministerial statement, the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) purported to clear Mr John Ryan, the former head of the Australian Secret Intelligence Service, of the range of allegations I made against him in my speech on 8 December last. The basis for his speech was an internal investigation by the Department of Foreign Affairs. I will not mince words. The investigation upon which the Minister's speech was said to be based was conducted by the very people who fulsomely and, I believe, falsely cleared Mr Ivor Bowden, the ex-Ambassador in Tehran in 1982. They were the very same people who provided Mr Street with a speech containing what I demonstrated was a false alibi for Mr Bowden over the fradulent misappropriation of some $8,000-odd in Hong Kong in 1972, the very people who had Mr Street at that time praise Mr Henderson and Mr Bowden to the skies. As I have said before, members of the public and I, as well as the vast majority of Foreign Affairs staff, regard internal investigations, particularly when they are conducted by friends of the accused, as being farcical, in the extreme.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Hayden's statement, and it is almost as though Mr Ryan helped in its preparation, by no means tackles all my allegations. Where it does so, it raises more questions than it answers. More seriously, in preparing the statement, the Department of Foreign Affairs has failed to reveal to the Parliament, and probably to Mr Hayden himself, a range of extremely adverse and well-known material involving Mr Ryan. It might be said that this is par for the course, an attitude I refuse to accept. What I find remarkable is this: I believe that Mr Hayden was aware of some of this adverse material when I made my speech on 8 December last. What is more remarkable is not that Mr Henderson apparently chose to conceal his and Mr Ryan's knowledge of this material from Mr Hayden, but that Mr Hayden apparently decided not to display the knowledge he had gained from honest Foreign Affairs officers to the Parliament. That may explain why the Minister's statement seemed designed to distance himself from what the Department had provided and what Mr Hayden knew was lacking in at least several aspects.

Figuratively speaking, Mr Hayden held that statement about 40 feet away from himself as he read it. As one senior retired Foreign Affairs officer opined to me only last week: 'Any Minister would be unwise to defend Foreign Affairs'. You will appreciate, Mr Deputy President, that my speech of 8 December last year, followed by Mr Witheford's persecution, has had the effect of bringing other people forward with information on these issues. I am in consultation with these people with a view to making further information available to the Parliament.

Mr Justice Hope has branded Mr Ryan as incompetent in several respects. I intend to demonstrate, as the Bulletin and the National Times have done, that this matter goes much further than mere incompetence. I express the view of many people, including some members of this chamber, when I say that something is very fishy when a man of Mr Ryan's incompetence can be promoted to a very high level on a salary of $60,000-plus and cheerfully accepted back into the Department of Foreign Affairs after the Sheraton fiasco. Rest assured, Mr Deputy President, that the ex-Ambassador in Stockholm of a decade ago, against whom Senator Gareth Evans has chosen not to prepare criminal charges, and in the cover-up of whose case I believe, contrary to Mr Hayden's statement, Mr Ryan was closely in- volved, is again but one of the many skeletons in Mr Ryan's cupboard .

All honourable senators have probably seen what I believe to be a misleading editorial which appeared in the Canberra Times on 5 March which compared me with Mr Sinclair and claimed that I had misused parliamentary privilege in respect of Messrs Bowden and Ryan. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard my letter of reply dated 6 March.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
AUSTRALIAN SENATE
CANBERRA, A.C.T.
6 March 1984
The Editor
The Canberra Times
Mort Street
Braddon, A.C.T. 2601

Sir While less than flattered by the linkage of myself with Mr Sinclair in your editorial of 5 March, my principle concern is with the selective, biased and I believe inaccurate way you have reviewed the handling of some of the allegations I and some other Senators have made about the bureaucratic corruption in Canberra.

My concern is heightened by the fact that the 'Canberra Times' unlike other major newspapers has failed to report some of the more serious allegations about the Department of Foreign Affairs, indeed you have not reported, nor did you mention in your editorial, my question without notice last week concerning Mr Henderson.
In saying this I must add that I have no complaint to make at all about the calibre of your working journalists. They are extremely competent and possessed of social conscience.
What does worry me is an apparent editorial bias which has been commented on by others some of whom express the view that you may well have allowed yourself to become too close to 'City Hall'.

Allow me to state for the record that over recent weeks you have either failed or refused to publish letters from at least two people concerning (a) the Tehran Embassy affair and (b) the more recent diplomatic bag smuggling and security breaches matter.

I maintain the view that my speeches under parliamentary privilege over the past two years concerning the Department of Foreign Affairs have been fully justified by the number of people who have and still are coming forward with contributions on the issue. That so little progress has been made is due in my opinion, to the fears of legal action justifiably held by many, combined with what I see as a lack of zeal on the part of some of those charged with the investigations.
In my opinion we will only get to the bottom of these matters through a Parliamentary Committee with full protection for witnesses.
Would it be too much to hope that the Canberra Times will support that goal and , in the meantime provide balanced coverage of what are extremely serious matters.

As I have said before internal investigations by the Department of Foreign Affairs can and are seen as being farcical and it amazes me that this aspect has been completely ignored in your March 5 editorial.
Your sincerely
CYRIL G. PRIMMER
Senator for Victoria

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind this chamber again that no answers have yet been given to the many questions I have asked on this issue over the past months. If there is nothing to hide, why have these questions not been answered? At the end of last session the Attorney-General tabled a report from the Ombudsman, Professor Richardson, concerning complaints of public misconduct from the Foreign Affairs people who gave evidence on the earliest set of Tehran Embassy allegations which I first raised in this chamber over two years ago. In my opinion, Senator Evans' s tabling statement was rather misleading, as was the Ombudsman's report to Mr Hayden. To illustrate this I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard the letter of response to the Ombudsman dated 30 December 1983 from the leader of the three complainants, Mr D. Witheford, of Foreign Affairs, who now faces charges under the Crimes Act. I also seek leave to incorporate in Hansard Professor Richardson's reply dated 18 January 1984, which in my view does not tackle the very serious points made by Mr Witheford.
—Is leave granted for the incorporation in Hansard of these two documents?

—I take a point of order, Mr Deputy President. I do so to try to simplify the matter. The convention, as endorsed by the Senate Standing Orders Committee is that where incorporation of material in Hansard is sought it should be shown to an honourable senator on the other side of the chamber. It is a little difficult to follow that procedure during an adjournment debate, but because of the contentious nature of Senator Primmer's comments, I ask you to ask him to honour that convention by letting me see the material he is seeking to have incorporated. At the moment I prefer to refuse leave and intend to do so , subject to my being able to see the letter in case it contains matters which I regard as totally inappropriate.
—The attendant will take the letters to the Leader of the Opposition. I will raise the question of their incorporation at the end of Senator Primmer's speech.
— I refuse leave at the moment, for reasons I wish to explain.
—I call Senator Primmer.

—I believe that those three people were harshly treated by the police. I say this having had access to most of the tape transcripts and written statements of the police investigations. Last session I informed this chamber that I would be taking up these matters with the Ombudsman. I have done so. At my request he examined the police report of investigations into later allegations made by Messrs Witheford and Henne against Mr Bowden and by other informants, who are senior people and whom I shall not name, against Sir Nicholas Parkinson and a former Ambassador to Germany. Subsequently I had a very useful conversation with Professor Richardson in the course of which it became clear to me that in many areas we agreed about the Department of Foreign Affairs . The only obvious point of disagreement we had was that he was much more relaxed than I on the question of the capacity of the Federal Police to obtain evidence of criminal offences by senior Foreign Affairs staff.

SPEECH.PARA: I was therefore somewhat surprised at the much more formal and less concerned tone of the Ombudsman's subsequent letter to me, dated 9 December 1983. This is indicated in my letter of reply dated 24 February 1984. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard both those letters.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that in view of Senator Chaney's previous remarks you should pass those letters to him, Senator Primmer. The question of their incorporation will be raised at the end of your speech.
—Are these all the letters which Senator Primmer is seeking to have incorporated in Hansard? Are they all there?
—If they are not all there, I have neglected to bring them with me.

—Mr Deputy President, I take a point of order. I am examining a letter given to me by Senator Primmer dated 6 March from him to the editor of the Canberra Times. I also have a letter addressed to Professor Richardson dated 30 December 1983 from Mr Witheford. I have a letter dated 18 January 1984 to Mr Witheford from the Commonwealth Ombudsman, Professor Richardson, and a letter to Senator Primmer dated 9 December 1983 from the Commonwealth Ombudsman, Professor Richardson. I am in the process of perusing those. Until I have done so, I would refuse leave to incorporate them in Hansard for the reason I explained earlier.
—The question of incorporation can be raised at the end of Senator Primmer's speech, if Senator Chaney has had a chance to read them by then.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. During the recess I was shocked to learn of the suspension and subsequent charging under the Crimes Act of Mr Don Witheford, one of the officers involved in the Tehran Embassy allegations. On 26 January I issued a Press release expressing my concern over what had happened to Mr Witheford. It is certainly ironic that he remains suspended from duty, locked out of his office, and frankly treated in other respects like a petty criminal while Messrs Henderson and Bowden and others continue uncontrolled.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Witheford's suspension and subsequent events, of course, had the effect of bringing another person into the fray-Mrs Van Dartel. Horrified, I believe, at the victimisation of Mr Witheford, Mrs Van Dartel has come out with another set of allegations against Mr Henderson. As a consequence, we have had another internal investigation which has been unable to substantiate the claims made. Frankly, internal investigations into matters such as this do not by any means turn me on. By such means justice is not seen to be done. Meanwhile, Sir Nicholas Parkinson, whose eyesight has been classified as too poor to work, not only plays tennis and runs a walnut farm but also drives around the streets of Canberra as he draws his invalidity pension of $1,000 a week.

I am heartened by the strong support given to Mr Witheford by the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association in a situation in which any honest public servant could find himself or herself were he or she to stand up and be counted, as Mr Witheford has had the courage to do. I hope that the Foreign Affairs Association, with whom I have had contact in the past, will do likewise. Witheford today-tomorrow who? It becomes evident to me that this case points up the crying need within the Public Service for whistle-blower legislation, about which I have spoken in the past and which I have taken up with the responsible Minister, the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters, Mr Dawkins, and with the Chairman of the Public Service Board, Dr Wilenski.

In my Press statement of 20 January I noted that I had received information that there had been what I believe to have been unauthorised persons in my office in this place during each of the first two weeks in January. My own inquiries tended to confirm that information. What their intent was I know not, but one does smell a rat, and I wonder whether they were after some evidence to try to pin something on me, on Mr Witheford or on some other person. Any such intrusion, as we are all aware, is a flagrant breach of parliamentary privilege, and I am gratified by the concern expressed by other honourable senators about such intrusions.

Finally, there is some light at the end of the tunnel, however faint. Honourable senators may recall that one of the allegations I made in relation to the Tehran affair concerned the movement of furniture, including one piano, from Tehran to Canberra on behalf of the ex-Ambassador, Mr Ivor Bowden. I am now able to report that I have been informed that, as a result of the investigations which ensued, the Department of Administrative Services has been asked to prepare for Mr Bowden an account for the component of the freight that he avoided paying for almost six years. I suppose that, if nothing else, that assurance proves that the wheels of government move slowly, and in this instance only with a bloody lot of prodding. However, I believe it is inevitable that this chamber will be hearing more of both Mr Bowden and Mr Ryan in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is Senator Chaney ready to make a decision on the incorporation of the material?

—I have had a very quick look at what is quite a large amount of material. For example, the letter from Mr Witheford is seven pages long and I have had time only to scan it. I notice, however, that there is a letter from Mr Witheford to the Ombudsman which sets out complaints. There is a quite lengthy reply from the Ombudsman to Senator Primmer, not necessarily on all of the same points but answering a number. Therefore, provided that all this material is going in, if Senator Primmer seeks leave to incorporate all this material, I would not deny him leave.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Leave is granted for the incorporation.

INTERJECT.PARA: The letters read as follows-
DEPARTMENT OF FOREIGN AFFAIRS
CANBERRA, A.C.T. 2600 30.12.83

Dear Professor Richardson, Please refer to your letter of 20 October concerning the investigations resulting from the assistance sought from your Office by Mr Henne, my wife and myself over the police investigation and other matters concerning the first set of Tehran Embassy allegations. I did not reply to your letter earlier owing to the need to inform the other complainants, one of whom is on a long term overseas posting, and to give them, and others who have been supporting us throughout the various stages of this affair, an opportunity to consider what if any further action should be taken in the light of your report. While this letter takes into account to the maximum extent possible the views of my co-complainants and our various advisers, it has not been cleared point by point with any of them. This is partly due to the clear impression gained that you would see no advantage in further exchanges about the first police investigation. While your view is noted, it is felt that a number of points have to be registered with you and this I will do as briefly as possible.

While your report was a very disappointing one from our point of view-and you will not be surprised to know that we continue to believe that there was police misbehaviour-I wish to place on record our gratitude to you and your staff not only for the amount of time spent on the report but also for the moral support provided at what was a very difficult and stressful time for all three of us.

A general point I will make is that the police attitude in discussion with all three of us was a clear example of what unfortunately remains the automatic reaction of law enforcement authorities towards whistleblowers in the bureaucracy. My motives, my efficiency, and my emotional stability were raised over and over again as was the possibility that I had breached other laws in seeking to bring the Tehran allegations to attention. This was done so vigorously that my wife, who is not normally thus disposed, was driven to tears. A further witness, who was poised to approach the police for an interview, stayed his hand, following my advice to him of what had happened to my wife and myself on 13 August, 1982. None of us, nor any of those whom we have shown the transcripts of interview, believe that these can simply be passed off as ''plain speaking''.
