It horrifies me to realise that the police would feel quite free to treat others in exactly the same way or, perhaps, in the case of suspects, especially those of lower social-economic status, even more discourteously. In saying this, however, I would register with you that I am aware of and applaud the prompt and effective way you achieved redress for Mr A. T. R. Griffiths from Mr Hayden's office, who had been treated abominably by a group of senior Foreign Affairs and AFP personnel very similar to those that Mr Henne, my wife and I faced.
I.I.D. Investigation

I would like to record that in discussion about the police tapes of interviews, Dr Preston put it to me firmly that the police were not worried about the contents of the tapes, since, if they had been worried, they could easily have destroyed them. I hardly need to say that that is a remarkable point of view. He also urged me to accept what he said was his view, viz. the Internal Investigations Division was completely trustworthy. I was concerned to receive the impression that the IID report not only ''cleared'' the police officers involved but praised them.

(a) Breach of confidentiality-While you understood what we meant by this phrase , the IID obviously did not. Their canvassing of the code names is irrelevant. Our complaint was that the police officers did not treat as confidential expressions of opinions or facts which had more or less clearly been communicated ''in confidence'' and which in many cases they had revealed for no good reason to the other interviewees. To state the obvious, if police did not hold their sources of information on criminal matters closely, their sources would quickly dry up. Their regard for confidentiality is, however, very strong with respect to the police reports themselves! I have been unable to achieve access to them.

(b) Descriptions of allegations as baseless-Your view on this is noted. However I would draw to your attention two points which would tend to raise a serious questionmark about the baselessness of these allegations and subsequent ones:

(i) a large number of allegations have subsequently been made against this suspect and others; these seem to have substance and there has been a deliberate effort made to avoid tackling or investigating some;

(ii) according to Hansard, Mr Loveday-the target of later allegations of which he was ''cleared''-will not be getting any further overseas postings; there are strong rumours circulating to the effect that a similar decision has been taken in respect of the suspect, who has been back in Canberra for 5 1/2 years.

(c) Police criticism of me-The IID view on this matter is not shared by us (my para 3 refers). Wallace was, with scant subtlety, conveying those assertions to my wife, just as they would have been conveyed to him by the Departmental contact.

(d) False claims that witnesses had changed their evidence-It is rather peculiar if the police questioning elicited different stances from witnesses than they had adopted previously and, in the case of Henne and Johns at least, subsequently as well (including in Hansard). As you know Henne has alleged that there was a transparent ''stage setting'' operation by the police, before the tape recorder was turned on.

(e) Absence of documents-As I informed Dr Preston some time ago, the police had not been shown X/A files relating to me or others; indeed these files were later also concealed from the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, the President of which rebuked my Department publicly. At the time of the interviews the police betrayed an ignorance of my communications with Mr Street and, subsequently, a lack of interest in those I passed to them.

I disagree with your view of the significance that there was no complaint about my earlier interview with the Police. What is significant is that the first interview covered the ground entirely, thereby tending to prove that the second was purely a bullying exercise.

On the question of criminal intention, the impression I gained was that the suspect had, on several occasions, claimed ignorance of the law/regulation in which he was in breach and the police had accepted this without concern. On the removals matter (which I'll cover later) Dr Preston was informed that separate evidence was held directly relevant to criminal intention. That appears to have been ignored in your report.

While I do not intend to go over each of the allegations again, I would draw to your attention that it is the view of many that the wilful submission of false accounting certificates is a serious matter for which the law provides heavy penalties; it is not just an administrative blemish. Overall our advisers continue to agree with our view that there was not in fact a ''complete lack of any evidence of criminal action''.

You refer in passing to the fact that the allegation had already been investigated by the Department of Finance. Please refer to our frequently stated serious criticism of that investigation. These were also made personally by Mr Henne to Dr Preston. None of them has ever been explained or denied.

Mr Lucas' disavowal of the influence of one or more Foreign Affairs Officers sits oddly with the secrecy being maintained over the details of those contacts, one of which appeared to occur in the course of my interview on 13 August, 1982. My principal concern is with contacts between Lucas/Wallace and a particular senior officer of my department. It remains my understanding that Inspector Whiddett withdrew from the investigation before any witnesses were questioned. In any event Mr Whiddett's attitude as expressed to me was very different to the extravagant and misleading terms of his Minister's letter to Mr Street (quoted in Mr Street's statement (26/8/82).

Our view remains that the investigating officers by whatever means-and note carefully Mr Henne's allegation about their off-tape conduct-achieved results at odds with views separately expressed by a number of interviewees, both before and after the police investigation.
Incidental issues

Number of complaints-Our principal concern remains that those protecting Mr Bowden's interests were at pains to emphasise that the allegations/complaints had been from only one person (''and no-one supports him''). As you know all three of us viewed ourselves as co-complainants and did everything we could to convince you of that. We were, of course, interviewed separately. Concern is felt at the informal contacts between your Office and Mr Street's on this particular point. Our belief is that Street's staff, under pressure from their Foreign Affairs superiors, approached you with the single goal of saying you had endorsed the view that there was ''only one'' complainant.

Objectionable material off the record-Your dismissal of the most serious implications of the sort of conduct off-tape alleged by Mr Henne is unacceptable . This sort of prompting, particularly when applied to junior officers, such as Mr Sergi, already under pressure in the workplace, will inevitably result in many giving the answers they think the police want. Your glib dismissal of the veracity of Mr Henne's claims in this regard is unacceptable, even offensive. It seems that neither you nor the I.I.D. have bothered to consider the importance of putting Mr Henne's allegation to the detectives. Are you assuming that both would deny it completely?

Retrieval of the R-file-It must have been crystal clear to your Office that there had been a considerable breach of faith in the timing and nature of the transmittal of the ''R''-file to you. We were likewise amazed to learn much later that you had let it out of your hands. As advised earlier, Dr Preston was told that evidence relating to criminal intention in this matter was held separately, as were photocopies of the relevant papers on the file. I understand that you are now examining the second police report. These particular allegations have obviously not been properly investigated, especially since neither Mr Henne nor I have been questioned about them.
Orchestration-Continuing secretiveness both by the Department and the AFP about their contacts on this matter would suggest to almost anybody that there is something to hide under this heading.

Nobbling of the IID investigation-At the time Dr Preston agreed IID had done the wrong thing. We persist in our belief that the Department's reaction-viz. to deal with the IID approach as if Mr Smith had authority to release Mr Henne-was also improper.
Variants of our complaints-I see no point repeating our views on items (i) to ( v) other than to say that those who have seen the transcripts share our view that the tapes speak for themselves.
Questions raised on transcripts
A1

It seems that neither the Ombudsman nor the AFP has seen the evidence which I raised with Dr Preston. Your view on the importance of Mr Lindeman is at odds with that put to me by Dr Preston-obviously Mr Lindeman's assertion would constitute evidence against Mr Bowden.
The problem is that they seem to have accepted claims of ignorance of laws/ regulations by the suspect without quibble.

I disagree entirely on this point. Isn't ''a bit improper'' roughly equivalent to ''underhanded''? Bear in mind that most would believe that Henne was, as he has stated, dealing with police who had ''programmed'' the interview before turning on the tape.

Our concern is that the police were trying to close the whole thing down i.e. that by whatever means they were trying to prevent officers in Foreign Affairs coming forward with allegations against senior officers, as in fact happened subsequently. I would submit that this is both improper and illegal.

I wish to record our very serious concern, which was expressed orally to Dr Preston-that your Office had provided information, last May, to Mr Hayden or to others, which had been employed in the Minister's speech, which was unfairly critical of me, amongst others. REF CP83/28 18 Jan 1984 Dear Mr Witheford Thank you for your letter of 30 December 1983 about my findings in relation to your complaint against the Australian Federal Police (AFP) and related matters.

In your letter you have disputed facts and disagree with my conclusions. All I can say is that I reached those conclusions after a thorough investigation and I do not consider that there is any more I can or should do in relation to your complaint. My investigation was, of course, into your complaint against the AFP not into the allegations you originally made to the Hon. A. A. Street, the then Minister for Foreign Affairs. I made it clear in my letter to you and subsequently to the present Minister, the Hon. Bill Hayden, that I did not receive a complaint from Mr Street about those allegations and that I have not investigated them. As you know, I have reached some conclusions about actions of officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs on the basis of my review of the investigations by the AFP and by the Department of Finance. It is on this basis that I commented that your primary allegations were in essence allegations of defective administration. This is still my view.

You have alleged that I conveyed information about the handling of your complaint to Mr Pryor of the Public Service Board. This is not correct. An officer of the Public Service Board did seek clarification of what I was investigating. One of my officers advised him, without giving any details, that we were investigating your complaint against the AFP but not other allegations you had made. We did not provide any further comments or information.

I should point out that in writing recently to Mr Hayden I was not acting pursuant to s25 (10) of the Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Act 1981 which permits me to discuss any matter relevant to an investigation with a Minister concerned. Rather, I had decided that it was in the interests of the Australian Federal Police and the Department of Foreign Affairs as well as in the public interest to provide the Minister with a statement setting out the results of my consideration of your complaint. Under a new section-s41A-of the Complaints Act, I have the power to make a statement where:

''in the opinion of the Ombudsman, it is in the interests of the Australian Federal Police or any Department, prescribed authority or person (including a member), or is otherwise in the public interest, so to disclose that information or to make that statement.''

I am sorry that you are so dissatisfied with the outcome of my investigation. I note, however, that you do not propose to pursue your complaint against members of the AFP. Accordingly, I have now closed my file.
Yours sincerely, J. E. Richardson Commonwealth Ombudsman

Dear Senator Primmer, At the close of our meeting on 25 November 1983 I told you that I would confirm in writing my conclusions with respect to your complaints about the Australian Federal Police (AFP) and related matters. In this letter I will deal first with your complaint about the AFP's second investigation and then comment on other matters we discussed at that meeting.

The AFP's second investigation covered your allegations about Mr Loveday, Sir Nicholas Parkinson's retirement, Mr Bowden's piano and his missing silverware. Ms Pidgeon of my office has examined the investigation report and all the relevant documents and concluded that the investigation was as thorough as possible in the absence of more specific leads or sources of information.
Mr Loveday

Mr Loveday's trip across the German border into Austria took place in November 1979 (not, as you believed, November 1980). The AFP investigating officers interviewed several officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs including Mr Loveday. They also examined relevant departmental files, the hotel account and the log of the car Mr Loveday used for that trip.

It is clear from those documents that the Department's Canberra office had approved Mr Loveday's proposal for a two day trip to visit the Frankfurt Book Fair, accompanied by his wife. Mr and Mrs Loveday travelled from Bonn to Frankfurt on the morning of 12 October 1979, driven by an official driver. He attended the Book Fair and gave a speech. During the afternoon he travelled to Ulm where he inspected the local university. He then travelled to Lindau for the night. The next day he visited another university in the city of Frieburg and also went over the border into Austria to the city of Feldkirch for a short time . Mr Loveday described this as a minor side visit. They then returned to Lindau for the night and travelled to Bonn the following day.

We are satisfied that Mr Loveday was entitled, as Ambassador, to decide to visit the universities in Ulm and Frieburg as part of his official duties. While there may be a question as to whether Mrs Loveday should have accompanied him on the visits to those towns, I doubt that there would have been a great saving (if any) of public money if he had driven back to Bonn immediately after the Book Fair and then set out on the trip to the universities without Mrs Loveday.

With regard to his trip over the border, I do not consider that he acted improperly in making a short private trip while in the area in the course of his official duties. the AFP believes that it was not a formal requirement for an ambassador to notify the German Government of proposed absences from the country . The Foreign Ministry did expect ambassadors to notify it of absences so that they would know who would be in charge of a mission but such notification was not warranted for a trip of only a few hours during a weekend (as in this case). Moreover, travel over the border is not unusual in Germany-for example to make use of better roads when travelling from one part of Germany to another.
I do not consider that there is any further action that the AFP or this office should take on this complaint.
Sir Nicholas Parkinson

The AFP examined medical and other records relating to Sir Nicholas' retirement and interviewed his doctor, several officers of the Departments of Foreign Affairs and Health (including senior medical officers) and Sir Nicholas. They also verified the signatures on medical reports and related documents. After a thorough investigation, the AFP found no evidence of the retirement racket you believe is going on.

From our examination of the AFP's report and the relevant documents, we are satisfied that Sir Nicholas Parkinson's retirement was bona fide. We are also satisfied that the fact that he may still be capable of undertaking some employment does not imply that he should not have been retired from the Public Service as medically unfit-he was certainly unfit to continue in employment appropriate to his level and experience within the Public Service.

If there is a retirement racket going on in the Department of Foreign Affairs, the AFP found no evidence of it when investigating Sir Nicholas' retirement. Without further specific leads or sources of information neither the AFP nor my office is able to take any further action. I appreciate the difficulties you have in disclosing your sources of information but if you are able to assist the AFP any further, I strongly recommend that you do so. As I told you at our meeting, I am happy to make members of my staff available to be present at any interviews between the AFP and your informants.
Mr Bowden's silverware

As you know, I have already investigated Mr Wilson's complaint against the Department of Administrative Services concerning Mr Bowden's silverware. Mr Bowden claimed that Wilson Removals failed to deliver to him a box containing silverware valued at $1100.00 and Mr Wilson complained to me about the Department's decision that he was liable for the loss. I concluded that the complaint was unsubstantiated.

My investigation focussed in particular on the nature of the agreement between Wilson Removals and the Department but I also considered the question of whether or not the box had been included with those delivered to Mr Bowden. Wilson Removals had stored 30 boxes belonging to Mr Bowden and Mr Bowden claimed that the company delivered only 29 to him. There is no evidence of how many were delivered-the company's employees had failed to note this on the receipt signed by Mr Bowden. Mr Bowden, on the other hand, did note on his copy of the receipt that 29 boxes had been delivered. He also told the Department that he had seen the company's records which showed that four of his boxes had been stored on one pallet in the company's warehouse, but, when the time came for the boxes to be delivered, the company had taken only three from that pallet. An assessor from the Department had tried to investigate this point but the company had refused to allow him to see its records.

When the AFP interviewed Mr Wilson concerning your allegation he had been adament that his grievance was about the Department's decision, not about Mr Bowden. He also told the AFP that he did not wish to make any complaint about any of the circumstances to which you referred as he intended to take civil action against the Department. The AFP did not make any further inquiries, therefore, into the matter. In the circumstances, I consider the AFP acted reasonably in discontinuing its investigation. I have reviewed my own investigation of the complaint and have had to conclude that there is no further action I could usefully take to investigate it further.
Piano

The AFP also investigated, as part of its second investigation, the movement of Mr Bowden's piano from Tehran to Canberra. After a lengthy investigation which included interviews of officers from the Departments of Foreign Affairs and Administrative Services and from the Australian National Gallery, and an examination of files and relevant documents from all three organisations, the AFP concluded that no-one had committed an offence. From our examination of the report and of the relevant documents we agree with the AFP's conclusion.

In brief, Mr Bowden included his piano in his inventory of possessions to be shipped back to Australia at the end of his Tehran posting. The Department of Foreign Affairs decided that he should pay for the transport of the piano, a piano stool and some other items as they had not been among the possessions Mr Bowden had taken to Tehran when he was appointed. At the same time the Department decided to use a container to ship his possessions to Australia, along with some paintings and other objects belonging to the Australian National Gallery. This was the cheapest method. The container was a standard size and the piano and other extra items took up space which would otherwise have remained empty. The cost to the Department was the same whether or not the piano and other extra items were included. The Department decided, therefore, to charge Mr Bowden only for the cost of packing his piano and extra items in Tehran and for the overland freight from Geelong to Canberra.

The Department billed Mr Bowden (and he paid) for the extra packing in Tehran. Once in Australia, the Department of Administrative Services transported the shipment to Canberra and billed the National Gallery for its share of the freight cost. It failed to bill either Mr Bowden or the Department of Foreign Affairs for Mr Bowden's share. The normal practice was for the Department of Administrative Services to charge the Department of Foreign Affairs who in turn would recover the money from Mr Bowden. There is no record of why the Department of Administrative Services failed to do so and we have had to conclude that it was an oversight. The Department of Foreign Affairs now regards the amount as irrecoverable as the Department did not bring it to Mr Bowden's attention within twelve months. I am currently examining this point to see whether, in fact, the amount is recoverable.

Mr Bowden did not take the initiative to pay the Department but this did not constitute an offence or a misdemeanour. He may have simply overlooked the matter. Even if he did remember the debt but decided not to do anything about it , this is not a matter I can criticise as Ombudsman.
First police investigation

The first police investigation was into allegations made by Mr Witheford about Mr Bowden. As you know we have thoroughly investigated the AFP's actions in following up those allegations. We have also investigated a number of related issues. After this substantial effort by my office, I am satisfied that Mr Witheford's allegations were without substance. I did have some reservations about a few minor aspects of the police investigation, which I mentioned to you at our meeting and which I have explained to Mr Witheford. I do not consider that these in any way reflect, however, on the impartiality or thoroughness of the police investigation.

With regard to your concern that witnesses may have been bullied by police into changing their evidence, I am satisfied that this did not occur. My staff listened to the tapes of all interviews of witnesses and confirmed that the investigation officers acted fairly and gave them full opportunity to support Mr Witheford's allegations. The witnesses did not support them.
Other matters

I have considered whether there is any action I should take to investigate other matters you have raised with me or in Parliament. As I explained to you, these are generally outside my jurisdiction as they relate to the employment of officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs. Section 5 (2) (d) of the Ombudsman Act 1976 provides that the Ombudsman is not authorised to investigate:

'action taken by any body or person with respect to persons employed in the Australian Public Service or the service of a prescribed authority, being action taken in relation to that employment, including action taken with respect to the promotion, termination of appointment or discipline of a person so employed or the payment of remuneration to such a person'.

In addition, I understand that a Public Service Board inquiry is looking into issues relating to the Department of Foreign Affairs' treatment of Mr Witheford and Mr Henne. In the circumstances I do not consider there is any action I can or should take on these matters.
Conclusion

Subject to any further comments you may wish to make, I propose to advise the Commissioner of the AFP that I do not intend to take any further action on these allegations. You are, of course, welcome to contact me again at any time if you obtain further information on any of these matters or are able to assist the AFP with leads or sources of information. As I have mentioned, I am following up the question of whether Mr Bowden is still liable for his share of the cost of transporting his piano and other items from Geelong to Canberra. I will write to you again on this issue.
Yours sincerely, J. E. RICHARDSON Commonwealth Ombudsman
Senator C. G. Primmer,

Dear Sir, Thank you for your letter of December 9, 1983 and my apologies for the delay in answering same.

Whilst at our meeting on November 25, 1983 you went some way towards alleviating my doubts about the matters we discussed, your letter has to some extent, served to refuel my long held suspicions that all is not well.

As one example, no account seems to have been taken of the fact that neither Mr Henne or Mr Witheford were not interviewed by the police about the removals irregularities which they had brought to Minister Street's notice in November 1982.
As you will recall, I told you of my previous experience about the meat industry scandal which left me somewhat suspicious of expressions such as 'no evidence was found by the police'.

Events have now moved on and Mr Witheford stands charged under the Crimes Act for having in his possession, certain documents. Quite frankly, it is my assessment that any public servant in Canberra worthy of his or her salt, could find themselves in the same boat. People do take work home and in all honesty, I find the charges ludicrous but that will be for the Court to decide.
Other happenings over recent weeks have tended to confirm my suspicions and these I shall hopefully, be able to follow up in the Parliament.
Yours faithfully, C. G. PRIMMER Senator for Victoria

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having given that notice of motion, I will speak very briefly on the matter raised by Senator Primmer. I do not wish to repeat the speeches I made on two occasions since the Parliament resumed when Senator Primmer made attacks on Mr Ryan. Since that attack on Mr Ryan by Senator Primmer quite a lengthy statement has been tabled by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) on behalf of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden), and once again I made some remarks then which I do not wish to repeat. I have given that notice of motion because I think that we can usefully have some debate on this matter and on the principles we ought to follow.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said earlier, there are a number of avenues open to Senator Primmer. I suppose that his response might well be that he has followed those avenues by referring matters to the Ombudsman, the Australian Federal Police, and so on, that he simply remains dissatified and that, therefore, he brings into this Parliament in extremis, as it were, or as a last resort, the continual allegations he has made. It is a little ironic that we have spent a great deal of time this week debating matters relating to the High Court and other things in which we have had a continuous stream of complaints and criticism from Government Ministers and senators about the use of privilege, the possible abuse of privilege, and so on. In this case we have really a long running saga in which there has been allegation after allegation and answer after answer, those answers coming through Liberal Ministers initially, as I recall, and subsequently from Labor Ministers. I think it is most unhelpful to the institution of Parliament, to the efficient functioning of the Public Service in Australia and, I suspect, to a number of other things that we ought to be concerned about, that Senator Primmer persists in this course. However, he has the privilege which we all have and wish to maintain and he is, of course, exercising his personal judgment as a senator.

I have not known any of the people Senator Primmer has referred to in his comments and, therefore, a detailed defence of them is not possible. Indeed, it would not be possible even if I did know them because I have no first-hand knowledge of the administration of the Department of Foreign Affairs or of any individual embassy. One person he has mentioned tonight is known to me-Sir Nicholas Parkinson. He is known to me only through his serving Australia in Washington. I have met him only in that context. I have met him on one or two occasions but I could not for a moment claim him as a friend or say that he would claim me as a friend. I have had nothing but politician-public servant contact with him. The limited contact I have had with him has left me with very great admiration for his professional skills. When I saw him as Ambassador to the United States he was, I thought, on top of his subject. He briefed a mixed group of parliamentarians. I do not even remember whether it was in 1976 or 1978 , but I do remember being extremely impressed by his competence, his enthusiasm and his grasp of Australia's interests.

At that time it was apparent to me that he had very considerable deficiencies of sight. In the meetings I have had with him over subsequent years it has become even more apparent that he is very disabled visually. These days a very substantial number of people retire for all sorts of psychological and other reasons-and I am not trying to throw doubt on anyone's resignation-but here we have a gentleman who has served Australia at great length and who has a very obvious disability. The rest of Senator Primmer's allegations seem to me to be thrown into doubt by the sort of comment he makes about the retirement of Sir Nicholas Parkinson. On the evidence of what I have seen of that man, it would appear to me that that element of what Senator Primmer has to say is nonsense and is grossly unfair.

I regret that we are again faced with this matter. I have given the notice of motion because I believe that it is important that the couple of hundred thousand people who serve Australia in the Public Service and who at times feel that they have had insufficient support from those of us in Parliament, whether in government or opposition, know that they are not simply fair game in this place. I again express my regret that Senator Primmer seems to find that the only course that he can follow, when his own Party is in government and when he should have access to men with whom he has worked for years and should have plenty of private opportunities to vent any concerns that he has, is to persist in making allegations after they have been investigated and answered and when very strong statements have been made by Ministers of the Government that he supports which suggest that the allegations are baseless. I do not know to whom Senator Primmer should give notice when he makes these allegations, but I note that the Minister who represents the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Gareth Evans, is not present, and I assume that that means that he was not notified that this would be happening.

TALK.START.PARA: —He was notified.

—Well, I can only say that I think it is important that when statements of this sort are made it should be immediately on record that Senator Primmer has made similar statements before, they have been subjected to examination by politicians, by bureaucrats, by the Ombudsman, and by the Australian Federal Police, and none of them seems to have come up with anything which would support his allegations or which would enable any action to be taken . I really think that Senator Primmer has trespassed well beyond the line of the proper use of this place, and I very much regret that he has once again taken this matter up.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will be aware that the Northern Territory Criminal Code has been a contentious matter and that I have raised it at Question Time and at various other times in Senate debates. This matter continues to receive criticism from the Federal Government and continues to be a source of conflict between the Federal Government and the Northern Territory Government. Later, Mr Deputy President, I shall seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a statement released today regarding the matter by the shadow Attorney-General, Senator Durack, and the shadow Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr James Porter. Before doing so, I wish to spend a little time going through the major points of the statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Judging by comments from the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) made in the Senate this week, it would seem that the Federal Government is intent on making alterations to the Northern Territory Criminal Code, come what may. However, I am somewhat alarmed at the Federal Government's methods of achieving these changes. Rather than following the conventional methods of discussion and consultation with the Northern Territory Government, the Labor Federal Government has chosen to bully the Territory into changing the Code. I remind the Attorney-General and the Senate of his statement that:

If no satisfactory response is obtained through our latest communication and within a short period of time-seven days-then we will recommend to the Governor- General that he in turn recommend changes to the Code to the Northern Territory Government.

The Attorney-General went on to imply that if the Governor-General's intervention did not achieve the required results, the Federal Government would step in directly and repeal or disallow certain provisions of the Code. I find Senator Gareth Evans's statements nothing less than threatening to the Territory and its Government. They are also unjustified.
I should like to read to the Senate two paragraphs from Senator Durack's statement, which will be tabled, as I have indicated. They read:

The Federal Government's move to force amendments to the Northern Territory Criminal Code is a betrayal of self-government, an infringement upon the Territory's legislative independence, and wholly without justification.
He goes on to say:

It is clear from debates of the Northern Territory (Self-Government) Bill that both the Government and the Opposition consider that following self-government, the Northern Territory would exercise plenary legislative powers. The Commonwealth would only move to disallow the Territory's legislation if it conflicted with Federal legislation. The Code does not so conflict.

It seems obvious to me and others that the Federal Government's real reason for seeking to interfere is simply that the Code does not conform with the Government's own view upon criminal law reform. To that extent, I take this opportunity to ask the Attorney-General some questions which I had been hoping to raise during Question Time in the Senate this week. I refer the Attorney- General to his answer to a question by Senator Macklin regarding the Criminal Code on Tuesday 28 February. In that answer, the Attorney-General said that in its present form the Code was:
. . . quite unconscionable by reference to Australia's international obligations, particularly under the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.

By the Attorney-General's careful use of the term 'quite unconscionable', is the Senate to assume that he concedes that the Criminal Code does not directly violate any of our international obligations but merely contravenes the Attorney -General's perception of the spirit of those treaties? Will the Attorney-General identify the treaties, other than the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, which the Code contravenes? Also, will he state how the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights has been violated, if at all? Does the Attorney-General disagree with the report made by Australia to the Human Rights Commission established by the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights that reverse onus provisions such as section 7 of the Criminal Code do not contravene the presumption of innocence guaranteed by article 14 of the Covenant? If so, does the Government intend to deliver a fresh report to the Human Rights Commission?

It has been a very busy week in the Senate. I have been endeavouring to have these questions put to the Attorney-General, but to no avail, so I am using the adjournment debate tonight to bring them to his attention. I now seek leave, Mr Deputy President, to have incorporated in Hansard the statement to which I referred earlier. It has been referred to the Government. I hope that it will help to clear up these matters with the Attorney-General and his colleagues. It is a statement by Senator Peter Durack, QC, shadow Attorney-General, and Attorney-General in the previous Government, and Mr James Porter, MP, shadow Minister for Aboriginal Affairs.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

The Federal Government's move to force amendments to the NT. Criminal Code is a betrayal of self-government, an infringement upon the Territory's legislative independence, and wholly without justification.

It is clear from the debates of the NT (Self-Government) Bill that both the Government and Opposition consider that following self-government, the NT would exercise plenary legislative powers. The Commonwealth would only move to disallow the Territory's legislation if it conflicted with Federal legislation. The Code does not so conflict.
The Government's real reason for seeking to interfere with the Code is simply that the Code does not conform with the Governments's views upon criminal law reform.

The criminal law must be a matter clearly within the independent ambit of territory responsibility. It is a local matter enacted by the NT Legislative Assembly with a mandate from last year's election. Even though the Code may not follow the same approach which the Federal Government would have taken to similar legislation, that divergence of views cannot justify Federal interference.
Self-government, as a principle, must mean the right to make your own mistakes or achieve your own successes without interference from ''big brother''. Anything less is a denial of self-government.
In any event there is nothing in the Code which warrants Federal intereference with the Territory's legislative process.
The Government has identified four areas of criticism in relation to:
(a) The abolition of unsworn dock statements.
(b) The Legislative Assembly's power to proscribe terrorist organisations.
(c) The defence of intoxication-the onus is placed upon the defendant to prove intoxication where he seeks to rely upon it as a defence.
(d) Payment of costs and compensation to victims where the defence of intoxication is successful.
None of these criticisms are valid (see detailed paper attached). They could not, in any event, justify Federal intervention.

NORTHERN TERRITORY CRIMINAL CODE ACT 1983
The following is a critique of the ''matters of concern'' noted by the Prime Minister in his letter to the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory on 29 February 1984.

1. Intoxication-Reverse Onus of Proof-In R v O'Connor it was held by the High Court that at Common Law in Australia the defence of intoxication was available not only for crimes requiring a specific intent but also for crimes requiring a general criminal intent. This is not the situation in the U.K. nor in those States (Qld, W.A. and Tas.) which have a criminal code. There intoxication is a defence only to crimes of specific intent.

This decision was criticised by the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General. Most crimes of specific intent (e.g. wounding with intent to resist arrest) have an alternative, less serious counterpart requiring only a general intent (e.g. malicious wounding) and carrying a lesser penalty. The O'Connor decision meant that an accused may go free from all criminal responsibility because of self- induced intoxication.

The Code accepts the O'Connor decision but seeks to place a barrier in the way of an accused seeking to plead intoxication. Section 7 Code deems that where intoxication is raised as a defence the intoxication will be presumed to have been voluntarily induced. Unless the intoxication is involuntarily induced, the accused will be presumed to have foreseen the natural and probable consequences of his acts and to have intended them until the contrary is proven.
The Government has criticised this provision as placing a reverse onus upon the accused to prove that he was, through intoxication, unable to form an intent.

Alcohol related crime is a serious problem in the N.T. 80% of all crime is alcohol related and the homicide rate is 6 to 10 times that of the States. Intoxication is a common defence and, where it is falsely raised, it is difficult for the Crown to disprove-a matter recently noted by the High Court- because usually the accused alone will know of the event and circumstances surrounding his intoxication.
The rationale of the approach adopted by the Code is that where the accused wishes to rely upon his intoxication as a defence-
(a) he will have to give evidence of matters peculiarly within his own knowledge; and
(b) he will therefore have to enter the witness box and be subject to cross examination upon that issue.

In adopting this approach the N.T. has complied with the guidelines for the use of reverse onus provisions recommended by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. The alternative approach is to allow intoxication as a defence only for crimes of specific intent but this could be a harsher approach from the accused's perspective.

2. Intoxication-Acquittal-The N.T. was concerned at overcoming the R v O'Connor anomaly that an accused may escape all criminal liability for an offence because , at the time of the offence, he was voluntarily self-intoxicated.

Accordingly, in keeping with similar approaches from various Law Reform bodies, and, indeed, some of the Court in O'Connor's case, an offence of strict liability has been included in the Code. It relates to situations where an accused commits an act that causes serious, actual or potential danger to the public in circumstances where an ordinary person similarly circumstanced would clearly have foreseen the danger and not committed the act.

It had been suggested by some of the Law Reform bodies and, indeed, the former Chief Justice Barwick in O'Connor's case, that such an offence of strict liability should extend to all acts, not just acts that cause danger to the public, e.g. to cover offences such as criminal damage.

The Territory chose not to go this far as it considered it could cause undue hardship to an accused. For example, if a group of final year medical or law students (or anyone facing a possible loss of career upon conviction for a crime ) in celebration of completion of their final exams, got completely drunk and caused a deal of damage to property, their careers and lives might be ruined by a conviction. The Territory sees a better remedy in allowing an acquittal, and where the jury specifically finds the only reason it acquitted the accused was because he was too drunk to know what he was doing, then to allow the Court, in its discretion, to impose a fine on the accused.
The imposition of a fine, rather than a conviction, may well be a far more satisfactory alternative to an accused facing this type of situation.
The normal rules relating to the exercise of a Court's discretion would indicate any fine should not be beyond a person's capacity to pay. The imposition of a fine is not mandatory.

3. Abolition of Dock Statements-The Federal Government says that the abolition of unsworn statements will prejudice Aboriginal defendants and has cited a decision of the Chief Justice of the Northern Territory, Sir William Forster, as supporting their criticism.
Dock statements are an historical anomaly. They have been abolished in Queensland and W.A.-States with large Aboriginal populations-and no noticeable injustices have occurred.
Last week the N.T. Chief Justice said in the course of proceedings: ''I think it is an abomination-the unsworn statement. I would have done away with it years ago.''
His Honour added that, in his opinion and experience, unsworn statements had been of little, if any, assistance to Aboriginal defendants.

4. Terrorism and Proscribed Organisations-The Code provides provision for the Executive Council to declare organisations ''proscribed organisations'' and it is then an offence to be a member of or assist such an organisation.
Following proscription the matter must be submitted to the Legislative Assembly for review. The Government considers that a specific right of judicial review would be more appropriate.

The N.T. counters this on two bases. Firstly, it considers that a decision to proscribe is one that should be made by the executive, not the judiciary. In a terrorist situation, judges could be placed in extreme danger if the decision was placed in their hands. Secondly, the provision does not exclude the common law rights of judicial review for breach of natural justice or if a decision was ultra vires because it was so unreasonable. In those circumstances a proscribed organisation should be able to apply to the Courts for a prerogative writ setting aside the proscription.
It is noted that this provision has been studied and acclaimed by the N.S.W. Law Society as model legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The last letter from the Prime Minister ( Mr Hawke) to the Northern Territory, of only a few days ago, indicated that he and his Government are now prepared to meet the Chief Minister, Mr Paul Everingham, and members of his Government to discuss the matter further. I appeal for a cool approach to these discussions. Let us have this contentious matter resolved. The whole matter is most unfortunate. I believe that there could have been better liaison and consultation. However, let us see now whether the two governments can come together and perhaps the Prime Minister and Ministers of the Federal Government will appreciate the problems of the Northern Territory and what it is endeavouring to do through the Northern Territory Criminal Code that was passed in the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly last year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to acknowledge that today is International Women's Day and to take the opportunity to draw attention to some of the achievements of the Labor Government over the last 12 months on behalf of women. I think the achievements of the Government overall are well worth noting but I will be selective tonight. Also, my list is not definitive. I do not have a copy of the last and ultimate achievements for women but I shall take the opportunity to mention some.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps the first and most important one was the re-establishment of the Office of the Status of Women and its relocation in the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, acknowledging the importance and significance that this Government places on the need to consult appropriately with and acknowledge the importance of women. Also, the Government has moved to establish a broad consultative committee of women's organisations around Australia to replace the previous consultative committee, the National Women's Advisory Council, known as NATWAC. The problems of NATWAC lay essentially in the limited number of women in that organisation with whom other women and organisations could consult. This Government felt it was much more important to have a more broadly representative consultative committee. The appointment of that committee of some 20 women strong ought to be announced in the very near future.

Further, the Government has appointed a great number of women to boards, statutory authorities, government departments and so on. At last count, some 66 women had been appointed. As was stated the other night, it will be very useful when we begin to take those things as a matter of course and not as a matter of particular celebration. But I think it is to this Government's credit that it has set out actively to increase enormously the representation of women in positions of importance and responsible decision-making. For most women in Australia they are still matters of considerable celebration and acknowledgment.

In more specific areas of policy, the Government has addressed itself to the particular needs of women. Very often it has done this by addressing the needs of the community but women, representing some 51 per cent of the community, have benefited. The Government was concerned to address itself to the problem of massive unemployment that it inherited when it came to office. The terms of reference of the community employment program require that some 50 per cent of the positions established under it be available to women. This is not an easy thing to achieve because many of the jobs for which local government, regional councils and so on might submit proposals tended to be in the more traditional mould and therefore to provide more work opportunities for men. But the Government was very insistent that a number of those work opportunities be available to women and it has maintained that requirement. It has not required that any local initiative or application for money under the community employment program provide 50 per cent job opportunities for women but requires that overall, over a region, over a State, some 50 per cent of those jobs be available for women. It adheres to this requirement and that is a great benefit to the many unemployed women in our community who are seeking work.

Another very important policy whose implementation has affected women has been the introduction of Medicare. Very often it is women who take young children or older folk to the doctor. It is the women who have had to contend with the problem of finding the cash in hand to pay doctors' bills. Under Medicare that is no longer a problem. It certainly directly advantages women in that way and, of course, it advantages any women who seek medical assistance on their own behalf. They do not have to find ways of dealing with the financial problems that many of them faced previously before they went to see a doctor. We have seen the establishment of the first home owners assistance scheme. This has been a great advantage to women. Any number of women have been able to apply and successfully take out loans and any number of married women have benefited also. In fact, the first home owners assistance scheme has been more popular than was predicted because as employment has improved more people have been able to exercise their rights to take out a first home loan.

On behalf of Aboriginal women an Aboriginal women's task force has been established within the Office of the Status of Women. That is another important acknowledgment by this Government that not only white Australian women but all Australian women are seen to be important and to have rights and dignity and are seen as people with whom this Government wants to consult. I will leave the area of social security more to the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes), who is a full bottle on all of these things, but I certainly acknowledge the contribution from his ministry to the areas of child care. While all of the aims that women, and I think the Minister, would like to see achieved cannot be achieved within the first 12 months, considerable achievements have been made in that very important area. If we are to provide more opportunities for women in employment and education, we must also ensure that they are able to take up those opportunities through the provision of proper, quality and adequate child care facilities.

The indexing of pensions is another thing that is of benefit to women because women are so heavily represented amongst pensioners and beneficiaries in our community. Serious consideration has been given by Senator Grimes and his ministry to the area of women's shelters, an area which started largely from individual women's initiatives but which is now seriously supported by this Government in acknowledgment not only of the needs of the shelters but also of the many women who go there and the needs that bring them there.

The Department of Employment and Industrial Relations has established an occupational health and safety interim commission to inquire into occupational health and safety. The importance of occupational health and safety to women and women at work is quite clear to anybody who has been reading the newspapers over the last few months. There has been a large campaign on tenosynovitis, sometimes called rapid repetitive injury syndrome. One would sometimes think that this disease strikes only white collar women workers working with word processors. Anybody who understands industry knows that tenosynovitis is a disease of women working on assembly lines and, for that matter, men working on assembly lines, and is broadly present in industry. It will advantage women when that interim commission recommends the establishment of guidelines for the first commission. That commission will, of course, benefit women.

In the education area, I highlight in particular the participation and equity program so well put forward, argued and established by the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan). This, of course, will not advantage only women but, as I said, tonight I am stressing the advantages of these policies for women. We have also seen the appointment of an Ambassador for Disarmament. For the women in this world matters of peace and nuclear disarmament are a powerful consideration. This Government is right behind that kind of concern. We have also seen the effects of legislation. I simply highlight the amendment to the family law legislation and the significant passage of this Government's sex discrimination legislation through the House of Representatives yesterday. Very timely it was, too, as today is International Women's Day. I think the effects of the sex discrimination legislation in the Federal sphere will bear fruit over many years to come. As a South Australian, I come from a State that has had very similar legislation in place since 1976. From our experience, it is of great benefit to the community and in particular to the women of South Australia.

One of the things that strike me is that all of these changes point to improvements for the future. Maybe we have failed or missed an opportunity to highlight the achievements of women in the past and/or the present. I think we have to acknowledge the importance of the achievements of women not only in terms of how many million dollars they make or how many times they score a century at cricket. I guess that while women have an opportunity to do that, women's cricket is not widely reported; however, I can say for the record that Australia currently holds the world cup for women's cricket. I hope that is a matter of surprise to most because it would confirm my suspicion that our newspapers do not adequately report women's sport. I hope that in looking to the achievements of women we will look at other achievements besides centuries scored or high achievements in business or government. One way in which I think this can be acknowledged is with the increased allocation or awards of the Order of Australia for women. I have written to all women's groups in South Australia urging them to nominate more women for the honours awards next year. If we look through the Order of Australia appointments or awards we see that they cover a whole range of community achievements. It is true that they represent achievements in sport; I like to see achievement in sport acknowledged. But I think we also acknowledge other achievements, in dance, theatre, art, business, community participation and so on.

While those awards are still very much presented to men I would hope that in the future we will see the same acknowledgment given to women. It is for this reason that on this day I have written to the women's groups asking that they give serious consideration to nominating many more women for consideration for the Order of Australia and other Australia Day awards. One of the reasons I have done that is that I have inquired of the Council for the Order of Australia. It suggested that the principle reason not many women were appointed was that not many women were nominated. I understand that some women who have been nominated have not been accepted for those awards. I therefore do not think insufficient nomination is a sufficient explanation. But appreciating that perhaps there has been a shortage of good women nominated, I hope to see many more nominations come through to that Council this year and, hopefully, they will be represented in the honours list next year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the adjournment debate tonight I wish to speak on a subject about which I feel very strongly and on which I believe it is time that action was taken. However, before doing so I would like to clarify a statement that was made during Question Time today by the Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans. He clearly misrepresented by inference my association with the Australian League of Rights. Last year I sent a greeting to a conference in Calgary in which I voiced my support for the League of Rights commitment to Senate rights and maintenance of our Constitution . I would like to put on record though that I have never and will never support any anti-semitic stance by any organisation. As a Christian I find that belief totally unacceptable and indeed repugnant. I take this opportunity to dissociate myself from any reference to anti- semitism.

SPEECH.PARA: In connection with the other matter that I wish to raise tonight, I feel that I have a responsibility, not only as an Australian senator but also as a mother and grandmother, to draw the attention of honourable senators in this chamber- although there are not very many in it I must admit-to the totally unacceptable level of television violence and crudities to which our children are subjected daily and to the increasing number of seedy videos which are finding their way onto the television screens. As all honourable senators would know, much research has been done both in Australia and overseas in recent years about the effects of television violence on young children. Indeed, I am quite sure that at some time or other most honourable senators would have had the experience of seeing totally unsuitable material on children's prime television viewing time. I certainly have. It concerns me greatly when I see the conclusive results of research into this matter which prove a definite co-relation between the level of violence on television and the level of teenage violence in the community.

I have received many representations over the past few months from various community minded organisations and church groups, all of which have expressed grave concern at the amount of bad language, explicit scenes and violence with which our television and movies are infested. Of course, I realise that in some homes such language and behaviour is acceptable. Nevertheless, my concern is that the privacy of the family home is being invaded by television programs and, increasingly, home videos which prove to be less than desirable material for our children to view. I accept the fact that adults should be able to discern for themselves what is suitable or not suitable for their own viewing consumption. But I do feel that where our children are concerned we, as parents, grandparents and as representatives in this place, should be most concerned with what those who choose the television programs dish up.

This is certainly not a new problem. For many years now-almost I suppose since the introduction of television to this country-much has been written and spoken about the amount of explicit language and scenes on television and the way in which children are prone to mimic such behaviour in real life. I think we have all heard horrific stories in the media of children who try to imitate Batman and want to jump off buildings or who mimic the vicious crime fighting antics of what is called the A-Team. But I feel that the situation has gone beyond the acceptable level of childlike behaviour.

Professor Peter Sheehan of the Queensland University Department of Psychology has been researching this area of television violence for many years now. Recently, he made some startling comments on the impact of television violence on children. One of his main concerns is that children tend to model themselves on what they see on the television. I suppose this is particularly true of young boys and their often violent television heroes. When we consider that the average Australian child watches television for something like 18 hours a week and, in some instances, as much as 70 hours-a figure which seems rather hard to go along with, nevertheless, this is what Professor Sheehan tells us-we see that this can indeed prove to be a very real problem.

The research of Professor Sheehan and his team has revealed the results of a contents analysis survey which shows that, in Australia, there are approximately five and a half acts of physical violence each broadcast hour which, I might add , is more than is the case in the United Kingdom and in Canada. I think this should be of real concern to us all. The problem is, of course, that some children find it very difficult to differentiate between the television world and the real world. What they see as the norm on television they feel ought also to be the norm in real life.

I believe that there needs to be a much greater awareness among parents as to what their children are watching on the television. I am convinced that many parents have no idea what their children watch, whether perhaps through lack of time or lack of interest. I guess it does not really matter. The children's program committee does a good job in ensuring that the bulk of television programs during children's viewing time is suitable. But outside this specified period of children's viewing is where I believe the trouble starts. Perhaps it is the responsibility of the industry not to import so much in the way of violent programs, particularly from the United States of America.

We also have a situation where recently the Federal Government passed legislation which will allow hard core, pornographic videos and publications in Australia. Indeed, I understand that a new X rating which is designed for films that are too hot for the movie theatres has been introduced. I do not really think that that sets a very good example for our children. I believe that such movies only further entrench the notion that blatant violence and explicit sexual scenes are acceptable in a community in which I am sure the majority of people do not find them acceptable. I feel it is time that we, as responsible and caring members of the community said: 'No more'. We want our children to grow up having a balanced outlook on life-not one which has been corrupted by excessive violence and explicit scenes.

On a similar theme I would like also to draw attention to the amount of unsuitable printed material which is prevalent and available for our children to read. In fact one has only to walk into the local newsagencies to see something of the type of publications to which I am referring. Whilst I again acknowledge the fact that adults are able to discern for themselves what they wish to read, nevertheless, the abundance of such publications is within the reach of our young children. Even some of the magazines which are distributed to our educational institutions are open to question. Recently I read a publication which is actually supposed to be Australia's contribution to the Year of Youth 1985 in which there are a few sections which I really did not believe to be addressed to youth at all. I must admit that some valuable and worthwhile information was contained in that booklet, which I understand has been put out by the Australian Medical Association. It is unfortunate that there are some parts of it that I believe are really not suitable for our young people.

The whole crux of the matter which I bring before the chamber tonight is the fact that, as parents, we must take our responsibilities to our children very seriously. It is ultimately up to us in our own individual family situations to ensure that the type of television we want our children to see, the movies we want our children to enjoy, and the publications we want our children to learn from are all suitable and, indeed, desirable. We cannot monitor every little bit of information that our children are subject to, but we can take a very active and responsible part in ensuring, as much as possible, that our children are given the very best of visual and mental stimulation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak very briefly tonight, having had no opportunity to do so through the week, against the visit by the Vietnamese Foreign Minister next week as the guest of the Australian Government. Nothing could be more damaging for Australia's place in the world than to have this representative of such a murderous regime here as our guest through that week. It is true that there have been previous high functionaries from the current Vietnamese Government in Australia. We had either the Vice-President or the Deputy Prime Minister here in 1978, but that was before Vietnam moved into and invaded Kampuchea, and it is still there.

SPEECH.PARA: The explanation as to why the Foreign Minister is coming is quite simple: The Australian Labor Party wishes to give developmental aid to Vietnam to help the communist regime. Bringing in the Foreign Minister is part of the conditioning process, part of sanitising this muderous regime so that there will not be political reaction in the country when the move is made to give developmental aid to that nation. The invitation is by the Australian Government. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) will wine and dine Nguyen Co Thach when he comes next week. It illustrates, once again, the double standards followed by this Government. We cannot have two parliamentarians from South Africa in this country because somehow or other society is not free enough to tolerate a point of view which might be abhorrent to all of us, but we can have a representative of this regime here being entertained by the Australian taxpayer.

There are two consequences of this visit by the Vietnamese Foreign Minister. The first is that it directly helps the communist cause because Australia has a position of responsibility in foreign affairs to countries that are not in the region and to countries that are not informed. The fact that a Vietnamese Foreign Minister can come in here puts the imprimatur of respectability on that regime, in just the way that some of those dictatorial regimes in central America are benefiting from the pro-socialist philosophies of this Government by its giving non-residential diplomatic recognition to their regimes. The other consequence of having the Vietnamese Foreign Minister in Australia is that it further damages the Association of South East Asian Nations relationship, a relationship that is now strained almost to breaking point. We need the support of the ASEAN nations. Historically, after World War II Australia really had no place and no contact with the group's that now form the ASEAN alliance. By dint of very hard work by successful Liberal Foreign Ministers following Liberal policies we have built a position where we do not always agree with the ASEAN and South East Asian countries but at least we have a relationship of mutual respect. It is a relationship that this Government seems hell bent on destroying as rapidly as it can.

It is a bit late at night to start going into the background of the disastrous diplomacy that was involved in the denial of support for the ASEAN motion to recognise the Kampuchean coalition, which was moved in the United Nations in September last year, and I will do that at another time. By recognising and inviting the Foreign Minister from Vietnam to Australia we are straining that reliance further than it has been up to the present. We have enormous problems with the Thais over this on matters that have never reached the Press. They have been hidden and whitewashed and sanitised by this Administration. The relationship between Australia and Thailand is very much in disarray and it is in disarray because of the way we are cosying up to the communists in Vietnam.

If we just look at it from a self-interest point of view, we need the support of the ASEAN nations as part of a regional defence policy. In our sector of influence, there are areas in which we are going to be trading and through which we are getting our oil supplies from the Mediterranean to Japan. We have the Russians, with a proven history of expansion, supporting the Syrians. They have occupied and usurped Afghanistan. India is a servile client state. It signed a treaty with the Russians in 1971. It has one of the largest navies in the world, a navy which is rapidly being expanded for no functional or defensive use for India but purely as a client of the Russian communist expansion into the Indian Ocean. Around the corner to Vietnam is Cam Ranh Bay. From intelligence reports, over 100 Russian aircraft are based there-not Vietnamese aircraft, Russian aircraft. The harbour is the port for the Russian nuclear submarines operating out of Petropavlovsk and for other Russian surface ships.

The best view we can put on this Government's actions is that it is naive and it is ignorant. The worst view is that it is treasonable. I do not attach the blame for this to Mr Hayden alone. Quite clearly, as a member of this Government , as a Minister of the Government, he represents a considered Cabinet view. For this Government to be prattling on about peace in Kampuchea and how peace could be achieved simply by having an honest broker go up there, quite oblivious of the history of thousands of years of warface, just strains the credulity of the Australian population. The reason we do not have peace in Kampuchea is because the communist Vietnamese went in there on Christmas Day 1978. They went in there on Christmas Day 1978 because on 8 November 1978 they signed the treaty of friendship and co-operation with Russia. That treaty has a clause which relates to the military activities of both countries, which concerned some of us at the time, and it has been the guise under which Vietnam has gone on its expansionist role into Kampuchea. I would like to quote briefly from a statement by Mr Hawke when he was in Thailand on 21 November 1983. He stated:
Australia strongly mindful of these risks, is concerned that continued isolation of Vietnam will only serve to exacerbate or heighten those risks.
It is in none of our interests that Vietnam continues to be in a situation of virtual isolation in the international community resting almost solely on a relationship with the Soviet Union.

I will come back to the point about the relationship with the Soviet Union in a moment. While the Vietnamese are in Kampuchea, they have seized the country, they have displaced the refugees and they are using them as a human barrier against the Thais on the Thai border. That little act has cost Australia, in refugee support, $50m in the last few years. We have given more humanitarian aid to the refugees in Kampuchea per head of population than has any other country in the world. It is a most inhuman way to go on. That leads me to one of the most galling things about the Labor Party's relationship with Vietnam. The great champions of human rights in this country are members of the Labor Party. The performance, though, never backs up the rhetoric. One would not meet a regime in the world with a worse record for human rights than the present Government in Vietnam. The only crowd that can come near them is the Ayatollah Khomeini's regime in Iran.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Pol Pot?

—Pol Pot probably is not as bad as the Vietnamese. The honourable senator is splitting hairs. I will have to concede that they are pretty close, but the Pol Pot regime is not a government; the Vietnamese Government is a government. Australia does not have a relationship with the Pol Pot regime. I take Senator Grimes back to the treatment by the Vietnamese of the allied prisoners through the Vietnam war. It was every bit as bad as that of the Japanese in the Second World War. They only modified their treatment of allied prisoners towards 1970 when they realised that the inhumane torture and murder was having an adverse effect on public opinion around the world, so they backed off. If Senator Grimes looked at their present treatment of political prisoners and the way they are shipping people around the world as slave labour to satisfy their alliance with the Soviet bloc he would not be so critical of my comments. The Australian Labor Party supports these people because it wants to give aid to Vietnam to satisfy its socialist beliefs. Last year on a quite dishonest basis Australia gave $500,000, allegedly for humanitarian aid, to Vietnam. It realised it could not give it as development aid, so it gave it as humanitarian aid on the basis of typhoon damage. There was no unusual typhoon activity in Vietnam in 1983. No suffering was occasioned by it. The whole thing was a trumped-up fabrication to get money into Vietnam.

SPEECH.PARA: I return to the disinformation contained in Mr Hawke's address in Thailand in November, when he stated that it was an intolerable situation to have Vietnam relying entirely on its relationship with the Soviet Union. Many honourable senators on the other side of the chamber would say that we must be kind to the Vietnamese because if we do not, they will be reliant on the Russians. Do they really believe we can take over the $2,000m a year that the Russians are currently paying? Do they really believe we can put in 10,000-plus advisers? Do they really believe we can support it economically in the way in which the Russians are doing? Do they really believe we can abrogate the treaty that the Vietnamese have signed which runs for 25 years from 8 November 1978? This is disinformation in the classical Russian way. Australians want no part of it. We want no part of any association with Vietnam and its murderous representatives until they are prepared to live honestly amongst the community of nations, until they are prepared to respect and observe the many resolutions, ever since they moved into Kampuchea on Christmas Day 1978, to vacate that country and to get right out. Then we will be prepared to talk to them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Primmer made some remarks about officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs. I have no knowledge of anything he has said tonight but I want to point out that he has made charges of this type before which have been investigated by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) and the Department of Foreign Affairs. I will refer the matters to the Minister for his attention. Senator Kilgariff talked once again about the Northern Territory Criminal Code and the Federal Government 's objections to that Code. I will refer that also, as I have no expertise in that area, to the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) for him to deal with. Senator Crowley spoke learnedly and at some length about International Women's Day and the contribution of the present Government to women. I found it interesting and enlightening.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Bjelke-Petersen spoke of her concern for the amount of violence and sexually explicit behaviour-I think that was the term she used-on television. I found it interesting, but was unable to elicit from her speech any actual details of some of the publications and films she was talking about. I am certainly sure the Australian Medical Association will be interested that Senator Bjelke-Petersen finds one of its documents risque, if not obscene. She also mentioned a matter which arose in Question Time today when Senator Gareth Evans questioned her apparent support for the Australian League of Rights. I am glad that Senator Bjelke-Petersen does not support the anti-semitic utterances of that organisation. I hope she also does not support some of the other extremist statements it makes about race relations generally, about white supremacy generally, and some of its strange economic views. I think it is very difficult for someone in Senator Bjelke-Petersen's position, or anyone else in this place, to associate with an organisation like that on the ground that it apparently supports States' rights in our written Constitution and ignore all the other undesirable areas it mentions.

Senator MacGibbon demonstrated that some things never change in this Parliament or this country. There will always be people who will speak about foreign affairs in the way in which Senator MacGibbon did. He has talked tonight about disinformation. He made allegations about the present Government's relationships with the Association of South East Asian Nations which he says are strained to breaking point. He gave no evidence for that except an assertion of his own. I would have thought that the recent visits by Mr Hayden and Mr Hawke to that area and their relationships with the ASEAN Ministers demonstrated to the Australian people the opposite to what Senator MacGibbon was saying. With regard to our relationships with Thailand, he not only made the assertion that they are almost at breaking point, but also that there was some cover-up and conspiracy not only by the present Government but also by the Press in this country to hide this from the Australian people. In the absence of any evidence, I do not believe that I can take that seriously, nor do I think anyone else will. I do not think our relationships with other countries are helped by honourable senators from either side of the chamber saying, for instance, that India is a servile client state of the Soviet Union and making assertions of that type.

I will refer Senator MacGibbon's remarks to the Foreign Minister but I doubt whether he will take them any more seriously than I do or than the Press apparently does. As I say, some things never change. We were told by the predecessors of Senator MacGibbon that the Vietnamese were actually clients of the Chinese, that we were spending hundreds of millions of dollars in Vietnam, raining bombs on that country and killing people, to stop the downward flow of the Chinese. We had the extraordinary situation of a Minister for Foreign Affairs of this country going to Russia and warning the Russians that what the Vietnamese were doing was on behalf of the Chinese. The gentlemen in the Kremlin in those days must have laughed to hear that sort of nonsense. I think what we need in this world is rational behaviour on both sides in regard to foreign affairs. We certainly have not had it from Senator MacGibbon tonight.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —on 17 November 1983 (Hansard, page 2755) Senator Lajovic asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs , without notice, whether I had seen newspaper reports about the decline during the June quarter in both overall arrivals and permanent settler arrivals and to provide exact figures on

ANSWER.PARA: (1) how many permanent settlers arrived during the quarter;
(2) which countries they came from;
(3) how many belonged to the family re-union category; and
(4) how many came as refugees.
The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Australian Bureau of Statistics, ABS, figures, to which the newspaper reports referred, show a decline in total arrivals (which include settler arrivals, Australian residents returning home and long and short term temporary entrants) during the June quarter of some 40,000 over total arrivals during the same period of 1982 and seem to reflect a trend evident over the past three quarters.
